content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												This game is targeted at a very niche group of people. Best to describe it as "inspiring" After finishing it you will feel like putting on a record of some old french chanson, grab "Mario and the Magician" by Thomas Mann and spend the rest of the evening reading and thinking about the lost world of circuses, magicians, and cabarets. If you have the slighest doubt about the world shown in the trailers, or you find yourself not interested in the world of the 1920s cabaret-world at all then my advice is to stay away from this game. You will simply not enjoy it based only on the gameplay or story because it has it's flaws (quite a few unfortunately). I made a pros and cons list just to show it in detail.Pros:- absolutely amazing, beautiful world. a true artistic masterpiece.- brilliant soundtrack, there are a very few games that come close in quality and execution.- great sound design (I'm talking about the fade-outs, reverbs and use of filters)- an interesting (but poorly executed) content.- tons of potential- interesting characters- puzzles requiring "out of the box" thinking.Cons:- horrendous glitchy gameplay with a tons of bugs (rage inducing at times)- glitchy and shaky camera movement- unresponsive controls (I played with mouse+keyboard)- mediocre story- a small game world, invisible walls not really meant for exploring (except for a few collectibles)- relatively short game time (3-4 hours including collectibles)As you can see I personally enjoyed my journey with "Contrast" but I'm sure it's not going to be a mainstream success. If you still feel like buying it after reading this review then I'm sure you will love the game (knowing what to expect)

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
A Child's Imagination Come To LifeMy boyfriend grabbed this for me because he knew I'd been anticipating this game since it was announced. Contrast is a noir-mystery that's filled with creativity, empowering messages, and gorgeous graphics. You play Dawn, a picturesque, fashionable, speech-impaired woman who can fade into the shadows, unseen by the colorful characters that walk among your partner in crime. You're there to aid Didi, a brave, optimistic, imaginative young girl trying to pick up the pieces her broken family leaves behind. The still life of everything around Didi and Dawn are metaphorical in that it makes the situation seem dark and bleak until you play through the puzzles and breathe life into everything.I would have had a problem with the length had the story not been executed as well as it was. The mechanics are unique and unlike anything I'd seen before and it seems like they've fixed all the glitches fans mentioned. I also used a controller so shifting from 2D to 3D and vice versa was done with ease. About midway, I started wondering who Dawn was and how she spawned from Didi's mind and was left with a treat in the end when all of my questions were answered.This game has a lot to offer and if you ever get a chance to pick it up, do it.9/10

												This game, without the glitches and bugs, is a 4/5 easy. However with all the little bugs, glitches, and invisible walls I just couldn't enjoy it. 2/5 in the end.I wanted to love it, but there's only so many bugs you can take.The environment is amazing and surreal, visuals are cool, the shifting concept is very unique, and the gameplay is basic but solid.The downside comes when you start actually trying to complete puzzles or shift into the walls, Dawn (the character your play as) constantly jumps out of the walls, gets stuck on little edges in the shadows, or cannot jump due to invisible roofs or walls. I've never gotten motion sickness before from a game, but like some other people, this game did indeed give me motion sickness after about 30 minutes.Its about a 2 hour game that takes over 3 and a half hours as you have to try sequences over and over and over again because Dawn keeps glitching out of the walls or getting stuck on elements in the environment :(

												Contrast is small, but it makes big in our hearts.We take the roll of Dawn, a shadow presence only seen by a small girl named Didi. The youngster is curious about the world, and has a dream; bring her family together.While we use the shadows to solve puzzles and protect Didi, we get ourselves wrapped in a plot to help Didi's family, or what's left of it. A father who is involved in shady mob-business, a mother who sings at a club, and a strange magician who is somehow related to Didi. A beautiful plot within an even gorgeous 1920's atmosphere, full of hopes and dreams disguised in the deadly shadows of the alleys.Although the puzzles start on an easy way, it soon requires you do make use of your grey cells, and when you’re really enjoying, it ends...! Collecting achievements is fun, and will maybe give you a reason to go back a second time.Overall the game presents a nice experience, with a nice soundtrack that take you back several decades to an era of glamour.I give it a 7/10. It's amazing, but short. Twice the length, and it would be a solid 9!

												Recommended with some reservations.....“It’s as if Limbo and Bioshock Infinite had a baby while watching Pan’s Labyrinth”VENTUREBEATNo, just no. It's as if Echochrome II & Rain dry humped to an episode of Sesame Street. The game from a conceptual point of view has so much in it's favour - noir setting, the shadow based puzzles, a storyline & characters which have potential to be interesting. In my eyes however the noir setting and general atmosphere is flat and lifeless given the themes and what they had to work with. The shadow based puzzles are simplistic and clumsy in the majority of cases favouring artsy fartsy stylings over the kind of truly satisfying, mind bending puzzles you'd get from say Echochrome/shift, Portal or Swapper. The storyline almost offers redemption with gray areas being left for the player to fill in the gaps based on scraps of information gained from collectibles, info within the lighthouse and the game ending.That said, this is a positive review. I played to completion & enjoyed it - the metascores are correct, it's a 6/10 game which had huge potential but falls short in so many areas and relies heavily on styling.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												I had much higher hopes for this game. The premise is neat - you control Dawn who can literally "shrink into the shadows." However, the execution is poor; the controls are clunky; the story is cliche; the writing is atrocious; and the voice acting is grating.The game is broken (intentional pun) into three acts and tells the story of Didi who is the only one that sees Dawn. While you can shrink into the shadows, the lights only light up in the areas where there is a puzzle. Everywhere else, there are no shadows. Given some of the platform jumping needed for the puzzles, the controls are wonky. They are extremely loose and the camera wanders which makes the POV confusing. Sometimes you will do a puzzle and the camera is in one location. The next time (because you fell) it is located differently and can't be moved to a better location because it is stuck or something.There are collectables in the game that are easy to collect. They are usually in your path and have blue sparkles swirling around them. In addition, there are several luminaires in the level. These are balls of lights that can be used to power equipment. These are spread through the level - some in your path (enough to finish the level) others in harder to reach areas. However, in many cases if you don't get them you can't get them later. In order to get full completion, you have to start over. I did this several times. Frustrating...There are no people in the game, other than Didi. Key story points are told through shadow figures. (My wife saw Didi's mom and made a comment that she wouldn't be able to stand and likely would end up on her face she was so top heavy.) This is interesting enough, but the shadows clip through the environment. Along with the voice acting, I was pressing the "Y" button to skip them. Some special swirling items activate "special" shadow show puzzles to flesh out the story.Its not all bad. Some of the puzzles are clever. Act II is pretty neat. Didi needs to fix a circus for her dad. And as I said, the idea has potential, just poorly executed in my opinion. It is hard to recommend this game, especially at full price. Wait for a sale. A good sale and don't expect too much.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												Contrast is a stylish platformer that doesn't entirely manage to convince. Let's start with the graphics. They\re quite stylish, '30-'40's style, but they're also a bit dark sometimes. As a result fine details aren't sometimes clear enough. Nothing gamebreaking but a bit disappointing. And while the game makes you think the world is open there's usually only one correct path to follow. You can run around a bit and try to collect orbs or collectibles, but it's nothing fancy. Where Contrast shines, however, is the fact that it allows the main character to use shadows in order to solve puzzles. It's unique and usually works quite well, but there were a few times where the game got glitchy, getting the character stuck in the environment or switching to your 3D form while still using these shadows.There's also a story which is actually fine, just not very well realized. There's a connection with the little, physical girl but whenever there's a shadow conversation it's hard to connect with these characters, because they're just that; shadows.The music is actually well done, with some nice jazzy tunes in it. The voice acting is also done extremely well for a game of this caliber.The game ended after about 3 hours, which gave me mixed feelings. I kinda wished it was longer, but, you know, bigger and better. But because it's not I was actually glad it was over. It felt a little bit too gimmicky. Which is a shame, because you can clearly see the game was created with passion.[Rating: 72/100]

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												FIrst thing you need to know: this is a very short game. Even taking it slow and going back for 100% achievements I only got about 4 hours out of it. On that basis alone you probably want to wait for it to go on a pretty major sale. In fact the length of the game is one of the main reasons I'm not recommending it. For a game to be so short I feel that it needs to make up for it by being either increadibly good or extremely original. Or very very cheap. I seem to be in the minority, but I don't think Contrast quite made up its length on any of these.As far as the game itself; it was fairly good but there were a few things I felt let it down. The story was a little childish, naive, and predictable. While it delt with some darker topics, things turned positive way too quick to seem real or satisfying. The world in which the game was set was interesting and had some great ideas, but also suffered from a slight vagueness which I think was meant to be mysterious and intriguing but didn't ring true to me. Personally  I'm used to my fictional worlds being a little more conrete and storylines a little less sickly sweet, but given the other ratings that seems to be a matter of taste.The platforming integrated with the shadow mechanic which the game centres around was both novel and enjoyable if straitforward. The levels were fairly pretty, and the jaz theme throughout suited it very well, but they were also quite small and sparse. Honestly if it was longer (both for playtime and to stretch the conclusions to storylines) it could have been a very good game. As it is, it turned out fairly good but not something I'd recommend. Excepting on sale.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
A Cute, enjoyable Noir gameContrast is a fun, neat little platformer. In Contrast, you play Dawn, the silent 'imaginary' friend of a young girl named Didi, whose mother is a cabaret singer. Throughout the game you help her solve puzzles and get past obstacles by using Dawn's ability to 'shadow walk' in 2.5 style platforming sequences.While the game is not a technical marvel, Contrast oozes atmosphere. Inspired by a 1920's vaudeville style, the game features impressive if somewhat linear levels. The choice to make almost all of the characters actually shadows of themselves thrown on to a wall Dawn is platforming across is a very nice touch that allows for almost all of the story to be explained while you're playing the game, so cutscenes are down to a minimum(in fact, there are only two or three actual 3d models of characters in the entire game, one of them being Dawn, the player character) while giving you something to pay attention to in cooperation with the gameplay.Gameplay wise, Contrast is fun, but is hampered somewhat by glitches and clipping issues. Some parts can be aggravating simply because Dawn clips weirdly into a shadow or hits a part of a wall that randomly ejects her from her shadow persona, usually over a bottomless pit that resets you at the start of the current section. Despite this, the shadow puzzles are well thought out and interesting, and despite hearing a lot of complaints in the reviews on the camera, I found that the developers managed to make the camera do what the player wanted(many times I found the camera 'locked' to a certain axis, which made platformer easier and highlighted spots I should be focusing on). There are many times when Dawn got caught on pieces of the level, or clipped at the edge of a shadow and simply threw me back out again, failing the puzzle. However, these issues were minor enough that there were only one or two times I truly felt the game was entirely at fault. Contrast's level design is pretty solid, though very linear, with the world well conceptualized to mix between shadow movements and 3d overworld sections, which serve to move you from one section to another. Occasionally I did find sections where it wasn't clear where I was supposed to go(In one, I had to resort to a walkthrough simply because the game's lighting hadn't highlited a jump point properly)This is not a very long game, but I think I like that(the entire game and all collectibles took a few hours at best). Not every game has to be 60 hours of content. Like a movie, this game has a story to tell and it's good at pacing itself for that story without dragging. The best description I can give for the playthrough is 'comfy'. It's not particularly hard, but a few of the puzzles make you think. And that's really Contrast's largest failing, in that the game is relatively easy for these sorts of games. I think this is by design, as it feels like some things were made simpler for a younger audience. Collectibles are sprinkled directly in paths you'll be heading anyway, and simply add little flairs to the story exposition wouldn't be able too, so I have no complaint with them.All in all, Contrast is a pretty decent buy for the price, though some leery of its short play time might want to consider wishlisting and waiting for a steam sale.ProsNovel ideaInteresting StyleChildren-friendly gameplayConsOccasional glitch/clipping issuesShort play time.No replay value.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												This game won my heart. Few games can be considered a visual and audio delight such as Contrast is. It is definitely not for everyone, not action packed or with potential cliffhangers but it’s by far a star. It’s the result mix between the 20's- 30's atmosphere, the vintage representation of the decadent circus life, the dream shards of a Parisian street, and the film-noir instrumentals. It has clever and most importantly aesthetic puzzles, playing with memories and shadows. It does however have its disappointments: few bugs and glitches that may at times annoy the player a bit. I also heard that people have problems playing the game itself because it freezes (it happened to me as well but only on short period of times) and crashes; and of course, the biggest problem of the game is that it’s too short. I would have adored to spend more hours of gameplay; not only that but because the game is too short we have to take the characters as they are, with few information about them and we have to adjust to the ‘momentary’ feeling of the plot. In what concerned the characters and the story telling: it’s a great plus. Until the end it makes you wonder what is reality and what not, what is fantasy and what is science. You get to see all these interesting side characters and discover that, in truth, the story is about them. It’s a game perfect to play during the evening and I encourage anyone with a bit of taste for the aesthetics to try it.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												For a 3D platformer the games controls are, to say the least, lackluster. There's a jump, a dash, and the ability to merge onto walls that have light on them. Aside, from these there's the ability to dash in the air and that's really it, unlike most other 3D platformers you don't really have a progression with more abilities added on or building on concepts. Luckily, it doesn't have the same issue as many other 3D platformers in that the camera doesn't fight against you a lot, though there are still moments of it.If you like to go fast, the dash is slightly faster than the walking speed so you'll probably end up just spamming the button to move around (With the exception of going down slopes as the time it takes to fall after each dash on the slope is often longer than just walking down.).The puzzles are often very easy, almost as if this game was designed for children. With the final level being an exception. In that chapter, instead of being too easy the puzzles are then made to be super vague and it seems like this portion was rushed as it lacks in polish compared to the rest of the game.As a bit of a side note, I managed to bruteforce my way through most jumping puzzles by abusing the dash in the game (You can dash as you unmerge from a wall and this lead to dashing while merged on a wall then unmerging and dashing.)By contrast, the story is very mature with a lot of talk about divorce, murder, and the like (Spoiler: There's even a scene where the little girl's mother attempts to kill her husband.). So that assures me that this game isn't meant for children. Like it's been said, this game can be 100% in a very short time. I beat the game with around 80% completion in about an hour and a half. It then took about another half hour to tie up the other achievements I missed. So you will not be getting a whole lot of time out of this game.I'd say there's one thing that makes this game fall short and that's it's lack of freedom and lack of replayability.Now let me explain what I mean by lack of freedom, the game feels like it might be an open world, or even Banjo Kazooie or Mario 64-esque hub world with stages, at first, but you soon realize it's a linear story with chapters and many many invisible walls. In the first area if you explore you can find the secret room with the donator names and I was hoping there would be more secrets like this as the game went on, but no that's the only really optional area in the game. Aside from that there are the lumes(?) spread around in the world and a completionist would want to go an collect those, but you only need about half of the lumes in a given area to proceed. This brings forth the question, why are there so many when you need so few?Onto the lack of replayability, the whole reason to play this game is for the story. The gameplay is decent, but what is going to keep people playing is the story of the game. Once you know the story there's no reason to come back to it.I was going to go back and try a speedrun of the game, but the amount of cutscenes and unskippable dialouge killed it for me. I'm certain there's plenty of ways to break the game, skip event triggers, and the like, but I don't want to put that much work into a game that, frankly, I don't like that much.

												The Contrast Collector's Edition was gifted to me for $4.99.Now, Contrast is a relatively short indie game with a few glitches here and there. Puzzles may take some people a long time, but for the most part they were easy and entertaining (in my opinion). I would not buy Contrast for the base price, however at a discounted price, of course I would, no doubt.The storyline is quite deep and a complete analysis of what's going on/has gone on/will happen will take forever because of the unexpected plot twists. Again, like some Indie games, the focus was on Dawn, the supporting character you play. Technically the main character is Didi as she is the one you're helping. I still have many questions and am quite frustrated because my questions cannot be answered. I would love to have some sort of a sequel of this pleasant Indie game which focusses more on Dawn and Dawn's predecessor (Aurora). I want to know more about the Shadow World and how it works, along with information about Didi's interactions, and why no one in the 'Shadow World' can interact with Dawn while she is a Shadow etc. But a good game, just like a good book. leaves the player with unanswered questions that you feel a burning need to get answered...I hope the new game that Compulsion is developing will focus on the Shadow World. There is a giant plot twist at the end of this game, by the way! I give this game a 8/10.

Posted: October 9, 2016
A very well presented and unique "game noir".I really like the story and style of this game! It's like it's been made by Tim Burton, Tom Waits, Jim Jarmush and Walt Disney.^^Summed up, the story is about a little girl named Didi and her imaginary friend, Dawn.You play Dawn, who can walk in the shadows and uses this ability to go to places where Didi can't go. All people, except of Didi, are seen only as shadows. Thus you sometimes experience pieces of the tale by climbing silhouettes of e.g. Didi's parents while fighting.There are some - more or less difficult - brain twisters to solve...Most of them associated with swithing fromshadow to shadow or placing lights the right way, so that the shadow casted by the environment helps you to reachthe next location.The grafics are fine, but could have been better. Especially the textures and antialiasing! All in all this game is just the right game to play now and then or while another more time consuming one (For me Witcher 3).

content:

												Horrible playing, amazing concept and story5/10------------------------------I really really wanted to like this game.  But it just... is not that good. The concept, the art style, jumping between to worlds seems amazing and in fact really is but on the other hand playing is totally frustrating sometimes.Thing is you start this extremely weird looking game and be like "oh god this looks awesome" and after some time you discover that you can switch between 2 worlds and you go "that is AMAZING". But after that you really play it and it is just HORRIBLE. Every 5 minutes you get into the moment when you know what to do, how to get there but the game is somehow broken and you just cant do it. Massive bugs and awful checkpoint system make it a bad game.When you 10 times fall from the ledge and the girl tells you for 11th time to "hahah i know what to do..." and repeat that same monolog she already did 10 times.. you just wanna throw a brick in her face.Contrast has looked sooo amazing at the store page so I've bought it in sale for like 5 € and I would really regret buying this game if it was at the full price. I have had to convince myself to give the game another shot to finish the story but it was for the purpose of finishing the game and not enjoying. There is a little chance for you to enjoy the game but for me it was just a horrible experience which is a shame because i mostly love these arty, weirdo games.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												A short (~4 hours, with all collectibles) romp through 1920's vaudeville culture that tells the story of a broken family trying to pick up the pieces of shattered dreams, and a little girl trying to make the best of everything, in spite of it. The game is short, to the point, and entertaining, though slippery and squirrelly controls at some parts give a bit of frustration to some of the more precise platforming moments. Puzzles are mostly simple and serve just to break up the platofrming flow, which is nothing super timed or intense. There is no combat in the game whatsoever, despite what the trailers obtusely hint at. It is pure platforming. The game is very linear, with side treks purely for collecting objects that lend a bit of backstory to the events that occur in the game.Everything in the game comes together to emphasize the environmental aspects, pushing the circus and performance aspects with heavy jazz and lounge singer themes, and it all comes together wonderfully. Some story bits at the end seem to have been left intentionally vague and up to interpretation, and it causes a bit of heas scratching as to how things "actually work", but it's nothing that detracts from the actual experience.An easy recommendation for almost anyone.

												Contrast was really a beautiful experience. Glad to have discover this great game with the Focus Creative week sale. The graphics are extremely pleasant and will bring you back to the 20's nostalgy, with a beautiful mix of influences, from the Vaudeville to the parisian streets abundant with Art Nouveau and Art Deco building, passing to the Film Noir. The Gameplay is addictive and original; (I suggest to use a controller for a better experience) permitting you to pass from the physical, 3D world to the shadowy's in 2D. The OST is astonishing and will please for sure to every Blues/Swing/Dixieland/Jazz Manouche fans and emphasize your immersion in this unique world. The game, sadly, is super short... It would have deserved a longer story! But in the end, you'll definitely love it! ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Contrast fut vraiment une belle expérience. Ravie d'avoir pu découvrir ce superbe jeu durant la semaine Focus Creative.Les graphismes sont extrêmement plaisants et vous ramèneront dans la nostalgie des années 20, le tout avec un merveileux mélange d'influences, du Vaudeville aux rues parisiennes foisonnantes de bâtiments style Art Nouveau et Art Déco, en passant par les classiques du Film Noir.Le Gameplay est addictif et original (je conseille d'utiliser une manette pour plus de plaisir) vous permettant le passage entre le monde physique en 3D et le monde des ombres en 2D.L'OST est étonnante et plaira à tous les fans de Blues/Swing/Dixieland/Jazz Manouche qui se respèctent, tout en amplifiant votre immersion dans cet univers unique.Le jeu, malheureusement, souffre d'une durée de vie trop courte... L'histoire aurait mérité quelques heures de plus! En fin de compte, c'est un jeu que vous apprécierez à coup sûr!

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
Amazing journey through shadows...It's about: helping charming little girl (yep, Telltale has created a trend); solving puzzles. Why you should play this: fresh concept: switching between 3D and 2D worlds helps you go through levels by solving puzzles, the core of each puzzle is creating a shadow from the object by moving a source of light; it's incredibly stylish: the atmosphere of the beginning of 20th century, cabaret, circus – all that covered with the thin layer of noire and touching main theme;  it offers simple, but intriguing story about human fears and desires, mistakes and regrets, renown and family, desperation and relief; you like Portal series and missed to play something similar; you like puzzles and platformers.Why you may not like it: you don't like charming little girls and hate to help them; you fed up with stories about family importance; you may find ending too corny: the atmosphere is charged with mystery (or even tragedy), but final turns around a fairytale; it's short: 4 hours to meet credits, maybe it will take 5 hours to get all achievements; there's no zombies to kill.Do yourself a favour – spend 4 hours of your leisure time by playing this game: from start to end without break… The feeling of journey, the bouquet of mystery, the world of dreams, memories and shadows won’t let you be bored. It’s like a flash of falling star – bright and momentary, but something to remember.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												While the ideas that drive Contrast are fantastic, the execution of this game is somewhat lacking. It's not a terrible game by any means. The music and atmosphere are enough to keep you entertained, and some of the puzzles are cleverly designed with both 2D and 3D in mind. However overall this game never amounts to more than a resounding "meh." Many of the puzzles offer too much frustration for too little of a reward, and for a game as short as this (around 3 hours) most of your time will be spent watching cutscenes. Even the story leaves much to be desired, leaving off just when things start to become interesting.If the atmosphere of the screenshots and trailers seems appealing to you, I definitely recommend this during a sale. Other than that though, I hate to say it's really not worth the effort. 2/5

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Late 2014, local bar in the middle of who cares USA. I was sitting at the bar alone, like usual, watching as groups of people all around me were having fun and drinking. Some were catching up with old friends like Half-Life 2 and remembering the good old days; others were becoming well aquainted with the new guy in town, his name was Far Cry 4 and he was busy wowing people left and right with his fantastic adventures. Yet in between seeing someone introducing themselves to Octodad with hysterical laughter and another person meeting Bioshock Infinite for the first time, a young lady caught my eye. She seemed different, almost as if there was a charm to her existence that pierced the heavens with her classy look; it's as if she had just arrived in town, yet I could have sworn I met her before.I asked someone sitting at the bar next to me who she was. The response was worse than what I had expected, "Oh that's Contrast, lovely girl; I heard she's pretty cheap too but I wouldn't risk the missus finding out so I don't know personally." What a dissapointment, I must've seen her standing on the side of the road one day; and to think, for a $15.00 I could've gotten to know her better, but I was a taken man myself. I place heavy emphasis on the WAS. My night wasn't getting any better, I was lonely, depressed, I needed to feel something again and I figured she would be the one.I walked up to her and introduced myself, she hardley seemed interested in what I thought of her, yet her artistic nature spoke volumes to me. "What's a classy platformer like you doing in a bar like this?" She turned away from me, almost as if she was preparing for the onslaught of abuse I had planned for her. "Do you like platformers?" her voice was shaking, she felt the judgement of the whole bar raining down on her as we talked. I leaned in close, grabbed her shoulders and whispered, "I love platformers." She turned back around, her face was stone cold but I could see into her eyes, they were filled with happiness and ecstasy; I must've been the nicest person she's met in years because she said, "for you it will be $3.00." Now I may not be a detective, but from the way her eyes rolled towards the ground, I could tell she already regretted dropping the price for me. That didn't stop me from accepting the offer, but I did feel like I should give her more anyways, just so she feels better about herself.We head back to my place, this couch has seen much action but this was a rare exception. How could someone of this beauty and elegance possibly put up with her lifestyle. Just before I turned off the lights, I touched her back and brought her close, I could hear her breathing intensify. But she didn't bring me in closer, she pushed me away; she answered my confusion with a question of her own, "can I sing for you first?""What?""Most clients love it when I sing to them before... we get down to business."A little confused, I figured it would be best if she was as comfortable as possible before we began, so I gave her permission. (Listen to this: 


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



. As she started singing, I got mesmerized. Her story was strong and to the point, she has been hurt, perhaps that's what lead her down this road; her voice was beautiful, the song was perfectly put together, slow, smooth and reflected what to expect from this game.Contrast is one of a very small group of games where I feel the artistic vision is met to my satisfaction and doesn't appear to be trying too hard or too little to get across what it wants to portray. You view the situations that happen throughout the story both through the eyes or an innocent child and your own personal observations, giving the game a sort of dual perspective that leave the second part entirely up to your own observations. There is a plot twist as well that leads to a revelation I couldn't even fathom feeling for myself, leaving my reaction up to what the child felt when everything was revealed to her. The bond you have with the child as you play all while being a silent observer of the story made me feel different from other games, almost like another game I played recently and would love to play again (not going to mention it here).Other than the story, the gameplay and graphics seem to compliment eachother really well. The game takes place in  a Noir styled France stuck in a sort of purgatory where people can switch between either being a shadow or manifesting themselves in an actaul human form. I know, that sound weird, but the shadow swapping leads to some really cool ideas when it comes to the puzzle sections. You will occasionally have to think while moving objects in the third dimension in order to create and modify shadows in the second dimension in order to reach new areas. It can be tricky at times yet feels very satisfying when you succeed at some of the trickier puzzles.Yet, at the end of the day, the time I spent with the lovely lady was short lived. 2.9 hours on record is a bummer considering I actually went out of my way to collect as many of the hidden collectibles as I could find and still beat the game short of 3 hours. The world is very interesting, the gameplay is challenging (despite the controls feeling a little off) and the story is realistic and a little troubling, but in a good way. At the end of the day, I would recommend her to anyone who likes puzzle platformers, just be sure treat her the same was I did, or she's not worth your time.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Contrast feels like a half-finished game that got pushed out the door because the developer ran out of money. It has a few neat ideas, but it never executes well enough for them to shine.Controls are passable, but not very satisfying. You don't feel very connected to Dawn, your character. It feels very 90s PS1 3D platformer, and not in a good way.The primary mechanical hook is the ability to step into and out of shadows to traverse terrain you couldn't ordinarily cross. It's interesting and there are some good puzzles, but like everything else in Contrast it feels unfinished. It's very easy to accidentally fall out of shadows and back into 3D, and some puzzles can be difficult only because it's hard to get the right angle to make a jump and stay in 2D.Any flow you might establish is ruined when the game constantly takes control of the camera so Didi can yell at you or tell you to follow her. I found this very annoying.The story is paper thin.There are a lot of sequence breaks, noclip glitches, and invisible platforms. If you're looking for something fun to speedrun, Contrast might worth a look for that.Check it out if you catch it on sale, but it is in no way worth $15.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												There is a lot to like about this game. It has an interesting story, and the 'noir' atmospheric setting works well with the game and it's main mechanic - being able to enter and move using shadows and light.The puzzles are fun and strike a good balance of difficulty, while the collectibles / achievements are not too obnoxious to find and add a little replay-ability - I was able to find most collectibles during my first play through without hunting around too much.The story is also interesting and keeps everything moving along nicely.However, there are a couple of criticisms. Firstly, what some might see as a fault is the short length of the game. It only takes around 3 hours to fully complete (including achievements) although some might play faster than others. Also, although I didn't experience any glitches, the puzzles where you have to carry objects while sometimes interesting do slow the pace of the game down a bit.My biggest criticism is the abrupt ending. Without spoiling it, I will say that the game ends quite suddenly and while I knew the end was coming I was expecting there to be some explanation for how / why events were playing out.Overall I would recommend this game, despite the criticisms it is fun, but I would only really buy this game during a sale as I don't think it is worth the price without any discounts.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
												This is a fantastic puzzle/platforming game that has some unique gameplay elements, a great story and wonderful voice acting. You play as Dawn, who goes around helping a young child named Didi fix various things in an attempt to save her father from trouble and resolve some turmoil with her parents. You’ll also uncover some twists along the way. The time period, art style and graphics are all very well done. It’s set in the 1920’s and it captures that vibe perfectly. Gameplay is unique, well implemented and fun. You’re able to transition from 3d space to 2d shadows. If you switch to shadows, then that becomes the ground or “physical” part of the world and allows you to traverse areas that wouldn’t be accessible otherwise. Shadows in general is a massive part of this game. The story is told via silhouettes and you even have to solve some puzzles while a silhouette scene is going on by using their moving shadows as a way to reach higher areas. It’s really cool. The puzzles serve up a small challenge. Nothing hard, though. With a little bit of thought, you’ll be able to solve them. Voice acting is terrific. Every character is unique and has their own personality.This game is very short. I logged about 4 hours to complete it will all achievements. The controls (I used a 360 controller) are decent. Character movement can be awkward at times and felt like they could use more polish. Pros+60fps+Great gameplay with shadows+Engaging & interesting story+Solid Music+Terrific voice actingCons+Short, about 4 hours+Character movement sometimes awkward8/10 Very good

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Short Version:---------------------+ Nice visuals+ Nice music+ Unique game mechanics+ Interresting puzzles+ good story (not great, but ok)- Short playtime- Can get a bit frustrating if you have to try some things over and over again[ Hint for german people: ~ Voice acting is english, subs are german ] Recommended? Yes, but only if you can get it in a deal Long Version: ------------------- This games is something different... It's some kind of a puzzle game with a good story, nice visuals and great music. Didi wants to get her father back to her family and you have to help her. To do so, you have to fix some things and open the way where didi is not able to get through. The interresting thing here are the game mechanics. You have to move objects in front of lights sources to change the shadows on the walls. Then you can step into the walls so that you can move along these shadows. You have to take objects with you when you are a shadow on the wall, to bring them to the place where you need them. And so on. Thats quite unique and a pretty nice idea. It is really fun, to figure out which step you need to do next, to solve all these puzzles. BUT: I finished this game in about 3 hours with almost all the collectable items (I missed 2 Items somewhere) This is a bit short in my opinion and this is the reason why I would recommend, to buy this game if you can get it in a deal and not for the full price. So if you can get it for cheap and you wanna try something different and you like to solve puzzles then buy this game ;)

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												For the video review, check it out here:  


YouTube™ Video: Round Egg Review: Contrast 

			Views: 133		

			Today we take a look at Contrast, a game focused on solving puzzles as you meld between the 2d and 3d worlds at the press of a button. How does it stand up? Stay tuned.		

"From the get-go, the life of young Didi will ensnare you, as her busy, workaholic mother and get rich quick scheme loving father will constantly be at ends.  In a seemingly never-ending struggle to bring her parents together again and keep them that way, Didi and Dawn will be placed in positions in which they can come to the rescue, fixing familial situations which would otherwise end their tumultuous little grouping in a heartbeat.  Contrast’s plotline can be both depressing and heartwarmingly joyful at the same time, and it WILL be the reason why you keep playing the game from start to finish.""To tie it all together, Contrast comes equipped with some soothing, noir-themed visuals, and a beautiful setting that stands as an amalgamation of the shadow world, as well as the real world.  Over the course of the game you’ll venture through places such as cabaret theaters, seedy taverns, decrepit carnivals, observatories, and shadowy alleyways, all of which invoke a feeling of wonder.  By throwing in some really top notch musical talent, Contrast’s atmospheric merits are almost as good as it’s impeccable storyline."

content:
Posted: February 18
CAUTION - Biased Reviewtldr;If you appreciate detail and aren't in a hurry to find some kind of FPS game, slow down and give CONTRAST a try - it is art-music-fun all-in-one.10/10Why Biased? Because I didn't like it...I loved it! I go into a lot of games like a misanthropic, glass half-empty, cutscene skipping sort of Gamer xD. "Let's hurry up and get this finished," y'know?!From the opening scenes in CONTRAST, I was mouth-agape WOWED by the unbelievably high quality artwork and smooth jazz music in this game.Pros:- artwork - blown away by the use of loud colors one moment and stark monotone the next, with incredible contrast and shading. This was too beautiful to be just a game. BTW IMO - captured the golden age of Art Deco perfectly.- music - set the mood throughout and was also impressive enough that I will be looking to pick up the OST at some point in the future. (And I Never do that <grin>)- gameplay - fairly challenging use of combos for me that usually required multiple attempts to 'get it right', like when using jump / dash / shift all together. Admittedly I'm a spaz with a controller, tho.- Flawless Controller Support I used Xbox360 PC controller- Stable Graphics- 100% Achievements nothing here to slow you down if you are Achievement Hunting. I got all but 2 on the 1st run-through, and they were easy to pickup using chapter select after I completed the game. FINCons:- Game Length it was probably about right length for this story, but I just hated to see it end & wanted more, moar, more xD.- Niche Game understandably, this game will not appeal to everyone, but it should LOLHope you found this helpful - Cheers

												First I want to comment on the main story being nothing more than a family struggling with love from time from time. I get that the game is supposed to be "art-like" with the dark noir atmosphere and lurking shadows but I really want to learn more about what's going on in those two worlds! I feel as a player I want to know a bit of backstory when going on the big quest but I guess I can't ask that when the game is supposed to be a big odd puzzle with shadows jumping around on buildings in love. Besides the story the gameplay is really original like no other game with the unique mechanic and odd puzzles that are very hard to solve from time to time, though I really wish the story would carry the game as much as the atmosphere does. With that said, if you want to have a hard time solving puzzles (atleast I think it's a challenge), and be in the spotlight from time to time as a lurking shadow in Paris among other awesome places jumping on everything you can jump on as well as shadows, then this game is for you! I would give it a 6/10 because of the game not being fitted for my need of a solid story, but if you don't care about the story balancing the gameplay that much then this game is a good choice! /Sow

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Contrast is a puzzle platformer that will tug on your heartstrings. It's stylized (in a very Parisian way), has some great voice work, and will leave you thinking about it long after the credits have rolled. The gameplay is experimental, yet simple. The use of light and shadow to shift from 3D to 2D and back works wonderfully, and forcing your brain to think in multiple dimensions leads to the best kinds of puzzles. There are just enough secrets and collectibles to keep things interesting and promote exploration without being annoying in this small but well-realized world. You'll notice jokes and easter eggs in the background while progressing, and it's rare that you'll ever feel lost.My biggest gripe is that the controls are just clunky enough that a few spots requiring precision movement can be very, very frustrating. I rage quit twice as a result.The short and sweet story is totally worth the time, invisible walls and all. All the collectibles and optional dialogue only serve to enrich the experience. You'll think you know where things are going and then a big reveal will twist everything around. Luckily, every new story point makes sense, and they don't come out of nowhere - it's simply the process of learning more about the characters. And the ending is just complex enough to be satisfying while opening your mind to multiple possibilities.Contrast takes high-concept ideas for both gameplay and story and manages to fit them all into a neat little package. It makes for a cohesive, fun, and memorable game.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Contrast is a strange beast. It's a platform-based puzzle game set in a surrealist, steampunk, early 20th century paris-like city. The player controls Dawn, the imaginary friend of the main character Didi, who has the titular power of being able to switch back and forth from the physical world to the shadow world. The player uses this ability to solve the many puzzles that are conviently wrapped around the story line. I don't want to delve too deep into the lore of this story, since most of its value comes from its twists (which is bad enough that I'm addressing), but it is something to witness. I wish that the game explored certain aspects that I felt needed developing, and the ending was a bit lackluster.I have two main quips about this game. The first is its glitches. Sometimes when doing certain puzzles in the shadow world, the game will inexplicably pop you back into the physical world. Puzzles like these just require trial and error, but in a game where the main goal is to challenge the player's smarts and not their patience, it has no place. The second quip I have is the length of the game. It only took me three and a half hours to finish this game, and I usually consider myself as someone who plays through games very slowly. Since I actually got this game as a gift from a very generous friend (thanks BOT Mathew :3), I'm not that mad about it. However, if you plan on buying this game, ONLY GET IT ON SALE. It is definetely not worth a full $15. Other than that, I love this game. The controls are great, the visuals are engaging, and the collectibles give an excuse to marvel at such a beautifull world. TL; DR: A very pretty game with an interesting story and even more interesting puzzles, yet can get a little buggy at times and is too much for its price considering its length. A must get game while its on sale. Can be considered one of those "art" games.Overall Score: 6.5-7

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Contrast is a game that seems like it should be amazing, based purely on the premise, mechanics, and art direction alone. And while I do still recommend it (to a point), the final package ended up being a tad underwhelming. But let's start at he beginning. There is a lot of good to the game, specifically the elements I just mentioned. The setting (early 20th century Paris) and art direction are very interesting, and there are lots of cool things to see throughout the journey. You play as Dawn, the acrobat "imaginary friend" of a young girl named Didi. The game revolves around Dawn's ability to transform from a 3D person into a 2D shadow. As a shadow, you can maneuver along any other shadow, as if it were a normal platform. Puzzles generally involve manipulating light sources to create navigable shadows, and then platforming your way through those shadows to reach new areas. The story, without revealing much, is just OK. It involves Didi's lounge-singer mother, her loser father, and a mysterious magician named Vincenzo. There's nothing wrong with the story, but it's also nothing mind-blowing, for the most part. And that sort of sums up the game as a whole - merely adequate. The main gameplay hook of transforming into a shadow, while cool, just isn't enough to sustain a whole game in its own. Don't get me wrong, there are plenty of neat segments and cool applications of the idea. But after a while, you'll start to get the feeling of "been there done that", only in a new location. Not to mention, most of the puzzles (such as they are) are very simple anyways, there's not all that much meat on the bone in terms of challenge or completely fresh ideas. I am not sure they even could have added anything more to improve the game. As I said, it's perfectly adequate as-is, and definitely doesn't overstay its welcome. I just have this nagging feeling that there were missed opportunities for additional puzzles or ways the shadow mechanic could have been used. Maybe that's unfair, but so be it. Despite all this, I actually did enjoy and have fun with the game overall. I just feel that maybe with a bit more development time, it could have been better. But what's here is definitely an interesting experience, and worth checking out if the atmosphere or shadow mechanic intrigues you, as it did for me. The entire experience lasts around 5 hours or so, so also keep that in mind when considering your purchase. I would say hold off for a sale, unless you really feel the need to check it out right away.My only real complaints would be for technical issues. Specifically, the game lacks many of the customization settings one would expect in PC games, such as video options and the like. Personally, I had an issue with the lack of an option for x-axis inversion for the camera controls. And while there is still no solution patched directly in game (at least as of the time of this review), for the record, I wanted to note that the developers actually responded to my request within minutes and provided a configuration file fix that could be changed manually to implement that feature. While it wasn't the ideal solution, I really appreciated their responsiveness, as it allowed me to play the game the way I wanted. So kudos to the developers for that. Which reminds me - I definitely recommend a gamepad for this one.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												For the full price - forget about it. When there is a  big sale   on, something around 75% off - still think twice. The The whole game is a series of disappointinng shortfalls. Here's my story explaning why:I noticed Contrast over a year ago and the concept of the game, coupled with what I saw on the trailers and in the screenshots, had me really wanting this game. The price though was a bit steep, so I only got it on sale recently. And I'm mighty glad I waited. Without further ado, here's what's wrong with the game.First of all, the story feels like scribbled down on a knee five minutes before the writers had a deadline to submit it. Nothing to keep the player interested, just a generic tale of a child and her parents don't quite form a perfect family. The characters, save the protagonist, are shallow, one-dimensional and there's little reason for anyone to form any sort of emotional bond with them. The only chance of livening up the plot  when the player discovers collectibles pertaining to Dawn and Vincenzo in the last act  is merely reduced to finding some collectibles and one scene just before the credits.Secondly, the gameplay is, to put it bluntly, rubbish. Platformers in the 90's offered better game mechanics. The fantasticly promising concept of manipulating lights and shifting between shadows and the 'real' world is there just so you can jump on some platforms and move one or two boxes around. Nothing else. And one more thing here: the player character gains some skills for no apparent reason and then hardly ever uses them.The controls are simple but even there you can find an issue, as the shifting mechanism often has a mind of its own and Dawn gets thrown off the platforms without the fault on the side of the player.Graphics. To be fair, the game looks alright. Nothing remarkable though. The models are edgy, locations deserted for the most part (I'm talking here about items, not characters - the lack of the latter is just part of the game) but the overall feeling is positive. The atmosphere in the locations is nice, kind of gloomy and decadent at the same time. On the other hand, the animations is where the game should deliver and fails completely. The protagonist is said to be an acrobat. Therefore, her moves should be fluent, graceful and light, which they only are when the character is walking slowly or standing still and I'm not convinced that this should be the case in an action game. The animations of Dawn interacting with objects or moving stuff, as well as thhe animations of all other characters feel terribly outdated.Finally, the music, where the game promises much but delivers little. Despite what you might think having seen the trailers, there is in fact very litle music in the game. Soundtrack activates only when the player apporaches a certain location. Truth be told, the best piece of music was the one in the main menu. Character voicing is just wrong, its highlight being Dawn, who simply says nothing throughout the entire game.Fortunately, Contrast is a very short game, in jusr 4 hours I manged to obtain a 100% playthrough. I say fortunately because I could not bear any more of the feeling that there's a game that could have been brilliant and turned out mediocre. Pros: Great noir setting Fairly good graphics Some nice music Great protagonistCons: Light/shadow manipulation reduced to one power Uninteresting, unoriginal storyline All other characters except the protagonist Very short Animations from 15 years ago Gameplay from 20 years ago Imprecise controls Wasted potential everywhereA final note: the ending hints, rather obviously, at a sequel. Unless the developers do some serious work to deliver a more complete experience with a story and gameplay to match its lovely graphics style its going to be, at least for me, a flop. So a word to the producers: Please, please do it right, because I so want the concept to be given the game it deserves.

The graphics are amazingly beautiful, the colors work really well with the concept and I was, as a noir fan, intrigued from the start,2. SO OVERALL:-If you are looking for a groundbreaking story, this is not the game for you. -f you want to enjoy a totally unique noir universe with really good puzzles (and you don't care much about the gameplay), try it out.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Nicely styled art direction, a solid core mechanic, and a well paced and well told narrative are what make video games unique and interesting and Contrast has these in spades. Beautifully designed, this is an excellent showcase of developer talent and I hope to see more from Compulsion Games.Contrast follows Dawn, a mysterious woman with the ability to meld into shadows, as she accompanies Didi, a bright young girl who won't give up, on an adventure through the abstract and shadowy reflection of the 1920s. The game itself is short, I completed it in 5 hours but many of you might take less time. As with any game with a similar length, one can't talk about the plot without giving anything away and playing the game for any amount of time will plunge you straight in.The main mechanic of this puzzle platformer is the ability to shift into two dimensions and move along the shadows as though they are solid objects. Perspective puzzles are a favorite of this game, as are weighing down switches with boxes. Admittedly the controls, while mostly solid, are sometimes fickle. One puzzle towards the end took me much longer than the others; not because it was hard to figure out but because it was difficult to wrestle the object into place. one aspect of the game I felt could be done better is the collection of Iluminaries, objects used to power the machines in the game. while there are a surplus of them in each level, the game has a nasty habit of locking doors behind you. So in theory, if you failed to collect enough of these things when you had the chance then progression becomes impossible; though this was not the case for me, be sure to follow your instincts and deal with the main objective last.At the end of the day I think this game has a lot of ambition behind it and, despite a few hiccups here and there, was very tight and well designed. The game does feel a little bare bones but as with the hiccups I'm expecting that the next game by the Compulsion will solve these issues. I can definitely recommend this game and others from this up and coming developer.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												I can never tell when a game will click with me. Contrast is one of those that I didn't think I'd like, but I did.The setting of the game is well-realized: art nouveau/art deco with a jazzy early 20th century theme. It was a fantastic change of pace from the usual common game themes, and it was well done here.As well, the mechanic of shifting into and out of shadow to complete platforming tasks was a neat twist on the usual platforming mechanics. I'm not a big fan of platformers (and this game didn't change my mind) but the novelty of this at least made it feel unique and somewhat fresh.The story was a nice noir concept, and it doesn't get in its own way with crazy twists - it exists and is fairly comprehensible, while suiting the game and its mechanics.As for downsides, I found the gamepad controls to be a little "loose" and slippery - movement felt overly-sensistive to me, and I sometimes had trouble controlling my jumps. There were a few puzzles that are not intuitive, but that's OK I suppose - the game isn't meant to be a complete cakewalk.I'd definitely recommend this if you're in the mood for something unique and noir and platform-y: 4 out of 5.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
Puzzle-Platforming, Film Noir Style.Contrast is certainly not for action junkies, nor for gamers who aren't all that interested in storytelling, but for me this little gem from Compulsive Games makes for an excellent puzzle-platformer.The big mechanic here is the ability to shift into silhouette form and solve problems with shadows.  It's remarkably adept at holding player interest because Contrast gives us so much to do, from simple platforming to complex object manipulation.  The 3D platforming elements are minimal, though there is a fair bit of 2D-3D shifting in certain sections to keep players on their toes.Our intrepid developers have done very well with the Unreal Engine, bringing a dreamscape 1920s world to life with a unique art style that makes full use of a specially commissioned Jazz n' Blues soundtrack.  This game treats us the way a lot of independent titles should: like intelligent people who don't need a compass pointing towards every objective, or a full explanation for every plot point.It isn't Braid or Portal by any stretch of the imagination, but it is an indie game that has been built with careful attention to detail and a clear love for simple ideas that lead into complexity.  A potential downside is that it's too short.  That said, I paid full price for the Special Edition and I'm not regretting it.  So, action-seekers stay away.  Thoughtful types who enjoy their puzzles with a twist of atmosphere - welcome!Still not sure which way you're swinging?  Watch my full video review here: http://store.steampowered.com

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I was intrigued by trailers and description of this game, but I'm pretty sure I fell in love with "Contrast" at the moment when I heard main menu music. Charming, velvet woman voice sounded like a promice of something sweet, precious and slightly dangerous... And all of those things create the world of contrasts, in which our heroine, Dawn, helps her friend Didi to find out her family's mysteries. I really love atmoshpere of "Contrast", dark streets with neon signs, unseen colors which blossoms in the streetlights (when graphics set on "low" worls appears much more colorful; I like darker city better, but I think it's interesting to play with both settings - just to see differences and to decide which world you find suitable for this story). Little things you will find - photos, newspapers, letters, etc. will make you better understand Didi's parents and the whole concept of traveling between 2D and 3D realms.Puzzles are not very hard, but quite nice and sometimes rather challenging.  I love almost all of them (except some parts of shadow theater).I like that the game has quite opened ending, and I like that there still are some questions left to be aswered by the player themself.Only one thing I didn't like in this game - I had leave game too soon to my taste. I'd love to spend a few more hours with Dawn and Didi. And I think so will you after playing this great game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Intro:Well I first noticed this game shortly after I started playing Bioshock Infinite. It cought my eye because of it's art style. After watching the trailers, I added this to my wishlist and purchased it during Winter Sale.Well I'm not sure how to rate this game. It's really well done in the visual and aural departments. The atmosphere really transports that 20s France feeling. But there are some things to be improved.Graphics:Not much to rant about. Maybe that's because im easy to plese with graphics, as long as they just fit together. But there are some glitches, especially on movable objects (crates and balls). The puddles on the streets look more like ice than water. That's because there is no added effect if you walk through them.Audio:Also nothing to really complain. The music is well done and fits the scenery. I really like the track that runs during the menu screen. The voice acting is okay except for Didi. Her lines just sound "strange" every now and then.Controls:My main complaint. It just feels like one of those early cheap 3D games. I often had problems judging how far I could jump. It just doesn't feel right. But I got used to it after a while.Gameplay:You spend a lot of time shifting into the shadows to acomplish your tasks. Sometimes the engine seems to have problems if the surface you are moving on is not even. If there is a corner, that's also a problem sometimes. But at least once the game forces you to go around a corner (which is evenly lit), so it cannot be intentional that the game throws you out of the shadow realm. Sometimes there are new things to consider when solving puzzles. Unlike in many other games you are not shown that those concepts are there. Like shifting certain objects with you or moving objects using spotlights. I'm not really sure if this is a good thing or not. But I really liked finding those things out by myself. Maybe some optional hints would solve this "problem" for both sides.Story:To make it short: No epicness, no world rescue, no over the top characters, no "only he/she can do it". But nothing that special either... but as there hasn't been a story one could call "groundbreaking" or "has never been done before" in the recent past, I really like that simplicity.Conclusion:An artistically nice game with a few control hiccups that doesn't do handholding and is solvable without the use of walkthroughs or FAQs. Tells a down to earth fantasy story without uneccesary epicness. Buy it if you like artistically interesting games that don't neccessarily appeal to the masses.EDIT:What I really forgot:It would've been nice if there was some more interaction with Didi. She often just stands there and does nothing. It only was about two times that she assisted you in one way or the other. For example: the screenshot where she lights the way with a lamp? Never happened.

												As someone who mainly plays games such as League of Legends, Heroes of the Storm, Overwatch or Terraria - all in all Multiplayer oriented games - it is rather rare for em to0 just be amazed by a game solely for soloplayer experience. Contrast was one of these games.The game is mostly focussing on the narrative, making you uncertain of how the story falls in place and even questioning your own existence as a whole until slowly it starts to fall in place like pieces of a puzzle. The atmosphere of the scenery surrounding you while playing gives you the feeling to run around in france during the 20th century mixed with Steampunky assets and apperatures.The gameplay itself is pretty self explainatory and straight forward. Blend into a wall as shadow. Move around. parkour. Solve riddles due to that. Sadly, the shadow mechanic is not that consistent throughout the game, screwing you over from time to time, pushing you out of walls for basically no reason before the next time you try letting you through instantly.If you like lighthearted riddles and parkouring as well as a nice narrative and aesteticly pleasing Steampunky landscape, I can only recommend trying this game out as quick as you can.10 outta 10. Will play again. (Sorry, I had to)

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
'Contrast' is a fantastic 'adventure'/'puzzle'/'platformer' which tells an interesting story and has great potential to a sequel.Desc:You are the 'imaginary' friend of Didi named Dawn. As Dawn you will help Didi by solving her family problems. Her mother Kat is a hard working singer who tries to help their families survive. Didis father Johnny Fenris gets himself always into trouble and left therefore his family, but he want his family  back. At the end you will help Johnny to get his lovely family back.Pros:+ very nice concept+ great story telling+ awesome scoring+ unique and vivid characters (especially Didi, where you get the feeling she is real)+ good soundtrack+ amazing realization of the concept (smooth switches between 2D and 3D)+ interesting feeling during gameplayexample: you are asking often yourself who is really in the shadows you or them and are the shadow the death or the life?(+ steam achievements)Cons:- controls (at default) are too sensitive (acting like a bunny on the run)- collision detection is sometimes annoying (2d)example: you are in the shadows, but you will be blocked by 3d objects (out of the shadow) that are above you, whereat you should only get blocked by shadow objects- collision detection is sometimes annoying (3d)example: you are standing in front of a chest and you can't jump on it, but you are able if you run towards it -.-(- with 5h a short play time)(- no demo )Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because this game will present you a great story embedded in a very cool concept, which works very well.9/10

I know that is a little unfair to punish a game for what it could have been an it isn´t, but some games show hints of what could have been an amazing experience and you can avoid that kind of sourness in your mouth,  but, like i said, if you like this kind of games and have little time in your hands to play or you want some palate cleanser between more intense experiences this is a game you should enjoy, i certainly did it, but damn, it could have been really good

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
My Impression:I heard about this game from watching the trailer of another game from the creators of this (We Happy Few). The artwork of Contrast depicts a Tim Burton movie with sex appeal; a seductive world of light and darkness. Contrast adds a unique feature that allows one to shift between the striking 3D fantasy world and the mysterious 2D shadowscape. I was intrigued...Positive:+ Amazing artwork accompanied with amazing voice acting+ The story compliments the artwork with a jazzy soundtrack that is a pleasure to experience+ Fun puzzles that are challenging but not impossible, fun for everyone+ Shifting between 2D and 3D is a fun new feature introduced to platformersCons:- Too Short- Story seems rushed- Awkward save features- A little too linear(a lot of the negative reviews are from 2013-2014 and complain about bugs, most if not all seem to be fixed)I purchased this game in a bundle and really enjoy it. I don't think I would pay $14.99 for it because of the length of the game, but if you can get it in a sale or bundle, it's a must try. Simply put, Contrast is a simple, yet poetic game of shadows and light.8/10

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												The idea of using shadows as platforms is an interesting one; shifting your character back and forth between shadow and light adds new variety. The 3 hours of gameplay doesn't allow enough time for this idea to evolve. Most "puzzles" end up being nothing more than jump - shift - jump - shift. To make matters worse, platforming is a bit clunky. I felt like my character was alittle too big for the world. Missing an easy jump and falling to your death is infuriating, but the game is really forgiving, almost always reloading near the last jump. The main plot, although nothing more than a mellowdrama, hid behind it the more interesting subplot of the player's identity. This, sadly, is only hinted at in clues in the environment and pointless 'collectables'. Then the game ends, not really concluding anything, even the main plot.  I really wanted to like Contrast, but there isn't enough of a game here to recommend to anyone.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Contrast is a 3D puzzle\platformer that takes place in a world full of magic, cabaret singers, and burlesque shows. It utilizes a 1920's 'French Noir Film' art style that is unlike any other game I've played. The character design is beautiful, the voice acting is amazing, and the jazzy soundtrack fits the world perfectly. I can't stress enough how much I love the look and feel of this game. Yet, I can't recommend it, which is particularly disappointing considering how much there is to like here.You play as Dawn, a woman trapped between the worlds of light and darkness, and who cannot be seen by anyone except for a little girl named Didi. Didi's parents have broken up, and with the father out of the picture, her mother works at a nightclub to pay the bills. This, of course, means nobody is watching the little demon-spawn and it's up to Dawn to keep her out of trouble. Easier said than done, since she insists on roaming around the city at all hours of the night, refusing to listen to reason, and all you can do is enable her.The entire game revolves around a shift mechanic that allows you to become a shadow, an ability you will need to solve puzzles and progress through the game. Adjusting light sources to cast shadows to interact with is this game's bread and butter, and you'll be doing a lot of it.The problems with Contrast start almost immediately. While the puzzle mechanics are unique and interesting, they are a bit buggy, and simple platforming can be difficult with controls that don't feel tight or responsive. Dawn has a tendency to get stuck in the environment and other shadows as well. There are even a couple of places where dropping an object in the wrong spot could result in the player not being able to progress further, forcing them to load the last checkpoint. Once the game defines the parameters on the first couple of puzzles, it doesn't change them up much and they can become repetitive fast, which really shouldn't happen in a game this short. Which brings me to the biggest issue Contrast faces. The entire game can be completed in under 3 hours, and the ending is exceedingly abrupt. All of these issues combined leaves me with a feeling that the game is unfinished. Almost as if Compulsion Games ran out of money for the title half-way through development. Obviously, I do not have firsthand knowledge that this is the case, but I can't shake the feeling that I'm playing an Early Access game, and not a full release.Altogether, Contrast is a game that should have been a one-of-a-kind, beautiful experience. When a bad idea becomes a bad game, it's expected, but when something that starts off this amazing falls flat, it's all the more frustrating. I expected better, as did most gamers, and in the future I hope Compulsion learns from their mistakes, and releases games that shows us all what they're really capable of.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												My suggestion: wait for a sale.I feel so saddened that a game I have been tracking since initial release wasn't what I expected, at all. The concept of the overall storyline is interesting with the main character, Dawn, jumping between a shadow world and a 3D world. However, the game mechanics are sloppy and sometimes so bugged that it can ruin the game. At one point, the little girl, was a static figure and simply slid across the screen for an entire Chapter. Other times, Dawn seemed to hit this invisible wall when doing different jumping puzzles, making some jumps almost impossible to do smoothly on a first run.The puzzles themselves were interesting and sometimes frustrating - which is always good. However, they sometimes would get so buggy...My other main issue with the game was the general graphics of the shadow people. They were exceptionally blocky and I felt that the developers had gotten really lazy. I could see seams on forearms and their mouths never moved even if they were deep in conversation. I felt like they were more like puppets than people.I also realized, after game completion, that there were significant plot holes surrounding some characters. I have no intention of spoilers, but it is really frustrating when a game feels incomplete in their storyline. For the full price, it is not worth the four hours of gameplay. I highly recommend that you wait for a sale and buy it on a whim. I loved the concept, the voice acting (Jensen from Deus Ex anyone?), and the film noir style of both music and setting. However, between the bugs, the blocky animation, and the weak ending, I really felt cheated.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												We should adress the good first, because what's good about this game is really good. The setting and tone of 1920's noir is brilliant and it shines through in every area; it feels like a mixture between the Sierra Madre and Bioshock's Rapture with the unique lighting, it is one of the best looking worlds ever seen in a game. Additionally, the voice acting is pretty solid and its interesting how you never see the side character, but you see their over the top body language in their shadows, which is quite entertaining in a Vaudville/Groucho Marx way. On top of all of this, the story is pretty good and surprisingly charming. However, that's really the end of the good stuff. Like Limbo, contrast has a really good idea, but fails to do anything interesting with it past the very first puzzle. Almost every puzzle is a varitaion of pressing a button to make something in the room move, which creates a shadow ramp. Unfortunatley, there are two big problems with the shadow platforming, which is supposed to be the star of the show. The first problem is that you will periodically stop being a shadow. You'll be standing somewhere and if you hit something (because shadows act like solid objects) you might instantly get out of shadow mode. The second problem is that the platforming is pretty shotty with landing detection and there are times where it looks like you should be able to make it, only to clip through the shadow, meaning you have to start all over. This is especially problematic during the second act, where you have to climb a massive building using the shadows of a carrosel to climb a large rotunda. If the platform detection messes up at all, you have to start all over. Additionally, there's an entire section of this game that is a direct "homage" to Limbo. A section in which you run away in a dark shadowy world from a giant spider. This amounts to about 1/10 of the whole experience, which really shows that the developers were running out of ideas at this time.Because of its incredible short length of about 3-4 hours, its boring and repetative puzzles, and its buggy gameplay I can't reccomend this as a game, but I can recommend it for its story and style
