content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												Disappointing for such a game that really could have been amazing. The general premise of the game, both story-wise (Didi and parents) and gimmick/mechanics-wise (using shadows to navigate and solve puzzles), was interesting enough for me to give the game a shot in the first place. I also enjoy the noir style and going back almost a century ago to a different type of world.However, the game really let me down. There's just too many issues that all stack up against it, and the quality of the game seems to bounce back and forth as you play. The story starts off without much information, though I did get into it once I started picking up what was happening. But there are a lot of weird background details that are never explained at all, and nothing much seems to fit together. I also did not think there was much of a climax, and the ending of the game felt very cheap.There is no real environment to the game, as the world is weirdly disconnected and with missing areas and emptiness. Basically, there is no "life" to it, is a better phrasing. You just go through hollow areas to get to the next mini-cutscene, and then solve a puzzle. While the visual art style of the game great, and some places look very beautiful, the lack of anything actually inhabiting the areas ruins it. And though the game's gimmick, as I mentioned before, is dealing with shadows, I didn't enjoy every character except you and Didi being shown as shadows. It just felt cheap and as if the developers didn't want to do that design. It only furthers the lack of "life" in the game. And the dialog and sound of the game also was nothing special. Nobody gave any performance that was great, and I think a good few scenes actually lacked any good emotion.Then you have the mechanical problems, showing that the game wasn't fine-tuned or even tested that well. Your character's movement is pretty far from good, and I often found myself glitching around, especially when you are in the shadows. One of the things about the shadows is that if certain moving shadows are about to crush you, then the game pops you out of the shadows, which is understandable; however, I found myself popping out of the shadows at random points without anything touching me, causing me to fall down and making me start parts of puzzles over and over again.When it comes to Didi, who you are following around, they were very lazy in her movement as well. I would often see her animations entirely stop, so she would "walk" without any motion. She doesn't move her mouth when talking, at least as far as I saw. And half the time you were supposed to find her somewhere, I would walk into the room or area and see her in "generic 3D model" form, standing in place with arms and legs rigidly stretched out as if someone is in the middle of editing her design.And in terms of actually playing, it seemed like "Saving" didn't actually mean the game was saving, whenever it popped up. At least twice, I exited the game to stop playing after it had finished saving, and I came back each time to find that the game jumped back at least 10-15 minutes, so I would have to redo some section. For instance, it did this in one of the carnival areas after I completed it and then quit the game.Finally, the length of the game - it is way too short, and with all of the issues, it all made it even worse. I don't know if the developer just didn't have enough money at the time, or they just chose not to clean things up or test enough, but the game is very lacking in pretty much every area. It could have been a really great game if they had put in more work.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Contrast is a sometimes...frustrating game.  But ultimately rewarding.   The pros?  Where to begin!  Absolutely top-rate storytelling (this could almost be a film), sometimes ingeniously clever puzzles (though none so hard that one just throws in the towel), gorgeous graphics, wonderful sound, and a genuine sense of child-like wonder which seamlessly blends with the harsher realities of the adult world.  Think Tomb Raider meets Limbo (that is to say, both 3D and 2D platforming elements, effortlessly combined), with a story and direction worthy of Tim Burton (the earlier one, that one that made the good films before he became such a predictable hack).  Oh, and it's nowhere near as painfully LLLOOOOONNNGG as all games seem to feel the obligation to be these days (or in other words, it doesn't "overstay its welcome").   Now the cons.  Some of the platforming elements are PAINFULLY pedantic...one teeny, tiny miscalculation in where you place a lighting rig (this game is all about shadows), and you could very well waste the next forty seconds running and jumping to a point just to realise you ain't gonna make that final jump.  And then it's ALL the way back to the start of the puzzle again.  And there's some reflex-based moments of timing which become frustrating thanks to the sometimes ill-responsive controls, though fortunately, these bits of the game are at least few and far between.    Honestly, though, none of what I've just said would be all THAT much to grumble about, if it weren't for the POSITIVELY DIABOLICAL SAVE SYSTEM.  Why does nearly every modern game have to insist that if someone switches it on, they'd better be ready to sit there non-stop for HOURS?  Do they not know that some of us have JOBS?  LIVES?!  That we CAN'T necessarily invest two hours at a time into conquering A WHOLE FREAKING CHAPTER before switching off and going to bloody BED???     But as I said earlier...sigh...at least this is one recent game which doesn't feel the need to give us a non-linear plot full of extreme repetition, constant backtracking, and an "open world" which takes 180+ hours to explore.  Short, and on the whole, very sweet.  But man oh man, do these game designers EVER test their own games, or better yet...give them to NORMAL people to try out before commercial release?  It's a good thing I don't have a "life" to spend precious time on, or I'd just about give away this whole "gaming" lark altogether!Verdict: 9/10.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I bought this game a long time ago, but I haven't played it then. Few days ago I finally decided to check it out and the game charmed me. It has really amazing cabaret/noir style atmoshpere and awesome matching music. Gameplay itself is pretty innovative too. You need to switch between 3D and 2D mode platformer. It is very interesting that in the 2D mode, you can move only on the "shadows" on the walls and flat objects. Shadows can be created by yourself through interaction with various objects in 3D mode. You need to use appropriate arrangement of their relation to one another and to light sources, so in the result you can move on them in the 2D mode. The biggest downside is the length of the game - finishing it in almost 100% takes only 3-4h. Also, the "puzzles" are fairly simple. It's a pity that the authors failed to further develop the aforementioned theme, because the game had great potential. Nevertheless, I sincerely recommend Contrast, especially in some more accessible price.8+/10

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												On paper Contrast seems like a really cool game: a puzzle platformer where you can switch between being a physical person and being a shadow on the wall, using the shadows of other objects to get where you need to go. Couple that with a jazzy nightlife setting, and you can't go wrong, right?Unfortunately that is not the case. The platforming was often really frustrating and the game was fairly buggy. I found a few places where I could melt with a wall or I would have to jump three or four times to make it onto a ledge that was well within reach.The story was alright. You play as Dawn, the imaginary friend of a little girl named Didi. Didi's parents are separated and she sneaks out in the night on a regular basis to watch her mother sing at a club. Dawn helps Didi to progress past obstacles and fix things, and hopefully eventually to reunite her family. Dawn and Didi are the only ones who appear as three dimensional people in the world; everyone else appear as shadows on the walls, and are often parts of the platforming that the player has to perform.In a lot of ways I am glad that the game only took three hours. I wish I could recommend Contrast because it has the makings of a cool, unique indie game. But it just wasn't made well at all. Don't buy it.

Posted: March 11, 2014
												I can recommend this game - with reservations. It's way more of an audio/visual experience than a "good game". The puzzles are fairly basic and the jumping feels floaty and imprecise at times. Having said that - it's something of a masterclass in world building. It's a game world I wanted to explore and know more about. The voice acting is all terrific (though having the voice of Adam Jensen as the doting father unnerved me - I was waiting for him to start snapping necks any second), and the game looks sharp despite a complete and noticeable lack of anti-aliasing. Worth it for a sale price. You can power through it in about three hours and I think it's worth it to see the intoxicating world this small 7-person team has built.

Posted: March 10, 2014
												This game will be exceptionally fun for fans of casual platformers and story driven games. Fans of the Portal series and Bioshock Infinite will enjoy the puzzle/story combination.The visual style is gorgeous, a 1920s world that feels both occupied and isolated provides a haunting yet compelling atmosphere.The gameplay dynamics are unique and enjoyable. Solving puzzles by entering, manipulating, and interacting with shadows (moving from a 3D to a 2D plane) provides a sometimes challenging, but always entertaining gameplay element.The only minor complaint is that it feels a little short with a completion time of 4 to 5 hours (even after finding all the collectables).

												I really wanted to like this game, had it on my Wishlist for several weeks before release, was so happy when I finally installed it, and have attempted two separate playthroughs of it. Posted: February 16, 2014
												Contrast's charm is evident from the moment you start the game. As soon as the first title screen comes up and you hear the stylings of 1920's blues, you know you're in for something different. Contrast takes place in an atmospheric France, 1923. You're a mute acrobat that can merge with shadows and you're followed by a little girl named Didi. Didi is the star of the game, her perfectly casted voice actor and her adorable lines will have you thinking "Who the hell is Ellie?". The noir aesthetic is reminiscent of Dishonored meets Bioshock meets Boardwalk Empire. The acting, story and scenery feel authentic to the era. The gameplay is perfectly simple, though the puzzle aren't much of a challenge. The past three years have been landmark years for the downloadble/indie game scene. The quality of absolutely great and relatively cheap titles rivals that of their AAA counterparts. Contrast is, without a doubt, a legend among it's peers; Bastion, Braid, Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons, Castle Crashers, Guacamelee, Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet, Journey, Magicka, Mega Man 9, rain, Shadow Complex, Skullgirls, Stacking, Super Meat Boy, Terraria, Torchlight II, Trine and more. In my opinion, the game tops most of those. There isn't much to say about the game's flaws. It's unfairly short; I collected every collectible, completed all of the achievements and still clocked in at 4 hours. A gem like this deserves to be a lengthened experience. Aside from the game's length, there is a clear lack of polish. Had Compulsion Games taking more time to test the game, we wouldn't have to be putting up with invisible walls or floors. While they weren't too frequent, they were uncomfortably noticable. At one point I left a building, turned around to go back into the open door and couldn't because of an invisible wall. I walked forward a bit and came back and was able to go back into the building. Though I am convinced these blemishes are related to an overbearing publisher wanting to rush their investment out,  small details like these and the game's length are the only thing that keep it from being a perfect game in my book. Anyone looking for a unique experience, pick Contrast up. It will definitely continue to go on sale, so do yourself a favor when you see it marked below it's normal price of $15.99. Games like this, from independent developers are on the rise, and as gamers it's up to us to support their new ideas in an effort to show the multi-million dollar publishers/developers that bigger isn't always better. [9/10]

Posted: June 8, 2015
												A short game with an interesting concept, contrast is a puzzle platform game based around lighting effects.The story revolves around a child Didi and her silent shadow jumping imaginary friend Dawn, to whom you control. This game is rather mature and deals with many adult situations from day to day life. Set in a noir mid 1900's city, the ambient is that of night clubs, bars and cabarets. Most of the story events are told through the silhouettes of the secondary characters sometimes having the player be prompted to intervene.All gameplay revolves around Dawns abilities. In shadow form she moves on a 2D plane where she can reach difficult locations and resolve puzzles, like taking a heavy object from the ground to a higher location made possible via the 2D shadows. Very rarely is the objective or next point of interest not made clear, but deviating from the path has it's own reward on finding more story elements, like memories of past events and collectables.Sound is a positive, each location has its own themes and sound effects that plays really well with the way the narrative unfolds, considering that most the story is told via silhouettes the sound becomes rather important. Voice acting is pretty solid and old timey that fits the time period.The game does end with a sort sequel bating, and unanswered questions, one of which is made right at the end of the game, which for me is a negative but not so much that I couldn't recommend this game.If you like perspective puzzle platformers, early 20th century noir visuals and a bit of drama, I can recommend this game. It's not the most original game out there, but what it does it does well and certainly has its more charming moments that stick with you.

Posted: July 5, 2015
												Cracking little game, oozes a noir atmosphere, a little bit of surrealism and a little bit of science back when things like Tesla seemed unwordly. The game isn't long, a few hours will see you through the whole thing, but it's a rich and amazingly visual trip, with some clever platforming and puzzles that make great use of light and shadows.If you want to see something innovative and an experience that doesn't come along too often, grab this game and give it a play.

Posted: June 17, 2015
												TLDR: Interesting game with interesting ideas, smooth gameplay and a lovely story-presentation. Unfortunately too short and expensive (when not on sale) considering the amount of content it offers, but still worth a try.Full review:A short (REALLY short, finished it with 100% of the achievements in under 3 hours) platforming game which in a way reminds me of the Portal games since, as one of the game's achievements references to by name, rather than thinking with portals here you are "Thinking with Shadows". Can't reach your objective in the 3d perspective environment? time to start looking for a way to make the shadow of objects, buildings or "people" (even tho they are invisible to your eyes) help you, so that you can then shift into the walls and do 2d perspective platforming with the shadows. The fluidity in which you do this change between the 3d world and the 2d shadows is very smooth. Yes you will run into a few "buggy" spots but they are few and don't really break the gameplay.Story-wise, it is a charm. You could consider it 2 stories, one of the young girl Didi's desire to be with her parents and to make them be happy, which is the focus point for most of the game's lenght, and a more subtle one which springs up near the end related to Dawn, the character you control, about who exactly is she and why she has the powers she has. Mind you, its not the best story ever but it works well for the game and the way it is presented is pretty good.Again, short game and expensive considering the amount of playtime it can offer (I'd recommend buying it when it is on sale with a 60-ish or more % discount) but what little you get is in my opinion quality content worth checking out. Hopefully we see a similar premise, or maybe even a proper game sequel, in the future from this developer.

Posted: October 18, 2015
PROS:+ cool concept of switching between real & shadow world+ beautiful visuals+ great soundtrack+ nice atmosphere of parallel worldsCONS:- quite a lot of glitches- unpolished level design- somewhat mediocre storyComment:Picked this game up a while ago and finally got to give it a try. The beginning felt really nice, with beautiful visual art and design. As you get introduced to the concept of a shadow world and switching between realms the game seems even more great and interesting. This is only emphasized by a cool soundtrack that fits the visuals. However, then comes the mediocre story that gets you running from place to place behind a little girl, making the game very linear. But later I realised this is not that bad. Because the design of the short levels is, while pretty, very unpolished. Glitches and weird camera placement is what took a lot from the experience and made the game frustrating sometimes. You see, the game is easy, casual even. It is just the design problems that make it hard. Otherwise it is a cute experience if you look over the flaws and I can recommend it.

Posted: December 22, 2014
												This game is fun, unique, and a refreshing new addition to puzzle platforming. From start to finish, I absolutely adored this game. The controls are solid, the gameplay is challenging and interesting, and the cartoony film noir art style is a nice accompaniment to the overall atmosphere of the game. To me, this is one game that stands out for really taking a different direction: the way the story is delivered and the emphasis on lights and shadows really made for an unforgettable experience.My only complaint about this game is that it is short. It doesn't take very long to finish this game. I did it in one sitting. It's a game that cries out for a sequel because it has so much potential that, unfortunately, didn't make the first cut.Overall, this game is worth buying. I wholeheartedly recommend it.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												It's great. It's just... it's great. It's beautiful, it's creative, and it's lovely.I was asked if the puzzles got repetitive, because most of them are "move box to thing." And that is true, but the game was only a few hours long. If it went on much longer, I feel like it would have gotten repetitive, but as it was, it was the perfect length to not get boring. There were a few puzzles that were kind of dumb, where I felt like I was kind of cheating by doing it the way I was, because I couldn't figure out what it wanted me to do. None of them were really frustrating, and the one time that I looked up how to do something, it was simply because I overlooked it. I'm all about collectables, so it was really jarring for me to collect something, which was something like the 15th out of 20, when the previous one I had was maybe the 8th. Then later, as I progressed, suddenly I got those bits. It looked as if I had forgotten them, and the way they were ordered for the second half of the game made me constantly question if I got everything. There were also a few occational blips in the graphics, where it suddenly felt like an early Playstation game with how things moved or reacted, and I caught a couple T-poses if I got caught on something. Certainly nothing game-breaking though - just took me a step back from the magic. Sometimes shifting into the shadows would be aggrivating as well, and it just... wouldn't. I would do it again and again and suddenly it would work, and then it wouldn't do it again when I wanted it to. Frustrating, but nothing worth quitting it over Dispite these things, the game is lovely. The art is lovely. The world is lovely. I wish that there was more going on, a sequal in the same space, or something. Maybe a second episode. I want more of this world and this cool ability, but maybe with a different puzzle designer. I would totally reccomend buying it if it's on sale, that's for sure. It's absolutely worth the few bucks. Ful price, ehhhhh. Didn't quite fall in love with it, but certainly had a big crush on it and made it my wallpaper for a day or two.

Posted: May 15, 2015
												Even though I liked the game overall, the entire experience was somewhat underwhelming. It has a lot of unused potential.I liked the setting, art style, music, and most of all, the shadow-shifting mechanics. However, the entire thing feels like it needs a lot more polish to make it feel complete.The story is kind of simplistic, character development is... weird (like that one scene where one character changes their mind by 180°)... You get hints of a back story in the form of collectibles, but they don't really reveal any coherent whole.Then there are luminaries, which are still a mystery to me – you have to use two or three of them in each act to activate some kind of switch or whatever, but you can find a lot more of them throughout the game (like three times the amount you actually need). It feels like they were supposed to be used for something else that then got cut out of the game or something. And I still have no idea what they are at all.There are a bunch of references to parallel universes, both in the final cut-scenes, and in some collectibles, but they don't really converge on any conclusion. They feel more like a cheap excuse for the existence of the main game mechanic, just slapped on the game without trying very hard to give it actual meaning.Same with Dawn, the character you control – there are a couple of hints about her back story, with a “shocking” revelation at the end, but it fails miserably at making sense. Thinking about it, even her name is only mentioned a couple-three times throughout the entire game. That's about as much as you'll learn about her.As for the actual gameplay, it wasn't terrible, but not breathtakingly good either. As I said earlier, shadow-shifting has a lot of potential for interesting and challenging puzzles, and there were a few of them too, but sometimes, you shift out of the shadow due to a glitch, or because the “dashing” ability is too random, forcing you to restart the same puzzle again and again.The lighting, around which a major part of the game revolves, also seems to be made somewhat sloppily. It makes sense that detailed lighting and shading is disabled in areas far away from the playable character, but it gets reenabled too late – after you get into the area, suddenly, a light source appears just like that, with all the shadows. And the shadows themselves are quite glitchy as well – sometimes, your shadow on the floor doesn't match the wall at all, sometimes, your shadow gets stretched into the void... It's not that it doesn't work, but it only works well enough to make the game playable.Other half-baked gameplay elements include grabbing ledges, which only works on a select few of them (and has a weird animation where Dawn's hands are a few centimeters away from the surface she's hanging onto), using objects inside shadows (especially moving them by moving the light source), or using the same awkward “interact” animation everywhere.All in all, the game feels like an exciting demo of a potentially wonderful game. I don't think it's worth its full price, but go get it when it's 75% off. If I were to put this into numbers, I'd say 6/10.

I haven't finished the game because I get bored of puzzle games after a bit, but if you do find the time, you should be able to beat it in a couple of hours and walk away feeling relatively pleased.

Posted: June 9, 2015
												THIS GAME IS AMAZING! Now, it is quite short at around 3.5 hours, but if you missed some collectibles it can get you to about 4.5 hours. The concept of this game sounds quite cool, and in reality it is. The puzzles, at least for me lasted a bit considering I had to look up walkthroughs on half of Portal 2. Posted: December 28, 2014
												Between the interesting playstyle(platformer/puzzle game) and the interesting story I couldn't figure out if I liked the game a lot. But after playing and 100% completing it I'd say it's 8.5/10. Needs some fine tuning but overall very good.ALSO, found a TARDIS. :)

Posted: December 24, 2014
												There aren't that many games which would make me (or anyone) say "Wow that was cool" after they come to an end.This one did it to me!Contrast is an innovative game, taking some well known video-gaming genres and making from them something we haven't seen a lot lately (if at all), with its main downside of being very (!) short and perhaps a little rushed.The main "punch" of Contrast is the you'd play around not only in your old-regular 3D world but also in the shadow world, yes, you'd step into a wall and become your own shadow.Sounds simple, but fortunately Contrast doesn't just use the one and only gimmick it creates in order to try and make itself a good game, but also wraps it with some great graphics and sounds, interesting characters and a moving story in an exceptionally good noir atmosphere.Too bad you can easily finish this game in about 3 hours, and if you like to take your time like myself, and explore every corner.. You may reach 6 hours. No more.The game is also mostly not very challanging, and despite the interesting gameplay you can easily rush through the game, most of the time. And when you have some difficulties it would not necessarily be because of a challanging puzzle, but because some minor technical issue, as you may notice that the game and its mechanics aren't 100% polished.I'm aware that the developers are new, independent and small company. But at some points I did wonder whether that's the reason for  those few and usually minor flaws in Contrast, or simply because it was too rushed.Anyway, it doesn't hurt badly to my appreciation for this game.Because of its great artistic values, because of it being new and unusual and yet so good and engaging, it may even be worth those 15 bucks, and I'd definitely recommend this game.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												This game is a little hidden gem! It's been on my wishlist for a while now and I'm so glad I finally picked it up when it was on sale. It takes only four hours to complete, but I usually don't hold that against indie titles, and the length felt perfect for the story anyway. It's set in the early 20's (a time period I'm a total sucker for), and the art style is totally amazing and very impressive that they could pull this off with I assume is a smaller team and budget - it looks like a Dali painting of someone's fading childhood memory.So the art style immediately captivated me, but it doesn't stop there: the main game mechanic is a very neat idea: you can jump in and out of the shadow world, where it plays like a 2d platformer, and there are all sort of puzzles around playing with light, creating shadows and then using those shadows to traverse both worlds. There are some rough edges with the controls and the mechanic here and there, but mostly it's really fun.The story is also very sweet, and it integrates very well with the game mechanics. All in all, it's an almost perfect game for a a relaxing afternoon :)

Posted: April 2
												Pros:-Art style is wonderful-Loads of references and easter eggs (if you can catch them)-Gameplay, as in it's interesting-Voice acting (other than Didi, god her voice sucks)-Easy to learn-Presentation-Story (not astounding, but good anyway)Cons:-Pretty short-Gameplay-Price (I'd say 10 bucks more like it)Why is gameplay both a pro and a con? Because this game is very charming and wonderful, it's gameplay included. However, the same mechanics that really makes it interesting also damn it so badly at times. I mean ♥♥♥♥, I was wanting to break my moniter at some parts because the game would not function by its own rules. This happans at least 5 times throughout the game -- these spots where unless you're standing in pixel perfect spots, or jump at the absolute perfect moment, you'll fail over and over.However, other than the length and Didi's terrible voice acting, this game is rather quaint and very enjoyable. I think the voice acting and art direction were just so on point, again, except for Didi. It sounded like they recorded her in a school hallway.If numbers suit your fancy, I'd say about an 8/10.

I love the storyline and the time it's set in, and the music is AMAZING. I'd even suggest buying the soundtrack, that is if you like 20's jazz type music. Posted: June 22, 2015
												It's great. It's just... it's great. It's beautiful, it's creative, and it's lovely.I was asked if the puzzles got repetitive, because most of them are "move box to thing." And that is true, but the game was only a few hours long. If it went on much longer, I feel like it would have gotten repetitive, but as it was, it was the perfect length to not get boring. There were a few puzzles that were kind of dumb, where I felt like I was kind of cheating by doing it the way I was, because I couldn't figure out what it wanted me to do. None of them were really frustrating, and the one time that I looked up how to do something, it was simply because I overlooked it. I'm all about collectables, so it was really jarring for me to collect something, which was something like the 15th out of 20, when the previous one I had was maybe the 8th. Then later, as I progressed, suddenly I got those bits. It looked as if I had forgotten them, and the way they were ordered for the second half of the game made me constantly question if I got everything. There were also a few occational blips in the graphics, where it suddenly felt like an early Playstation game with how things moved or reacted, and I caught a couple T-poses if I got caught on something. Certainly nothing game-breaking though - just took me a step back from the magic. Sometimes shifting into the shadows would be aggrivating as well, and it just... wouldn't. I would do it again and again and suddenly it would work, and then it wouldn't do it again when I wanted it to. Frustrating, but nothing worth quitting it over Dispite these things, the game is lovely. The art is lovely. The world is lovely. I wish that there was more going on, a sequal in the same space, or something. Maybe a second episode. I want more of this world and this cool ability, but maybe with a different puzzle designer. I would totally reccomend buying it if it's on sale, that's for sure. It's absolutely worth the few bucks. Ful price, ehhhhh. Didn't quite fall in love with it, but certainly had a big crush on it and made it my wallpaper for a day or two.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Stunning visuals. Beautiful soundtrack. Challenging puzzles. 1920s noir ambiance. A bit of carnival, a bit of burlesque. This game is full of art, music and beauty. There is no daylight – only streetlights that bathe the cobblestone streets and alleyways. You are in a dreamlike world. Straddling the physical world and the shadow world, you must use various light sources to carve your path in the shadows to the other side. Though all but two characters are mere shadows upon the walls, their voices echoing around you, the game manages to pull together an interesting and captivating story… a story that becomes an adventure for you, Dawn, and Didi - the only one who can see you. Didi wants her family back together, and you are here to aid her using your unique abilities.At times, the gameplay mechanics are frustrating and glitchy. But overall, the game is challenging without being impossible. The puzzles are creative and clever, and they carry the shadow play throughout the entire game and encourage you to use it intelligently to either continue on your path or obtain necessary elements or optional collectibles. The immersion is consistent and flawless - you do not leave the world the developers have created until you quit the game. And even then, you may find yourself humming the theme song...Though it will only take you a handful of hours to finish, it would be well worth your while to give this puzzle-platformer a try. This game has heart.

Posted: May 15, 2015
												Even though I liked the game overall, the entire experience was somewhat underwhelming. It has a lot of unused potential.I liked the setting, art style, music, and most of all, the shadow-shifting mechanics. However, the entire thing feels like it needs a lot more polish to make it feel complete.The story is kind of simplistic, character development is... weird (like that one scene where one character changes their mind by 180°)... You get hints of a back story in the form of collectibles, but they don't really reveal any coherent whole.Then there are luminaries, which are still a mystery to me – you have to use two or three of them in each act to activate some kind of switch or whatever, but you can find a lot more of them throughout the game (like three times the amount you actually need). It feels like they were supposed to be used for something else that then got cut out of the game or something. And I still have no idea what they are at all.There are a bunch of references to parallel universes, both in the final cut-scenes, and in some collectibles, but they don't really converge on any conclusion. They feel more like a cheap excuse for the existence of the main game mechanic, just slapped on the game without trying very hard to give it actual meaning.Same with Dawn, the character you control – there are a couple of hints about her back story, with a “shocking” revelation at the end, but it fails miserably at making sense. Thinking about it, even her name is only mentioned a couple-three times throughout the entire game. That's about as much as you'll learn about her.As for the actual gameplay, it wasn't terrible, but not breathtakingly good either. As I said earlier, shadow-shifting has a lot of potential for interesting and challenging puzzles, and there were a few of them too, but sometimes, you shift out of the shadow due to a glitch, or because the “dashing” ability is too random, forcing you to restart the same puzzle again and again.The lighting, around which a major part of the game revolves, also seems to be made somewhat sloppily. It makes sense that detailed lighting and shading is disabled in areas far away from the playable character, but it gets reenabled too late – after you get into the area, suddenly, a light source appears just like that, with all the shadows. And the shadows themselves are quite glitchy as well – sometimes, your shadow on the floor doesn't match the wall at all, sometimes, your shadow gets stretched into the void... It's not that it doesn't work, but it only works well enough to make the game playable.Other half-baked gameplay elements include grabbing ledges, which only works on a select few of them (and has a weird animation where Dawn's hands are a few centimeters away from the surface she's hanging onto), using objects inside shadows (especially moving them by moving the light source), or using the same awkward “interact” animation everywhere.All in all, the game feels like an exciting demo of a potentially wonderful game. I don't think it's worth its full price, but go get it when it's 75% off. If I were to put this into numbers, I'd say 6/10.

Posted: June 17, 2015
												TLDR: Interesting game with interesting ideas, smooth gameplay and a lovely story-presentation. Unfortunately too short and expensive (when not on sale) considering the amount of content it offers, but still worth a try.Full review:A short (REALLY short, finished it with 100% of the achievements in under 3 hours) platforming game which in a way reminds me of the Portal games since, as one of the game's achievements references to by name, rather than thinking with portals here you are "Thinking with Shadows". Can't reach your objective in the 3d perspective environment? time to start looking for a way to make the shadow of objects, buildings or "people" (even tho they are invisible to your eyes) help you, so that you can then shift into the walls and do 2d perspective platforming with the shadows. The fluidity in which you do this change between the 3d world and the 2d shadows is very smooth. Yes you will run into a few "buggy" spots but they are few and don't really break the gameplay.Story-wise, it is a charm. You could consider it 2 stories, one of the young girl Didi's desire to be with her parents and to make them be happy, which is the focus point for most of the game's lenght, and a more subtle one which springs up near the end related to Dawn, the character you control, about who exactly is she and why she has the powers she has. Mind you, its not the best story ever but it works well for the game and the way it is presented is pretty good.Again, short game and expensive considering the amount of playtime it can offer (I'd recommend buying it when it is on sale with a 60-ish or more % discount) but what little you get is in my opinion quality content worth checking out. Hopefully we see a similar premise, or maybe even a proper game sequel, in the future from this developer.

												This game is fun, unique, and a refreshing new addition to puzzle platforming. From start to finish, I absolutely adored this game. The controls are solid, the gameplay is challenging and interesting, and the cartoony film noir art style is a nice accompaniment to the overall atmosphere of the game. It doesn't take very long to finish this game. I did it in one sitting. It's a game that cries out for a sequel because it has so much potential that, unfortunately, didn't make the first cut.Overall, this game is worth buying. I wholeheartedly recommend it.

The game is short enough to not outstay its welcome, and there is an interesting back story in the collectibles.Worth playing for the Princess shadowpuppet level alone.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Contrast is a rather simple indie, platform/puzzle game about a young girl, Didi, and her (apparently) imaginary friend Dawn trying to help out Didi's father figure, Johnny, over one single night in a 1920's, jazz-themed city.You take control of Dawn and are given the power to switch between a normal world and a shadow world in order to advance in the city, solve some puzzles and collect bonus items, like luminaries and plot documents. The premise is simple enough, but the game, while being worth just 2-3 hours of platforming and puzzle solving, is able to offer you a decent but fair challenge, introducing new mechanics and gimmicks as the story progresses that manage to keep you on your toes. Furthermore, failing a jump or anything of the kind won't inconvenence you at all, given you have pretty much infinite lives/tries.The  strongest points of Contrast are a very charming art style, which heavily borrows from the 20s and jazz music, and an interesting story, which is able to engage the player even if not exactly long or overcomplex. As mentioned above, there are some collectables to be found, but hunting them doesn't extend the game's lenght substantially.It's also worth mentioning that Didi, the young protagonist, is one of the most berable, cute and useful child I've ever met in a videogame

												Great concept, poor execution. Movement, and especially the jumping on shadows, feels a bit awkward, and you are certain to fall to your death a lot. Posted: July 2, 2016
												This game is a little hidden gem! It's been on my wishlist for a while now and I'm so glad I finally picked it up when it was on sale. It takes only four hours to complete, but I usually don't hold that against indie titles, and the length felt perfect for the story anyway. It's set in the early 20's (a time period I'm a total sucker for), and the art style is totally amazing and very impressive that they could pull this off with I assume is a smaller team and budget - it looks like a Dali painting of someone's fading childhood memory.So the art style immediately captivated me, but it doesn't stop there: the main game mechanic is a very neat idea: you can jump in and out of the shadow world, where it plays like a 2d platformer, and there are all sort of puzzles around playing with light, creating shadows and then using those shadows to traverse both worlds. There are some rough edges with the controls and the mechanic here and there, but mostly it's really fun.The story is also very sweet, and it integrates very well with the game mechanics. All in all, it's an almost perfect game for a a relaxing afternoon :)

												Contrast is a game for those seeking a story-driven experience rather than a lot of action or brain teasing. The game isn't exceptionally long and rewards taking things slow to view the environment and attend to the story surrounding little Didi's broken family.The main gameplay mechanic which the puzzles are framed around is that of shadow manipulation; the player character shifts in and out of shadows on the walls to navigate through the environment and achieve each goal. 												Nice little game with unique shadow-jump-and-run gameplay.Short but gameplay-matching story with nice visuals.I encoundered no bugs or glitches, which was a pleasant suprise given the quality of some other games.I enjoyed the ride. 8/10

Posted: March 5, 2015
												This game had so much potential, but ultimately I was disappointed by it. With more work, this could have been a great game.Contrast is a game with a novel mechanic: the player moves between a 3D normal world and a 2D "shadow world" to solve platform puzzles. It makes for some really challenging puzzles, but unfortunately, this system can be buggy and unwieldy at times, making some of the puzzles much more difficult than necessary.The game took me three hours to finish. It's not a long game, and I feel that is its biggest weakness. It lacks the depth of a truly immersive story. At the end of the game, I was left wanting more. More backstory. More plot. More explanation. More puzzles to solve. I feel like so much more could have been done with this game to give the player a really good story.The story is set in a beautifully-crafted, dark, intriguing noir-20's/30's world with heavy steampunk accents. The level modeling and art are excellent, but the character modeling and voice acting leaves something to be desired. The actors are rather unpassionate and unconvincing.Contrast is a fun little game, and I definitely recommend it. However, I think it could have been so much more, and ultimately I was disappointed by its lack of depth.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												I seriously loved this! And I'm glad I didn't listen to the mixed reviews but instead followed my intuition.This game reminded me of an unexpected cross between Limbo, Life Is Strange and Bioshock Infinite with some Tim Burton influences (and a faint déjà-vu of Alice: Madness Returns during one of the levels), and on top of that, it's really well done! The only few and in between moments of frustration were some glitchy/fiddly shadow jumps and the solving of some non-obvious puzzles (but that's actually a good thing!). Other than that, I have no complaints whatsoever, except maybe how short it is: I played it through within one sitting of 4 hours. It's atmospheric and suspenseful and emotional and I REALLY recommend it! It does deserve a sequel (though I heard Compulsion Games are busy on another project now).

Posted: July 8, 2016
												Contrast is a very short game with flaws but it has a charming personality with some great high notes.Pros:+1920's noir aesthetic is really well done.+Many clever puzzles, shifting between the 3D world and a world of shadows.+Collectibles are not obnoxious.+Not terribly hard to 100%.+When the story is flowing well, it's pretty entertaining.+Fantastic soundtrack.+Mostly solid voice acting.Cons:-Only 2-3 hours of game play to see everything.-Some puzzle elements are pretty obtuse. Lots of "huh, I didn't know that was a mechanic" moments when solving puzzles.-Motivation for main character is pretty slim.-Sometimes the transitions between shadow realm and real world aren't clean, leads you to die or repeat sections often.-The story can hop around or drag, then it ends suddenly.-NPC girl you spend most of your time with is frustrating and pushy to no end. Her whiney screeching of non-sequitur commands was a grind.All in all I feel that this was a game that was aiming much higher than where it landed, but it didn't end up in a bad place generally speaking. There are plenty of fun bits alongside the annoying. Worth a pickup on sale, not so much at full price.

Posted: July 14, 2016
												A very nice puzzle 3d exploration/puzzle game.While not long, the storyline is emotional and engaging.The mechanics fit completely with the story, and the combination of 3d/2d with shadows is something I've never seen before. Most of the puzzles are fairly simple, but enjoyable nonetheless.I did occasionally have trouble with being automatically shifted out of the shadows, which sometimes made puzzles annoying/repetitive to solve.If the game looks interesting to you, I would recommend you buy it. It is a enjoyable experience, well worth trying out.

Posted: July 12, 2016
												This game was great fun for me. I'd recommend it to anyone who can handle slightly bad controls and a bit of weak story in exchange for beautiful visuals and a ton of ambiance in a game that you can complete in one sitting (2.5-3 hours). Most of the puzzles were fun and rewarding and the theme was pretty neat. Definitely catch it on sale if you're a fan of puzzle-platformers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19
												Contrast is a 2D/3D puzzle platformer set in a surreal version of the 1920's.The unique mechanic here is switching between the normal 3D world and the the 2D world of shadows. Most of the puzzles in the game are based on this core mechanic in one way or another. Unfortunately puzzle quality feels rather inconsistent. Some of the puzzles make a great use of the shadow world whereas others feel rather poorly designed.Controls are probably the weakest link in this game. I was playing on a gamepad and overall the controls felt rather imprecise. In particular it's way too easy to exit the shadow world by accident. The game also suffers from a number of glitches like getting stuck in obstacles or walls.On a more positive note the artwork and the audio are great and fit the setting perfectly. The story and the writing are rather strong too. Unfortunately the game is fairly short, some more content would have been nice.Despite its flaws I'd recommend Contrast to any fans of puzzle platformers who are willing to put up with the rather poor controls.The good:- Switching between 3D and 2D is a clever idea- Great setting- Gorgeous visuals- Nice audio- Strong mature storyThe bad:- Poor controls- Some poorly designed puzzles- Little bit short (I took me around 3.5 hours to finish the game)- Very linear mapsThe ugly:- Quite a few glitches and minor bugs such as getting stuck in walls

												There's something special about this game, maybe you'd spect a larger game but the lenght is just enough to tell the story of this little girl in her world full of imagination. This game have unique parts of history and really cool puzzles.Graphically It's looks gourgeous, the shadows and colors are just great.Also he music reminded me the movie "Moulin Rouge", If you love puzzles you'll find this game as an awesome experinece, but if your are watching for a game to spend more than 6 hours you'll be dissapointed because this game is very short... but really it's a satisfaying game that you should try by yourself.

Posted: February 11, 2014
												This is one heck of a great indie game. The art style is simply amazing, the puzzle and platform mechanics are fun and innovative, the environment is very well fleshed-out and really gives character to the world. A nice heart-worming story, short and sweet but well worth the money if you want a taste of something that breaks the mold of all the popular adventure/platformer games out there. Just had a little trouble actually getting the game to run due to some game settings that don't allow certain graphic cards, but there is a quick and harmless workaround to get it going. Also forgot to mention the fantastic jazz and cabaret music that goes so well with the environment and greatly adds to the immersion into this world.

Posted: February 11, 2014
												Contrast is one of those story driven games, but it has enough platformer to be a bit challenging. Its more of a beginner platformer than an advanced platformer so if you are looking for hard puzzles you won't find them here. Its got a pretty unique game play style, and as the game is story driven, the plot is just amazing, and the whole feel of the world (as well as a few bugs) keep you on your toes the entire time. Its got that deep otherworldly feel to it while you are tackling pretty everyday(ish) problems in extraordinary ways. The voice acting is pretty amazing as long as you don't mind a LOT of it, you get attached to all the characters. And, I have to iterate, to enjoy this game fully, you MUST try to pick up the collectables and read through them as you go, as they are an integral part of the plot, especially later in the game, and you will get very lost very quickly plot wise if you don't. All in all, its a little rough around the edges but its got a passionate heart that will move you in story and in some really cleverly disguised, if not a bit easy, puzzles. Its very much an open to interpretation game, like Journey, and with art I think is pretty influential and amazing to the atmosphere in a cartoony yet gritty style with fantasy splashed on it in the most fascinating ways.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												I'd consider "Contrast" one of the "Indie gems" of our time.It's a modern game with some fresh ideas, but also obvious roots in some classics.The whole design, the art, the music, the story, the levels, the mechanics, it all plays together very well, creating a rounded experience.The story soon became more intense than I expected, driving me forwards, wanting to know what happens next.The levels, puzzles and platform sequenses aren't very big or difficult, though sometimes there are little to no indicators what to do next, just a little exploration or trial should provide the solution.The main mechanic of using light and shadow is just amazing, used in various ways, keeping it interesting, only sometimes it seems a little rough/ glitchy.The only "negative" i could say about the whole game is that i would've wished for some more of it all, a little bit more story, a little bit more gameplay to go through, (even) more things that could've been done with the mechanics and a bit more smoothing out the little edges of the game. So i would wish for a bigger, second part, or a spinoff or something, but that's not even really a bad thing to say about "Contrast" itself.

Posted: March 11
												This is really a nice little game, easy to miss though as it seems to be a bit underrated.I really liked the 20's vaudeville/ film noir atmosphere, the design of the puzzles and the narration. The voice acting is also very convincing. And the game is unique with its mechanic of manipulating light source to solve the puzzles: this forces to think a bit out of the box.On the downside I wish there was more of it: with about 4 hours of gameplay, I felt the end was a bit rushed. I'll probably come back to it for the few details I missed during my first playthough, but there's not much replayability.One minor issue I had were some glitches: sometimes the controls can be a bit clumsy, and I got stuck 2 times in the wall and had to reload the game (bad collision detection I guess).

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Contrast succeeds at being surreal and cute at the same time. Cute only because of the secondary main character and her naivity.As a 3D platformer, it is very short, but boasts a wonderful art style that is also creepy in a Tim Burton kind of way.You play as Dawn, an 'imaginary' friend to Didi, the daughter of Kat and Vincenzo. Didi's adoptive father is actually this guy named Johnny who's trying to make a name for himself. The overall story has overtones of mafia involvement, magic, illuisions, etc. It has a very early 1900's feel to it but the world is so surreal with the city that the game takes place being on floating islands. And the clockwork systems and other stuff.The standout element is the ability to shift from the real world to the shadow world, similar to, I think it's Paper Mario where he can stick and travel on the walls. Or one of the Legend of Zelda's where Link actually does transform into a shadow of sorts. Well, it's like that. Dawn has that ability basically.I guess my only complaints would be the lack of ambient sounds and the length of the game. Otherwise, pretty good.7.5/10

Posted: September 6, 2015
												Okay game. Kind of short. 2 hours and I finished it. It's so simple I think I'll just go for the achievements. The story is a bit peculiar. Sometimes, you will be wondering if everything is in Didi's (little girl protagonist) head. You'll be wondering if you are playing Tim Burton's Psychonauts. You might be assuming that Dawn (shadow girl) is actually grown up Didi but the ending may change your mind. The ending is really interesting. The subtle hint with the hand is quite "Hmmmm". Multiverses.I would recommend that you get this on sale at a really low price. It's too short and it's not AAA. But it is ingenious.PROS1. Ingenious Use of ShadowsI love the way the shadow world works on the wall. It's different from games such as Soul Reaver where you alternate between dimensions to find missing pieces. Having a flat surface and light creates very interesting situations.2. DashingQuite fun to use. Fast to transverse the map. 3. PuzzlesVery nice. Loved the Solarium. Had to pause for a while to think of where to adjust the correct distance and angles to place the gears. Too few puzzles though and most of them weren't much of a challenge.4. Pirate ShipQuite funny5. Princess StoryLoved it, especially the ridiculous commentary when you fall onto the bamboo. Poor Fred.CONS1. Shadows and Rounded Surfaces, CracksBuggy. The shadows don't work well when it come to cracks and rounded surfaces. They tend to throw you out from the shadow world.2. Way Too Short2 hours is way too short. A slight waste of money. I was hoping for at least 10 hours. I was actually expecting Vincenzo's story, Knight's story, the gangster's or Salvo's story and a little more about Didi. 3. LuminariesWhat's the point of collecting all the Luminaries again? You only need 2/3 to power up the lights.NEUTRAL1. CollectiblesThe photos and news clippings are a bit "meh". They hardly add to the story since the game already tells you about them.

												pros: really good presentation & voice acting, creative puzzles consisting of in-and-out shadow form with platforming, a well paced 3 hour game, collectables and easter eggscons: some puzzles could of used fine tuning instead of trial-and-error. content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Short but sweet. Contrast is a very creative game, unlike most of the games I usually play. While it has its share of flaws, i.e. gameplay feels clunky here and there, it totally makes up for it with surprisingly interesting characters and fantastic music. The game is short, and the end left me wanting more, but despite some frustrating moments, I just finished it with a satisfied feeling. I was really rooting for Johnny to get his act together, and I think, most people will. I got Contrast for a nice deal (during the Canada sale), so I'd really recommend you spend a few euros or dollars if the game is up on sale again. It'll be worth it.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Contrast is short, has a few minor bugs and flaws. There was actually a lot that erked me. For example, the game screwed with my mouse sensitivity in game, so i had to tweak it so the camera wasn't making me dizzy. Also, it was a bit more demanding on my pc then i thought it would (but my pc is old. Any up to date pc should do fine). Fixed camera angles when interecting with objects can also be a bit obnoxious. However... for the flaws, this game was really enjoyable. It's a bit of soul food, makes you think and ask questions. It feels substantial as far as the story and the world is concerned (Some say gameplay is lacking challange, but for me it lacked a lot of the frustration that can come with some puzzle games with obtuse solutions. For example, the secret star solutions in Braid, one of which requires you to do nothing but wait for nearly 40 minutes or so). The art is fantastic, definitely different from what i've played recently. The Music and overal sound design is wonderful, though the voice acting isn't the best. Contrast is one of those examples of "Games are Art" while still being a game, as opposed to a tour with some narration over top. If you don't mind a short, but fufilling experiance or some so so gameplay, and you want a great story, world, and overall aesthetic then pick up contrast. If you want something challanging, lengthy, and a bit shallower (i.e. good dumb fun such as Painkiller) then look elsewhere. A game for when you're in the mood, and a damn good one if you end up playing it in that mood.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
Short, but not too shortContrast tells the story of a little girl named Didi and her seemingly invisible friend Dawn, who is literally living in the world of shadows. The story is set sometime in the 1920s and takes place in a wonderfully crafted and stylistically consistent world that looks like a mix between reality and dream.You as player take on the role of Dawn, who is not only invisible to everyone but Didi, but can also shift between the 3-dimensional realm of reality and the 2-dimensional plane of shadows, where ever there is a bright light on any large enough surface. The feature is well-implemented, and most of the puzzles are cleverly built around this feature; the way it forces  the player to view things and think about them differently reminded me of Portal 1 and 2 - in a good way.The story, surprisingly, is far from being a fairy tale for children as there are some very dark tones to it. On the other hand however, Contrast is a fantastic example for a compelling experience that does not need unnecessary violence in order to work. Both gameplay and story work well together, and neither falls short.Speaking of short, the only short thing about the game is the time it takes to complete the story; for me, this was less than four hours. This is not to say the game is too short, however, as I found it to be just the right duration for the story to unfold. Any longer and it would've fallen into the same trap as so many other games that try to stretch the length of a decent story by diluting it with repetitive gameplay segments.So can I recommend this game? Yes, the story, gameplay and presentation (both visuals and audio) are definitely worth it. However, if you are unsure because of the short length you may wish to wait until it is on sale again.On a sidenote: When I started playing the game with a DualShock 3 Controller emulated as 360 Controller using MotionInJoy, the camera seemed to be a little oversensitive. After changing to a proper 360 Controller (cable) for the second half of the game, the camera seemed to be a little more controllable. Just a heads-up for everyone using a DS3.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												A unique experience, however brief, that should not be passed up by anyone who's looking for a good story. The game is presented with a beautiful art style in a strange and enchanting city, where you play the role of an imaginary friend looking out for a girl named Didi. On your way you'll solve puzzles, shift into a dimension of shadows and explore the dimly lit city. It wasn't long before I knew that this would be one of the best games I've ever played. I can remember many games that might have a more satisfying conclusion, better structure and pacing, but Contrast is simply beautiful and engaging, and I could never stop to wonder why. It's a game that's been made with heart and soul, by developers who really wanted to share their vision and story with the player. And although it may not have been fully realized, Contrast is a simply marvelous mystery that I'll be recommending to my friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
PresentationContrast is one of those games that's unique and memorable at the same time, as it drags you into a shadow world in the 1920s Paris in the role of Dawn, young Didi's best friend who possesses the ability of shifting between the 3D material world and the 2D shadow world, making Contrast one of most ideas-filled titles of this year. Didi is also the only person who can see Dawn, but the actions you perform around the city will have an impact on the real world that is seen as shadows from Dawn's eyes as well. Even though Dawn is an interesting character on her own that you'd definitely become interested in as the game goes, this is the story of Didi's parents, who are constantly arguing after Didi's father left and her mother is too busy working at night, leaving her unattended - a perfect opportunity for her to sneak out and fix things around the city with Dawn's help. The bad thing about Contrast is that it will end too soon, rushing through the events of the story just to get to the ending, and even though following the plot is satisfying as it is, there are lots of moments that could've been detailed more, making the game longer and the lasting experience more satisfying in the end. Without doubt Contrast nails its presentation, having a simple menu that will almost instantly take you into the action, while still offering you plenty of options to manage things such as collectibles or taking a look over your stats. Starting with the purely astonishing art work and the detailed characters and moving on to the shadows that have an important role in the gameplay, but offer an incredible visual effect as well, the game is constantly reminding you how awesome its core idea truly is. The problem with that idea however is that it hasn't reached its full potential, as the moment when you get most comfortable with the control and the idea of the game is the same moment the game will reach its denouement. There are so many ideas that are simply rushed inside the game, such as walking up the shadows of Didi's parents in order to reach a location and listening to their speech while doing so; those are the kind of moments that make Contrast feel unique and make you desire more out of this game.Rating: 9.5GameplayThe idea of shifting between the real 3D world and the world of shadows is without doubt one of the most unique and innovating ideas of this year and Contrast takes great advantage of this idea, creating some amazing puzzles that will leave you satisfied each time you complete one and move in to the next area, but the best thing about those puzzles is their deductibility, forcing you to analyse each one of them, but offering the solution if you stare at them long enough as it is sometimes more than obvious. Each new location you visit will introduce new puzzle concepts, some trickier than others, but same as the story those are rushed, never taking full advantage of their potential, as the game will quickly move from one concept to another, leaving abilities such as the shadow dash to be used only a few times in the entire game. There are the occasional glitches that will stop you from making a move in your first try, but there isn't any sort of time pressure on the gameplay so you have all the time in the world to find your way around a puzzle and reach your destination. The 3D world puzzles are enjoyable and the shadow puzzles even more, but the real magic begins when the game combines those elements to create some amazing areas that you will have to scout first, try different approaches and only then decide on a final solution that will take you to your destination, but all this time spent looking around an area is well spent as you will constantly be excited about where one thing should go or how the positioning of some objects will help you reach a higher point. Walking up the shadows of Didi's parents is an amazing concept as you get to listen to a part of the story while you're slowly making your way to a location that's related to that story, constantly keeping you on the edge about what's gonna happen next as you climb higher and higher and eventually reach a location that will unlock further mysteries. There is a lot of great stuff in here and because it is so great it leaves you with a thirst for more and unfortunately there isn't anything else.Rating: 8.5GraphicsContrast on the PlayStation 4 looks amazing, making the city of Paris come to life at night with the use of those same shadows that make the gameplay so enjoyable, as the little bit of light that is available in an area will reflect objects in the precise direction, something that affects the gameplay as well as the overall beauty of this title. Even if you only get to see Dawn and Didi as full characters, as the rest of the cast is seen as shadows, they are both incredibly detailed and fit into the world perfectly. The visual effects are okay, with a few things that could use some work, but what is really impressive is the reflection of certain things on the pavement of the street as it is wet and seeing that no matter where you go is impressive.Rating: 9AudioThe voice acting is top notch, as the entire cast including Didi, her parents and Vincenzo take advantage of some amazing voice work that truly helps sell the story and the emotional road it takes once you get to know Didi better. The sound effects are just as good, making the world come to life and give Dawn's powers a great background; the best thing however, comes in the soundtrack, as from the start of the game you will be greeted with a noire classic, a perfect fit for the city of Paris in the early '20s, and the list goes on and on as you progress through the game.Rating: 10ExtrasUnfortunately, the main campaign is the only thing that the game provides and that will be over in less than 6 hours, depending on how much time you take to solve each puzzle, and even though the game has collectibles you can find those easily in your first playthrough if you just look around, so unless you wanna replay the game a few weeks after just to relive the awesomeness, there isn't anything else to keep you around.Rating: 4VerdictContrast is one of the best experiences you can have this year, not only because it is unique, but because it works wonders, providing some great puzzles, amazing exploration and a story worth hearing, unfortunately that will only last a few hours, so if you were looking for something to keep you around your PS4 a lot more, this will come as a disappointment, but either way Contrast is a game worth playing at some point, even if it isn't your priority for the new console.Rating: 8.2Check out the full review and a lot more about Contrast at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=38&t=330

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												Contrast is a story driven puzzle-platformer game with interesting light mechanics where you manipulate shadows to create a path. Platforming is not very challenging so it feels more like eye-candy game with some casual puzzles .There are some minor issues with gameplay and infrequent glitches like getting stack but overall Contrast left a positive impression because it is such a beautiful game I am completely in love with the surreal artstyle and overall design of the stages . Enviroments are very exaggerated so it looks like you playing inside a dream or fantasy painting . The lack of characters is probably a budget problem but in a way it complements gloomy atmopshere that I very much enjoy .The story at first seems very down to earth but the ending kinda puzzled me in a good way . You actually use cutscenes as a platforming objects which is a cool way to tell a story .Despite the wird nature of this game it is not a hard game to play . Perhaps it depends on a person but I had no problems getting in and out of shadows when It was needed . There were few moments where it was a bit junky and I plummeted to my death but check points are very close so it was not a big issue .Perhaps my only serious problem with the game is the lack of music during puzzle sections . Contrast has some good music but it goes silent during most areas where you stay for 10-20 minutes . Maybe it is a design choice but I really hate doing puzzles with nothing playing in the background .I beat this game just under 4 hours but the quality of the stages justifies relatively short game . Also I will play it at least one more time just to collect all the clues but replay value is only held by the artsyle .Verdict 8/10 . Not every platforming game needs to be hard or complex . Contrast was relaxing and enjoyable experiance even if gameplay felt slightly lacking  . It may feel a bit empty when there is no music during puzzles . However overall Contrast's artistic vision and compelling story telling was worth my time .

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Disclaimer: I have mostly good things to say about Contrast, but the lack of polish on this game makes it so I simply cannot recommend it, no matter how much I wish I could. A post-release patch could easily fix all the issues I describe below, but two years after release and these are still problems; hence, thumbs down, albeit reluctantly. I was tempted to grab this game when it was first released, but I'm glad I waited. I completed the game in about 3.5 hours, so do the math and figure out what amount of money you'd be willing to pay. I would instead recommend a game like Papo & Yo, which also centers around a child with family issues and is of similar length with equally unique but different qualities. So, without further ado:Contrast is a platformer where you shift between the 3D "real world" and the 2D "shadow world" to solve puzzles. The controls are clunky/sloppy and you cannot remap your keys. This game was released in 2013 and the player can't remap keybinds? Hell, keybind remapping should be required; it's nearly an industry standard, and Contrast loses big points for lacking this "feature." This issue, combined with the dreadful controls, made it extremely frustrating at times. Near the end of the game, I died about a dozen consecutive times trying to jump a small gap. Was it my fault? I can't imagine so. I was very close to rage-quitting, but I knew I was in the home stretch. Fortunately, dying is pretty painless in Contrast, as you just respawn at some predetermined location in the game-world, and quickly at that... but even then, the developers barely put any thought into it. Sometimes to complete a puzzle it's easier to just jump into a pit than go back the way you came! I felt like I cheated during a few portions of the game, but considering how frustrated I was with the game by those points, I didn't mind. Ugh.By Act III I just wanted to get it over with... but not because I didn't enjoy the characters, visuals, style, noire atmosphere, or music, all of which are excellent (especially the songs performed by Laura Ellis on vocals!). The story is good as well, but nothing to rave about. Gameplay just became a chore, partially because there's zero hand-holding in the game. Now, I'm not saying I needed hints to complete the puzzles; honestly, they're all pretty easy. But near the end of the game, I assumed the puzzle I was completing had to be much harder than it really was... so I spent about 15 minutes trying to move spotlights to solve this imagined quandry when all I actually had to do was jump up a ledge I didn't know I could jump up. Oh, and one time I screwed up a puzzle and had to restart from my last save... but since you can't save manually and the game doesn't tell you when it auto-saves, it made me replay a chunk of the game. Sigh. Come on.One final nit-pick that really irks me: in Act II of III, there's a carosel puzzle, and once you complete it you can retrieve an item on top of the building... but if you don't grab the item when you're up there, you cannot go back and retrieve it, ever. I realize it's a small issue, but man... combining that with the lack of remapping and no real saving function and it's just too much. The developers could have created a wonderful experience for the player, but with the previous issues and the awful controls, Contrast is simply a shadow of what it could have been....get it?

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Pros: -Dawn's powers and design are pretty cool-Hidden Tardis-Going from 2d to 3d is a really cool concept-Parts of environments are destroyed and look surreal, but gorgeous.-The game is pretty short.Cons:-Didi is annoying-Almost every mission is about helping Didi's dad (also she has to have the worst parents in the world)-There's not really a plot. You help Didi and her parents with a bunch of stuff, but then it just kind of ends with a "twist".-Dawn's powers and what happened to her are somewhat explained, but not directly.-The game seems too short for 14.99Bottom line: If you care about story, don't get it. If you like platformers...or kids, go ahead and get it. I would strongly suggest buying it when it's on sale. There are other games for 14.99 or less that will give you hours of playability. This is not one of them. Some day I will replay this game to get all the achievements and the collectibles (i missed 1), but I won't anytime soon because I found myself angry and frustrated at the end of the game with the story and everything involving Didi, her parents, and the magician. I cannot express how disappointed I was after beating this game when it looks so good.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This game had a great concept and story, but the horrible gameplay ruins the experience. The "interaction" is buggy as hell, and the screwy third-person view isn't particularly helpful either. My field of view actually clipped outside the wall in the wall at the start of the game because the room is way too small for such a zoomed-out camera.Also, the game has random lag spikes at the worst possible times, and the graphics settings are extremely lacking in customizability. I could not get past a certain point in the game because it lagged literally EVERY ♥♥♥♥ING TIME that I tried to make a certain jump, and so I couldn't switch back to shadow mode in time, and fell to my death. Repeatedly, until I eventually gave up.Also, the girl's dialouge is really really annoying and adds almost nothing to the story, especially when she keeps telling you the same lines over and over again. Honestly, this game was vastly diappointing and I very much regret buying it.The really sad thing, though, is not my wasted money but wasted potential. This game could have been SO much better, but as I've said, it wasn't very good at all.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												'Contrast' has you phasing in and out of shadows to complete puzzles, whilst following a little girl who is trying to fix her parent's troubled lives.Phasing in and out of shadows is a nice concept, but here it's poorly executed. I felt I was fighting against the controls the whole game. Often I'd complete a puzzle unsure of whether I'd done so legitimately, or by glitchi-jumping throgh an obstacle. Other times, puzzle solutions were obvious - but had to be repeated several times because the shadow phasing is so tempremental. It's also occasionally unclear what the objectives are until you stumble upon them.The art direction is good, the voice acting is great. The plot was somewhat dragged out, but enough to hold my interest. There was clearly vision here. It's a real shame most of the play time is spent beating your head against unpolished controls.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												I'm glad I didn't buy it at its full price, because even though there IS GOOD in it, the good is not enough to justify the cost.The concept is stunning, great atmosphere, the soundrack makes me wanna drink tea while smoking my pipe wearing an early 20's nightgown and the shadow/real world switching is such a cool idea. Also, I'm in love with Dawn even thought not much is said about her. BUT (and here comes the ugly part) how could they develop her character when they couldn't even properly tell the whole game story? Let me be clear: the story has a beginning and an ending (which I adore because I hate when they leave you puzzled) but it's told in such a rush you won't really find yourself connected with anyone. This game is short (or better: it would be but as I'm gonna explain next, it will gain longevity thanks to all the times you're gonna uncontrollably fail).There is something really wrong with the controls, I played with a controller and Dawn's movements were very uncomfortable. I tried using mouse and keyboard and it was kinda better but still, weird physics. It's not very reactive and considering you have to jump a lot and switch while rushing and jumping, that's a big no no for me. It got on my nerves, I fell so many times and had to run back and forth so much that I almost threw away the controller.Gotta be honest, I insulted Dawn so much that if she were real, she would have come find me and punch me.
