content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												After beating the game, I can say that I don't find the game fun. Sure, the visuals are beautiful and the music is good. The morphing into shadows is a cool game mechanic  however too many times in the game is it easy to slip out of the shadows or something will knock you off. Sometimes jumping on to platform becomes tedious work, you end up concentrating on to getting on to one platform so much it takes away from the beauty of the game and its concept. I find myself fustrated  more often then not, and when I'm not I am a little bored. Plus after a while I did get annoyed that the child was consistently bossing me around. SPOILERS DOWN BELOWAs for the story, it's hardly there. So you're Dawn (the tall shadow girl) who is the companion of Didi (little girl) for whatever reason Didi and you are friends, or at least Dawn feels a sense of responsiblity towards Didi for unknown reasons. You sneak out at night to see her mother perform in Act 1. In Act II, it concentrates on helping Didi's father figure because its clear he owes the mob money and he is using a broken cicrus to get money to pay them back. Then in Act III, Didi's biological father is performing at the circus and Didi ends up following him to his workshop in hopes for some connection. Then in the final act you have to turn on the lighthouse to light up the stage where the biological father is performing. Then in the ending there's this big happy dysfunctional family scene where mother takes father figure back meanwhile biological father offers Didi a chance for them to connect too as family. Keep in mind through out the whole game Didi and Dawn are the only 3d people everyone else is a shadow on the wall. The biological dad morphs into a real person and places his hand on Didi's shoulder, she gasps exclaiming she thought Dawn was the only one capable of that. The last scene is the biological father thanking you (Dawn) for taking care of Didi.Prior to this point if you were looking through the collectables, its set up to make you think Didi is mentally ill and that we are playing as some imaginary friend or demon/fairy. So its an interesting twist because it does change your perspective on what the story is. Because we are never really given the whole story most of it is for the player to piece together and make decisions. And in the end, you don't know who Dawn is as a character, or whiy she has a relationship with Didi, you don't know why the biological father can morph in and out of shadows or while he knows Dawn, the question of why is everyone a shadow expect for Did is never really answered.There is one collectable that is a old time picture of Didi being a shadow on a street of real people, which could suggest she's the true shadow person but then it goes into hay wire with what occurs in the game.If you still want to play after reading this be my guest, I just feel that the take away from the game wasn't impactful enough to make my eariler fustrations worth the trouble.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I was very disappointed with this game. I wouldn't say it's bad, but pretty much everything felt underwhelming or out of place. You would think that in a puzzle platformer the platforming would be really fleshed out and feel good, but in reality it's super clunky. Even the 2d bits once you enter the shadows feel bad and bugy. The dashing ability makes no sense. Why would the players character be able to do that. Maybe if it was just for platforming and mobility, but you are braking fences with that ability. It's just silly. Same goes for the players ability to carry big boxes like they are made of cardboard. As game mechanics they are fine, but they don't feel right in the games world.Considering the length of the game I think it could have benefited form just flushing out the basic platforming and shadow stuff and leaving out all the other tiny mechanics. In my mind having a solid platformer with a shadow gimmick would be much better,  than a clunky platformer with a bunch of flimsy mechanics that are used only handful of moments in the game. Moving objects to manipulate shadows was very interesting, but again, it was used only two times in the game and wasn't all that sophisticated. It would be so cool if the game had a bigger emphasis on this aspect. The story is nothing special either. It's very simplistic. I really didn't care about it. It was frustrating that the mystery of why only the players character and Didi have physical bodies is addressed only at the very end of the game. The only positive aspect of the game is its aesthetic. The Art Deco/cabaret stile is relay cool. And some of the level design visually is very interesting. Though I was a bit disappointed that in a game about shadows the shadows them selves ware a bit ugly at places. In conclusion - get it on sale if the screenshots look really tempting to you, but stay away if you want super tight gameplay.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												A game built around a couple good ideas--setting, shadow mechanics--and not much else.The gameplay the entire scenario is built upon can, more than anything else, be described as simply glitchy. It bugs out constantly, leading to unfair deaths or do-overs. Some puzzles, like Vincenzo's workshop, are absolutely agonizing because of this.The setting is nothing more than an idea: Cabaret. That's it. Nothing more.The developers seemed to have desperately built everything in this game on those two ideas, turning them into nothing more than gimmicks. The story is nonsense--a mash-up of heart-felt cliches and sexist family drama the player will not care about, with random (--wrong--) references to Einstein and generic ideas of science floating in the background. I guess it's meant to add depth to the universe they're creating, but it doesn't help when a handful of the world-building collectables are called nothing more than "Science Drawing" and are literally just nonsense symbols and images.The story also just gets in the way: I can't count the number of times I'd move a few feet and have control taken away from me, so the camera can do a stilted, early PS2-era swoop over the surroundings, complete with lots of janky start-stop moments. Speaking of, the controls--movement and camera--also feel like the platformers (e.g., MDK 2) of the early '00s.Whatever. Everything wrong with this game comes from its creation. It's clear the general ideas of the shadow mechanic and gimmicky cabaret setting were steps 1-10, and everything else was an afterthought.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
PLAY Contrast? MAYBE. The world, characters, and story may intrigue you, but game mechanics drove me nuts.Pros+Unique, and smooth art style+Jazzy, 1920s art direction+Adorable (though, somewhat too talkative) child main character+Good Soundtrack+References to games and movies+Adult "Inside" jokes+2560x1080 Resolution Option (Fits Ultra-Wide Monitors) fineMids=Unique shadow platforming mechanic that becomes fustrating=Potentially interesting storyCons-Parts of level gemotry where you can get stuck-Major crashes-Terrible Checkpoint system that eventually made me stop playingOverviewContrast appears to be a fairly cute story about a daughter born out of wedlock that can speak with a potentially imaginary acrobat, controled by the player that can phase out of reality and into the shadows to platform across the world. There is something else going on in the world than just convienent lighting, as other humans are invisible except for their shadows, only Dororthy can recognize the acrobat and their are strange anomalies in the world, such as a giant chasm of space seperating a road to a town cinema. Unfortunately, I didn't get far enough to see the end as I grew fustrated with the gameplay - so I will probably watch a playthrough. Thankfully, this game is nowhere near as pretentious as Papo y Yo.FrustrationsThis is a floaty platformer, much like Trine or Limbo, though there were many times I either missed jumps or fell during platforming because the "Rush" move didn't work or over shot my jump. The game gives an impression of a simple indie platformer, and for the most part it is, but there were so many instant-death moments in the game that wore thin after the 20th time. I got to a point where I had to save "Fred the Knight" in a "shadow story telling" sequence and the game straight up crashed when the dragon's fire hit Fred. I'm not sure if it was supposed to Kill Fred or activate some sequence or cutscene, but the game immediately locked up my PC for a solid 15 seconds (I was sure to need a Hard reboot soon), then Windows came back up and shown that I was disconnected from Steam. Again, I don't know if that disconnect triggered some sort of glitch (maybe it was about to register an achievement, but I was offline and the game crashed),  but thanks to the irritating checkpoint system, the game took me back to the start of the level, requiring me to walk all the way back to the area and replay the entire sequence again. Mind you, there were two other story telling sequences I had to complete before then. Plus, earlier in the game, I got stuck in level geometry and had to restart from my last save. To my surprise, it damn near restarted the whole level and lost all my progress in the part of the circus that I was trying to repair. The death at the dragon was the final straw for me and I lost all interest in playing this. ConclusionI'm sure other, less demanding gamers can get enjoyment out of this, and honestly, I want to see more of the story, so I will watch the remainder on Youtube. Unless you absolutely adore what is going on here, I suggest you do the same. Value your time and money. I bought this on a deep discount for $3.74, but I could have done without doing so.

												Contrast this is a game platform and puzzles with Noir ambiance. Developed by Compulsion Games and distributed by Focus Home Interactive. This being launched November 15, 2013.The protagonist in the game is called Didi and control her friend Dawn imagine. Maybe count it sounds strange, but although we control another character is that Didi has its story developed throughout the plot.The gameplay takes place across the various puzzles using the special power of his character, through the shadows. Manipulating some objects or even following the right time some shade.In the course there are some collectible items which are varied and the only thing that sets the brightness is involving them, these same collectibles can help better develop the story. There are also lamps which must be found to continue the gameplay in certain parts.Things that caught my attention in particular:- The story can exercise certain weight on the player.- The songs are a special touch, especially those that are accompanied vocally by Laura Ellis, other songs are only instrumental. It is two: Kat's Song and House On Fire.This is a relatively short play, about 3 to 4 hours and may complete the game. His story though short, is really interesting and even shocking addressing family problems. Although I think the game is worth, I must stress that faced many bugs that can yes frustrate me. Things like invisible floor and ghosts areas (appears to be ground, but when he stepped on the character falls and dies) are constant throughout the game, jumping on objects that should not also happen. There are parts in the game that can move forward without following the right goal, not by decision of the player, but recurring errors in the game. Some falls are the checkpoint out of place, even if the fall occurred in the same place, and there times when the game crashed and advanced parts that I had not explored (mainly mean the theatrical part). Finally, there is another bug which I believe to be the most frustrating, I think not received certain achievements in the game even after going through the areas indicated. Finally, despite everything bad that happens can not say I did not like the course of the game, but unfortunately so many problems so make me give negative.Not to be unfair, if not call the various problems you may face, a chance to play and if too frustrating use the refund.For similar Steamified Reviews and Giveaways, please visit  steamified [steamified.com]. Also you're welcome to join in the fun in our Steamified group.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												To put it simply, Contrast is a game that follows a little girl through her beautiful, broken world.In Contrast we take on the role of Dawn, the imaginary friend of the character Didi- we go on an adventure with this little girl who is trying ever so hard to just put her family back together.Contrast features a wonderful Jazz soundtrack that really brings a lot to the game as a whole. The voice acting is full of emotions in both the English and French translations of the game. The voice acting is well recorded and well cut. 5/5The visuals in Contrast are some of the best to come out of Greenlight. This near unique art style really gives the game some flavor. Contrast has top quality visuals both in it's 3D, and 2D worlds. I have yet to encounter fuzzy or broken models/textures. 5/5The story is brilliant and the execution is just as wonderful. Though many complain that the story is "too short" we need to remember that length does not dictate the quality of the story. Contrast's story is about bringing a broken family back together. The story has all elements of a story, a great intro, tense climax, and an interesting conclusion. Watching the world change as the story progresses is simply fantastic. 4.5/5Mechanically, Contrast has a few issues- though the game does contain a brilliant feature where the character has to work through both 2D and 3D worlds, this proves to cause some of the major problems in the game. In the shadow(2D) world, the gameplay is relatively choppy- whether the character will execute commands correctly in this state is hit or miss. We can regularly see the character pop out of the shadow world for no apparent reason what so ever. This is not game breaking, but does cause some frustration when attempting more complex or multi-step puzzles. 3.5/5I believe that this game could also use some optimization with the keyboard/mouse. For me, it was a little tasking making the settings work with my hardware. This has no impact on the final rating.Final rating – 18/20 or 90%   - I would suggest getting this game.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The game's title perfectly encapsulates my play experience, which alternated between delight and frustration. The story follows a young girl named Didi, and so do we. We step into the shoes of a mysterious young woman called Dawn, who assists Didi on her quest to mend her broken home. The story is generally well executed and the art style and music help sell it beautifully. Steeped in early 20th century vaudeville aesthetics, the game's mood is warm and magical, but the over-the-top theatricality often seeps into the dialogue, at times causing it to come of as trite rather than impactful.The main conceit of the game is that Dawn exists in a sort of parallel world, and her only connection to the real world are Didi, who seems to exists in both worlds, and the shadows. Dawn has the ability to literally become a shadow on the wall, and most of the gameplay revolves around using this mechanic to solve puzzles and execute jumping challenges. Shadows are also the only way in which Dawn can see people besides Didi, and the game's most inspired moments combine moments of shadow-puppet storytelling with actual gameplay. Unfortunately, these moments are far and few between, and most of the challenges are fairly mediocre, with the shadow-shift mechanic adding little but a bit of flavor. My biggest disappointment is how often the game interrupts the flow of gameplay with little cutscenes, sometimes wresting away control of your character simply to execute a camera pan and deliver a line from Didi.The game shows great potential, but falls short in execution. Aside from the issues already discussed, there are the occasional technical issues, such as graphical glitches, erratic collision detection and at times wonky controls. A more rigorous synthesis of gameplay and storytelling could have elevated this game out of its mediocrity. However, its charming style and rare moments of inspiration make it worth a look should you find it for cheap (e.g. during on of Steam's many sales).

												I was excited about Contrast. When I finally got it during the summer sale, I was happy. I played through it, and I can't remember the last time I was this disappointed. I didn't like how Dawn moved around in 3D mode. It was hard to control her I felt. She almost moved too fluidly. I also didn't care for the story. It was just...strange. Also, this game is way too short! I finished in about 3 hours, but it really felt shorter than that. All of a sudden it was over.Despite all it's negatives, Contrast does have positives. I loved the transitions from 3D to 2D and vice versa. It is done so smoothly, and the platforming was very innovative I thought. I also loved that Didi was the only person besides Dawn in the world. Everyone else appears as shadows. The music and setting are cool as well. Dawn doesn't speak, but Didi does and I found her character kind of annoying. Also, Didi's father is Adam Jensen. I found that distracting. Buy this game if you can find a good sale.Also, no jump scares.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												This is one of the most well-imagined games I have ever played. The art style, the concept, the characters, the storyline, the soundtrack; everything is phenomenal. I was drawn in instantly. Unfortunately, I found it a bit difficult to stay immersed at times. The gameplay is quite buggy. I'll admit, it has gotten better than it was the month after release, but I still feel like it could be better. Interacting with items is difficult to initiate and rather imprecise once you do, making some puzzles a bit more difficult, not to mention frustrating, than they otherwise would be. Another minorly infuriating aspect was the save system. You cannot manually save. The game saves automatically after solving certain puzzles or reaching a crucial plot point. The problem is, you never know which puzzles it saves after unless you're paying close attention to the corner of your screen. I was so fed up with having to do certain parts over that I abandoned the game for weeks at a time several times. All of that being said, I still truly enjoyed the game. The positives definitely outweigh the minor glitches and I am recommending this game to everyone. And who knows, they may fix the save system and wonky item interaction at a later point.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Overall Score: 8/10My advice: If you like a good puzzle/story driven game, buy it.Genre: Third person puzzle platformerContrast is a short, sweet, stylized adventure with an intriguing story and a fascinating concept. It only took me about 6 hours to finish the game with all achievements, so don't come looking for an exceptionally long playthrough. The story it tells is worth experiencing nonetheless. The story follows a little girl named Didi and her mysteriously invisible friend Dawn, who you play. The girl's mother is a singer at one of the local clubs, giving Didi a chance to sneak out at night and try to learn more about her father, her family, and ultimately, the origin of Dawn. As Dawn, you have the special ability to enter the walls around you, walking atop shadows to help Didi during her strange and dream-like adventure.As you can imagine, there are quite a few puzzles to keep you occupied, but not as many as I would have liked with such a fascinating concept. The music is fantastic, as is the stylized atmosphere, but what really ties things together are the story. Almost the entire story is told through the shadows and the things people leave behind, and they still manage to craft an interesting arch for it all. If I had to complain, though, harder puzzles would have really made this game a lot more fun, and the occasional frustrating glitches shaved off a point in my book.Still, for this kind of price tag, it's a crime not to pick it up.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												A great platforming\puzzle game for people that are not into such.If I were to categorize players as follows Type1: Rarely plays video games or sticks to Iphone type of games Type 2: A regular video game player, but not into platformers/puzzles Type 3: A regular video game player and is into platformers/puzzle games and type 4: A diehard fan of platform/puzzle games.I would say that Contrast is for the Type 2 player, which is where I classify myself. The graphics and sound are excellent and the story is interesting, but the challenges are not over the top. I play games other than platform/puzzles, like RPGs, survival, action, shooters, etc, but the look and story of Contrast intrigued me so I got it and finished it (only took 3.5 hours) and it was a great experience. The difficulty was right up my alley and I felt good about resolving the puzzles.The voice acting, sound, music,etc are all excellent. I normally detest games with 'collectibles' and will usually ignore such in games, but in Contrast the collectibles were easy to come across and, towards the end, they really open the story and shed some light (pun!) on the background of the character you are playing, Dawn.Overall I would rate this game pretty high, say 8 out of 10. Especially because it is so short, I can see myself playing it again a few months from now.Edited for typoes.

Posted: April 17, 2014
												This game, like any, certainly has its flaws. However, two of these flaws are grand downfalls to the game. It's puzzles are too easy and the game is too short. I beat it in roughly three hours -- and I am the sort to expore EVERY nook and cranny of a game like this, if that tells you anything. Despite all that, if you can wait until this gets extremely cheap during a sale or something, by all means give it a shot. It's a wonderful experience if noir-inspired art, jazz soundtracks, and creative approaches to puzzle platforming are your thing.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Overall Score: 8/10My advice: If you like a good puzzle/story driven game, buy it.Genre: Third person puzzle platformerContrast is a short, sweet, stylized adventure with an intriguing story and a fascinating concept. It only took me about 6 hours to finish the game with all achievements, so don't come looking for an exceptionally long playthrough. The story it tells is worth experiencing nonetheless. The story follows a little girl named Didi and her mysteriously invisible friend Dawn, who you play. The girl's mother is a singer at one of the local clubs, giving Didi a chance to sneak out at night and try to learn more about her father, her family, and ultimately, the origin of Dawn. As Dawn, you have the special ability to enter the walls around you, walking atop shadows to help Didi during her strange and dream-like adventure.As you can imagine, there are quite a few puzzles to keep you occupied, but not as many as I would have liked with such a fascinating concept. The music is fantastic, as is the stylized atmosphere, but what really ties things together are the story. Almost the entire story is told through the shadows and the things people leave behind, and they still manage to craft an interesting arch for it all. If I had to complain, though, harder puzzles would have really made this game a lot more fun, and the occasional frustrating glitches shaved off a point in my book.Still, for this kind of price tag, it's a crime not to pick it up.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												A great platforming\puzzle game for people that are not into such.If I were to categorize players as follows Type1: Rarely plays video games or sticks to Iphone type of games Type 2: A regular video game player, but not into platformers/puzzles Type 3: A regular video game player and is into platformers/puzzle games and type 4: A diehard fan of platform/puzzle games.I would say that Contrast is for the Type 2 player, which is where I classify myself. The graphics and sound are excellent and the story is interesting, but the challenges are not over the top. I play games other than platform/puzzles, like RPGs, survival, action, shooters, etc, but the look and story of Contrast intrigued me so I got it and finished it (only took 3.5 hours) and it was a great experience. The difficulty was right up my alley and I felt good about resolving the puzzles.The voice acting, sound, music,etc are all excellent. I normally detest games with 'collectibles' and will usually ignore such in games, but in Contrast the collectibles were easy to come across and, towards the end, they really open the story and shed some light (pun!) on the background of the character you are playing, Dawn.Overall I would rate this game pretty high, say 8 out of 10. Especially because it is so short, I can see myself playing it again a few months from now.Edited for typoes.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												I really want to like this game, believe me, I do.I adore the music and the unique art style and the story is interesting, but the gameplay is so infuriatingly difficult at times that it breaks the immersion and makes me not want to play it. The shadow shift ability is very sensitive. If you run into something, or if you're crushed by something, you'll shift out of the walls and you'll have to try again or you just might die altogether. Not only that, but it's very easy to miss jumps when you're trying to jump over certain gaps (most are easy to scale, but there are a few that are just mind boggling). And there are also some puzzles in which you have to reach a platform in a small amount of time - and those kinds of challenges in games are always maddening. I'll play and I'll be mesmerized by the details and I'll want to find out what happens next in the story but then I reach a roadblock of a challenge and - after being pushed out of the walls, failing to jump over gaps and dying repeatedly - I get increasingly frustrated and then it's not about the story or the gameplay anymore, all the focus has shifted to that one piece that just doesn't seem to give if you don't get it just right. And after all is said and done and I can move on, I just can't relax and enjoy the game anymore and have to shut it off. A game is something that you should be able to enjoy and crave, but if it's frustrating - there's no point in trying; and that's a real shame. It's a good game if you're a big fan of challenging puzzles; but if you're looking for a fun game with a sense of ease and flow, you might want to find something else to try.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												TL;DR: Check it out.THE GOOD:• Gameplay:  Contrast is a truly unique concept; I can't think of anything that does something similar: shifting from a 3D environment to a 2D one using the shadows on the wall.  Shadows can sometimes be manipulated by moving light sources.  It's neat!• Story:  The story isn't masterfully told, but it is an interesting one, and I'm glad I stuck around to see it through to the end.• Art:  Contrast is beautiful to admire and its music is always a pleasant companion.• It's Indie!:  Support your local indie game developer!  Especially when they're doing awesome work like this!THE BAD:• Game Feel:  As cool as traversing the shadows as a platformer is, Contrast has a tendency to be real finicky.  On some puzzles, I would get so frustrated falling out of the shadows, I would question if I was performing the task correctly; in every case, I was.  It becomes easy to slip out from the 2D world and fall to your death, and not even be sure why it happened.  I managed to finish every puzzle, but I would have had a lot more fun if the mechanics had been fine-tuned a bit more.• Acting:  The voice acting could've been a little more convincing, but--  Ehh! What'r'ya gonna do?

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Contrast (video game) is a noir atmospheric puzzler set it in the 1920's. You play as Dawn, the imaginary friend to Didi, a 9 year old girl who's step father is trying to put together a circus. Throughout the game, you must help Didi help her father put on a good show.You morph in and out of the 3D world and 2D world of shadows, helping Didi by solving various puzzles. The gameplay was okay, there is a little bit of weirdness with the camera, but it wasn't too bad. It's a lot of parkour but the puzzles were pretty simple. The majority of what makes this game so good are the music, art and it's story. If anything, it's what makes the game worthwhile. Should be a quick and easy finish and will make for a good afternoon session.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Contrast is one hell of a buggy game but what I got out of it was something more. I was frustrated all the time when I played Contrast. I was always stuck in walls, lost in the geometry, and always felt out of control when I played. That being said, all of the bugs felt, necessary. The aesthetics of Contrast matched with the tone of the story and one's loss of innocence felt surreal. Playing as Dawn, who is thought to be Didi's, the girl who follows you on your journey, imaginary friend, the deconstruction of the world in what seemed like a total destruction of reality made sense. By the story's end, I cared about the cast and about Didi, no matter how annoying I saw her. As Dawn, I felt responsible for her sanity, trying to keep her whole in a world that doesn't seem right. Even with confusing puzzles and weird design choices, I had to finish this from beginning to end.Like, this isn't a Gone Home or a Proteus type of game in quality of build, but it felt right because of it. I wouldn't really recommend this game for the full price but this is definitely a game I would recommend on a sale. It isn't a tear jerker but its premise was so thought-provoking and engrossing that I felt like I got hit with a brick by the end of the game.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												A nice concept completely ruined by a poor and rushed development. Not only this game is tremendously short (4 hours to get 100% completion, including replaying a chapter to get a thing I missed!), it's also full of glitches and the so called "secrets" are ridiculously easy to find. Moreover, the plot is undermined by a fragmented exposition which is just too rushed and specious to make sense like it should and ends abruptly leaving little to nothing to the player.There were many good ideas at the base of this title and It's pretty clear that the developers had issues in the making of it, but even considering that and making an effort to appreciate its aesthetics it's nearly impossible to recommend Contrast to anyone. Not even at a sale price.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												As someone who followed the development of Contrast with much anticipation, going as far as preordering it on steam, it pains me to say that the game is not good. What looked like a fascinating premise in a fantasical world intermixed with an amazing sound selection turned out to be only one of those things. Being a shadow becomes very boring very quickly, as the puzzles all end up revolving around a convulted system of controls that will leave you very very frustrasted. You will be afraid to enter walls. You will be afraid of messing up a button press. And you will be very afraid when you realize this puzzle will just continue to drag on with more complicated situations that faulty controls will only make worst. The only puzzle game I can think of right now that followed the same tune as Contrast is Braid, and by Jove does Braid make this game look like a joke. In Braid you can rely on your platforming abilities to carry you through a series of increasing difficult puzzles, which will truly reward the player for their abilities to think intuitively as well as perform proper platforming practices. In Contrast, you will struggle about a world with frustrating controls, little variation in puzzles, and little reward from solving the them. Little reward as in you will not care at all about the story because your willful suspension of disbelief will begin right at the start. The game takes place in France, and it makes a point to say so. What it doesn't explain, unless I understood world history entirely incorrectly, is that the world is floating in a vacuum of space. No explanation ever. No explanation as to why Didi, the girl you are escorting most of the game, sees the pit once but never comments on it again, as well as no one else commenting on it. Hell, in my opinion, the characters stopping to talk about the fact they live in a void would be more interesting than any plot point presented in this game. The story is weak, from the first moment of blackmail to the ending scene. The ending won't make you feel anything. You will be annoyed by Didi. You will hate every character that pops their ugly mug in this game. So what do you have so far? A messy universe with messy controls, a cast of completely unlikable characters, a character that is a young annoying child most of the game (Trust me, Didi is no Clementine, and you will go back to hating video game children after playing this,) in a story that is riddled in plot holes and does nothing to keep you interested in it. Oh, but the music is pretty at parts. I think I heard some of it over my continued groans over having to do another jump dash puzzle that would randomly throw me out of the wall to my death. Do yourself a favor, and skip out on this one.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Some nice ideas and visuals, but there's really not much to it. The game is quite short which is fine, but for a puzzle platformer there are very few actual puzzle/platform sections. And some of these can be more frustrating than fun due to clumsy controls, poor guidance, or just long waits for cut scenes (especially in the shadow puppet/princess part).Although the game world looks quite nice it feels very empty (although maybe this is the point) and you have some freedom to wander around but there is nothing to do or see until you are forced to go to that area later in the game.While not a bad game per se, unless you are looking for a short indie platformer reminiscent of American McGee's Alice with an interesting mechanic poorly executed, I found it to be dull and tedious and you are better looking elsewhere.There are far more enjoyable indie puzzle-platformers out there worth spending your money. See Two Brothers, Deadlight, Trine, Braid, Limbo, Thomas was Alone, etc...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Maybe I'm just too quick to be critical of games, but sometimes you have to be in a world with hundreds of thousands of video games and lots of Triple A titles.For me, Contrast is the type of game that delivers a game mechanic that promises to be innovative and amazing, but fails to really deliver where it matters - namely, being able to use shadows as though they were tangible things. You start off as an unnamed woman walking around in a little girl's bedroom, and it is quickly conveyed that all living creatures (with the exception of one special little girl) appear only as shadows and you are invisible to one-another.Unfortunately, after establishing that you are this little girl's friend (by way of picking up a drawing she made with you in it), that's all the reason you are given to follow her off on a boring adventure of interacting with objects, collecting objects, and being pestered to do things and go places in order to watch cutscenes. It really feels like it's being forced upon me when I don't even want to follow this little stranger and watch her parents fight; I want to explore the world and be given my own reason for doing things instead - not because a child tells me to.So that was storytelling ruined within the first 5 minutes.Then there was the shadow mechanic - it seems cool in theory, but you end up using it to do very rudimentary platforming straight off the bat. Exciting stuff. Maybe throwing a few shadow balls would be nice, or knocking over a bottle, or knocking over a bottle's shadow using a ball's shadow! The first few minutes are where you really have to give OOMPH to this new mechanic, and sadly it's used only to run up shadow ramps (some of which are inaccessible until you have tagged along with your new friend so she can push a simple object for you and progress the story). Again - I'm feeling like this is off to a bad start. I hear the game eventually progresses to pushing boxes around, but manipulating an object to reach a high place is hardly an innovative improvement.And finally there's my last gripe - atmosphere. At one point within the first 5 minutes you also walk into a cabaret restaurant which is completely devoid of people and life. "BUT WAIT," you say, "people are invisible and appear as shadows!" Well yes, this is true, but there is nothing to make this restaurant feel LIVELY. There are glasses of alcohol on tables and cigars smouldering away in ashtrays, and there is ambient audience music playing, but there is nothing to make it feel ALIVE. No swaying and sliding of chairs, no sloshing of alcohol, no strange poltergeist-esque atmosphere replete with drinks trays floating around the room; bartenders shaking tumblers and pouring them out, no cats in alleyways knocking over trashcans and yowling, certain conversations that dim and fall as you wander the room - there is nothing - and that is where this game really falls flat on its face. You walk into a dead room and your only objective is to interact with the flashing objects scattered around the room so you can progress the plot because an invisible woman keeps nagging you to turn on the lights.I'm sorry, I wanted to like this game, but it took 5 minutes to convince me that I hated it - all because there was nothing to try and persuade me into staying a while, looking around and really enjoying myself.Maybe somebody somewhere else will do it better one day - because this game isn't there by a long shot.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												The gameplay should have been kept in "2D" (wrapping around the walls, but 2D control wise). Instead, it tries to keep you in 3D (without the shadow puppet stuff) most of the time.The intriguing part of the game, using the shadows to move around, seemed like a lot of fun. Unfortunately, the main part of the gameplay seems to consist of moving lights or boxes to create those shadows where you want (without much in the way of real solving). The actual platforming across them, is only difficult by it being nearly broken. A lot of the time, I wasn't sure if I had glitched my way through, or solved the "puzzle". Really, the only puzzle is that you have to place the box so that it's shadow forms a super easy platform jump. This is made harder because the "targetting" system makes it hard to actual lock onto the object you want to carry. When there is any actual puzzle that isn't an immediate solve, it's only really difficult because of the trial and error of moving the light as well as shadow generators. But there isn't really any lateral thinking about it, just move a few things around.The platforming, as a I mentioned is nearly trivial, made difficult only by the 3D controls being near broken, and the 2D having awkward physics (made worse by the fact that modern analog controls don't adapt well to it).When not in the shadows (which is most of the game) it is all the broken camera and awkward controls (made worse when the camera suddenly changes the perspective forcing a control direction correction) of poor late 90's platformers. You are always wasting time either because the controls messed you up and you need to recover, or because you need to keep running back to the objects to manipulate into position yet again. It is a shame, because the moments when you are using shadows made by things other than your own dragging boxes around (such as a sequence early on where characters are having an animated conversation, movbing their limbs all over the place), it is a hell of a lot of fun. If the game had been entirely this, moving from shadow to shadow as the scene plays out around you, I would have really enjoyed it.

This game needs some DLC missions or some other expansion. It's too clever and beautiful to leave things as they are.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												A nice concept completely ruined by a poor and rushed development. Not only this game is tremendously short (4 hours to get 100% completion, including replaying a chapter to get a thing I missed!), it's also full of glitches and the so called "secrets" are ridiculously easy to find. Moreover, the plot is undermined by a fragmented exposition which is just too rushed and specious to make sense like it should and ends abruptly leaving little to nothing to the player.There were many good ideas at the base of this title and It's pretty clear that the developers had issues in the making of it, but even considering that and making an effort to appreciate its aesthetics it's nearly impossible to recommend Contrast to anyone. Not even at a sale price.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												This is the second worst kind of indie game.The worst kind being cheap ripoffs of whatever's popular right now (see: zombies, survival, crafting).This however is an overly artsy fartsy platformer with one single original idea - which cannot carry a game by itself.In the first hour or act you gain no understanding of your agency or place in the world and you begin to realize that you never will. The game just is way too much in love with its imaginary-friend-perspective of storytelling.And what do you do? Follow a linear corridor of boring puzzles. Yes the shadow walking gimmik makes them orignal, but the shallow world, fixed camera (starting in act2!), and dodgy controls really remove all joy that might have been had here.Oh and the "Soundtrack" are 15 tracks that amount to 20 minutes of samey music - and it's not even in FLAC format.Not even worth 5 bucks.

I'm just diappointed.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I have mixed feelings about this game.  While the concept is quite intriguing and I've never played another game like it, the shadow mechanics are rather sloppy and it's very short, taking place over 3 hour-long acts give or take depending on how fast you solve the puzzles.The game's main mechanic allows your character to become a shadow on any wall where bright light is projected.  In this form, other shadows become your platforms and obstacles and you have to manipulate and navigate them in order to solve puzzles.  It's a very cool concept for unfortunately not implemented all that well.  I found myself frequently popping out of shadow mode because I'd touched a small feature on the wall even though that didn't interrupt the shadows I was walking on and occasionally without any noticable cause.  Traversing moving shadows can be a bit problematic as well.The game looks pretty good and runs well, utilizing the popular Unreal engine.  The writing and voice acting are surprisingly high quality and tell the story well, accompanied by collectible items which you really need to take a look at to get the whole story.  Luckily most of them are in plain sight.The real disappointment of the game is its length.  I finished the game in one sitting and I want more, hopefully with fewer glitches in shadow mode.  I want it to be a full length game like Portal 2 with more difficult puzzles and more game mechanics.  Here's hoping for Contrast 2.While the game has its problems, I quite enjoyed it and am recommending it to others.  Just don't go into it expecting a difficult or lengthy game.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												The word "contrast" is quite distinct, when I hear the word I imagine spectacular colour palettes of vividly juxtaposed hues and shades. Unfortunately, the type of Contrast presented here appears to have rewritten the definition to fit its drab and dreary canvas. As if someone took the worst parts of the Psychonauts and completely desaturated the visuals, turning bleak a very uniquely bright and eclectic art style.Contrast is filled with wasted potential and, from the get go, riddled with visual and mechanical glitches. The shadow mechanics are often inconsistent and ham-fisted, causing many a sigh of frustration. If I fail to react accordingly I will often be forced to sit through the same piece of dialogue, waiting for that small window of opportunity to open, only to be forced out of the shadows because I gently touched the wrong thing at the wrong time. I feel my character is too large and agile for such a small set piece, it becomes quite claustrophobic at times.My main issue isn't the poorly implemented mechanics, but the lack of care I have for the characters within the story and the absence of any exposition that isn't told through the numerous collectibles found in the game. Thankfully Contrast is a very short game as it starts to overstay its welcome by the middle of the second chapter. How many puzzles must be solved by standing on the head of a person's shadow? I'd lost count.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												If you are into Jazz, Contrast is worth playing just for the sake of the soundtrack.If the premise of a bluesy, gloomy, artsy, early 1900's Paris atmosphere - which this game reflects brilliantly - doesn't particularly appeal to you, you might want to think twice.Contrast's gameplay is entirely based around blending 2D and 3D, a good idea; fits well with the semi-magical atmosphere, but unfortunately doesn't feel like it's been used to the full potential. The biggest challenges lie in the 2D platformers, whilst the 3D part feels underexploited (and the keyboard controls clunky - this was clearly designed for a controller). The 3D world just serves as an aid to model the 2D world, or as a link to reach the next 2D surface. At some moments, you feel like it's almost there and regret what the game could have become if the 2D and 3D had been made to blend in a bit more crazily.Some of the puzzles are brilliant, some of them just about mediocre, but it all ends too soon. The game is extremely short (only 3 levels, count about an hour each). WIth no extra difficulty or challenge, with all collectible lying out in plain sight of the linear path, the replay value relies on just one thing: the really compelling atmosphere, characters, and the excellent voice acting.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												So this game turned out to be quite enjoyable even though it is unfortunately very short. You play Dawn a woman with the power   to shift from the 3D world into the 2D shadow world. Also Dawn can only be seen by her young friend Didi who also happens to be the only person Dawn can see as everyone else can only be seen as a shadow. The game is a pretty decent puzzle platformer, with a mix of 3D platforming and 2D when you shift into the shadows. This mechanic makes for some good puzzle sections as you need to shift in and out of the shadows to complete them. The visual style of the game is great as well with a sort of 30's noir vibe to the world Dawn and Didi inhabit, as well as a decent soundtrack to match.The biggest problem with this game is it's criminally short. I was left wanting more at the end and it really lets the game down.The Good:- intersting mechanic of shifting from 3d to 2d to complete puzzles- this game looks pretty good with a 30's Paris look to it-a good jazzy soundtrack that really adds to the feel of the game.The Bad:- Very short and i was left wanting more-Little replay value Overall this is a pretty good game which i enjoyed but it really is too short to justify paying full price. If it's reduced on offer and you like puzzle platformer pick it up. 6.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												I would have to say Contrast is one of my favorite games. The art style, music and time setting are right up my street and the whole game takes place in a slightly surreal 'Alice In Wonderland' style. I'll explain. The world seems to be made of of floating islands floating in a night sky, it looks lovely but detracts the game from normality, that being said playing as an imaginary friend who can jump in and out of shadows ins't exactly normal so this floating island surreal-ness actually adds to the game, pushing it away from normal and closer to dream-like. As I have said the music is also fantastic if you enjoy cabaret style music. There are also some lovely other tracks later in the game, one of my favorite plays during the carousel puzzle. The whole jumping between shadows and normal world is an awesome mechanic. Not exactly new but it is still nicely done and it creates some interesting and genuinely challenging puzzles that stumped me for an embarissingly long time. One thing I will say is that it can be a bit trickey at times. The switching between the shadow and real worlds is tricky especially when jumping. If you don't time it right when jumping you will land half above, half in the shadow which gives you another 50/50 chance of clipping onto the shadow or being forced back into the real world which will probably spawn you into a death pit. After 6 or more times this gets annoying. The run animation is also odd too and the main character moves like she has a rocket attached to her back and strides like the Striders from Half Life 2.Aside from those 2 tiny nit picks the story is good, visuals great and soundtrack fantastic. Pick it up, play it and you'll be glad you did.Check out my youtbe channel for lets plays and commentary every Monday and Fridayhttp://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2l1zwMcpJm_hJq4owO3nHg

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Contrast is the differences seen when two sources of light come together. Similarly, Contrast (the game) blends its ligher and darker tones into a short, immersive experience with differences of quality that feel worthy of the price of admission, yet lacking in other ways. If anything is holding Contrast back from feeling complete, it's not just the gameplay itself but also the technical issues and the final act. This game will ultimately feel like it was two-thirds of the way done but never half-baked. Dancing in the DarkContrast is by no means a difficult game. Your average playthrough, depending on how many collectibles you go for, will take you somewhere from two to four hours.(I would strongly recommend going for the luminaries as they use the shadow-swapping mechanic a lot, which is the main attraction for this game.) Games like these with a narrative focus are fine. Sometimes games with little to no challenge other than my wits are relaxing, which this game never struck me as being overly complicated.However, the inclusion of replay value would have been appreciated as well besides tying up the loose ends of the plot.In Contrast, you play as an imaginary friend of the main character of the story, Didi. As you are a make-believe creation of hers, you are a surreal character to the mature events unfolding around you. This also means you are given supernatural abilities: The ability to swap in and out of shadows and the real world, the acrobatic fitness to traverse the environments, and a few other abilities (a dash mechanic and  the ability to use light orbs). The main focus is always put on the shadow-swap mechanic, which I think is its best quality. You aren't simply finding the well-lit areas to enter and leave new entrances. You are moving light-sources to shape the shadows on the environment, enlargening them and scaling them down, and you sometimes have to use the shadows' terrain to move real objects. Sometimes the technical limitations rear themselves into this mechanic, such as when you are going around corners and you might teleport out of the wall because of not rotating the camera. Or when you enter a wall with the camera on the other side of the wall. For the most part, this mechanic is well-thoughout and only at some parts of the game feels buggy. Unfortunately, the other gameplay aspects either feeled tacked on simply because other platformers have them or they are there because of the game's light/dark theme.The acrobatics shown on the first trailer on Steam are nowhere to be found in this game. (I watched it after I finished the game, and I felt that was worth mentioning because of how misleading they were.) I think the game could have benefited from more twitchy swapping sections lacking in the final game without making the game have a sudden difficulty spike. It would've also made the open-areas more expansive and well-worth finding the collectibles.The luminaries only feel necessary when the plot demands it, and there are more than enough within the area you are locked in to never worry about finding any more. In the end, I felt these were pointless other than for achievement purposes. The Shadows on the Walls Tell AllThe one thing Contrast nails almost flawlessly is its narrative format told through gameplay. Although the game deviated from what my inital expectations were--of a subconscious friend being there to aid the protagonist--I still appreciate the manner of the story told that is not too dark for kids and not too forced for adults.Do not write this game off as another tale of the loss of innocence. That's not what the game is about; it's about seeing the adult world through a child's eyes with an imaginary friend. The adult themes of vice, regrets, misfortunes and personal mistakes make the world intimidating while hiding away the faces and other details that would make things more clear.Characters other than Didi and Dawn are represented by silohouettes with distinctive voices and models. The side-cast are executed well, and the implementation of their cutscenes as platforming "puzzles" is an interesting way to keep the pace of a game going. This is a case where a limitation on the budget ultimately proved to be a great outlet for storytelling purposes, and it doesn't stand out with the rest of the game.Sadly, the one character you will be hearing a lot of is not the best actor, Didi. Dawn never speaks, and Didi will give you instructions on what to do and where to go at every point in the game.Didi is not the only obstruction from the otherwise fun, creative gameplay. Forced cutscenes showing key-parts of the room are triggered way too much to let the player figure out the puzzle, and the constant text-prompts for objectives are not necessary either. Both of these take the player out of the experience and they are not necessary. You won't get lost as the game is very linear and the areas are never that big.The story is split between three acts. Act 1 and 2 go hand-in-hand in terms of the game's simple, yet clever difficulty as well as the narrative tying in together. Act 3, however, intrudes upon an otherwise surreal story with realistic explainations and a twist ending that ends abruptly for no good reason other than to end the story there. The twist and darker elements within Act 3 are not a problem because they don't make sense. In fact, like with The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, they might make too much sense for my liking.My problem is how they feel ultimately rushed into the game to give it a deeper meaning, and once I reached that point of the game I knew my early expectations were wrong. (It's a shame because I think having the PLAYER be an imaginary friend is the perfect explanation for a video-game.)The devs stated they wanted to keep the ending short and brief to leave the game open-ended. While I am fine with games that have ambigious endings on purpose, like LISA, I don't think Contrast left an ending satisfying enough for the player to be left thinking about.Except for what might have been in the story instead.A Flawed, But Ultimately Charming GameI wouldn't recommend Contrast for full-asking price as there is not enough content to warrant it (nor replay value). Nor is the game as finely polished to be liked by everyone. But Contrast is still a good game, which sees through with its ideas giving all its got while being in the spotlight. It's a game that won't make you cry in the end because of the emotional attachment you experience; it's a game that will make you cry because you don't want the curtain-call to be over so soon.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Contrast is a highly ambitious game which just falls short of being amazing. The gameplay is unique and interesting given that the game allows you traverse between the real realm and the shadow realm which greatly changes how the player would interact within the world compared to a game which is just in the third dimension or just in the second dimension. While the puzzles are integrated nicely within the world you are placed in, the game is rather short taking me just under four hours to complete the entire game.The aesthetics and charm of this game brings back the feeling of a platformer back from the Playstation One era, however the game often has issues explaining the story and world to the player which is mainly due to the game being so short. However if the player is keen on collectable hunting, collecting as many as possible can give some very interesting and subtle insight onto details the story does not wish to make obvious.The voice acting feels stiff sometimes and often repeats itself, more often than not having the child explain to you where to go despite you already knowing where you have to go. However the voice actors in themselves are believable and well done, each reflecting the character nicely.Despite being a short game, 15USD is not a steep asking price for what this game offers if you are looking into a unique platformer. That being said, I would recommend waiting until a sale since 15USD can buy games with a lot more gameplay.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												For those of you who enjoy inventive platforms, or dynamic interestings story lines I highly recommend this game.Contrast brings to the table inventive gameplay with well crafted characters. As the story develops your emotions run with it a bit, and it makes it that much more fun and interesting.The collectibles bring extra elements to the story you wouldn't have known otherwise, so even if there wasn't achievements for finding them, they tie into this story extremely well and answer questions you wouldn't have even thought to ask. In fact, in Act III my mind was basically blown because the ending wouldn't have made any sense if I hadn't found every collectible, and after the first collectible, I wanted to know more so I made sure I grabbed every single one before the end of the last Act.The ending makes you want more! I won't tell you any of it, but I personally was blown away and left awaiting a sequel.But for those who worry about how the game handles, Its controller compatible and easy to pick up, and for those dedicated to the key board and mouse it can't be very hard to manage. It ran smooth and I didn't have to change any settings for it to work and faster. I was very satisfied in that regardThis group does an amazing job, I not lay in wait for a sequel, but for their other projects as well. I can't wait to see what other inventive ideas come next.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Pro: distinct look, sane controller layout, puzzle game without fights, charming story, good flow, quite enjoyableCon: Fixed (and questionable) keyboard layout, no proper saving, no choice of character/avatar (liked the one you get though)In a nutshell: Casual game I replayed pretty much immediately after finishing the first time around. Would buy a second part.The details: Contrast has the good taste to let you think its riddles through, without pushing fight or flight at you while you're working it out. The puzzles of course for the most part aren't too hard, so the game develops a nice flow, all the while looking distinct and neat -- rare enough for a game that will also please the casual player. (In fact if you're stuck, you've probably either overthought things, or run into a bug. The latter are rare, but in the last act, I twice had to restart from a savepoint when vital items became impossible to interact with (one got stuck for no apparent reason, the other became intangible). Given that savepoints can be a good while apart, this is a bit annoying. (There is never a good reason not to have "saving any time, as many times as you like".)The story starts off as inoffensive -- somewhat basic, but not bad, and not getting in the way of the game's flow --, and gains charm with some minor twists as it goes along. Very "children's book", in a good way. (I'm not quite sure what earned the game the "sexual themes" label, by the way.)Act I and the endgame are the strongest parts of the game; Act II has (amongst other bits) a fairy tale segment that tells a nice enough story, but outlives its welcome -- rather than capitalize on Contrast's strengths, that segment looks a good deal like Limbo, and incorporates that game's trial-and-die gameplay. The actual tale told is amusing enough, but a bit repetitive. Less would've been more.Act III would have been fair enough, although the rare bug soured the experience a bit; there are also two moments where the game should've been more forgiving, or the controls more precise. I'm also still not sure why sometimes when I seem to do the exact same things, Dawn suddenly unshifts, while at other times she doesn't. Is it a bug? Is it an intended feature of the game world that wasn't properly communicated? All I know is it's frustrating -- and fortunately somewhat rare.The verdict:The game isn't too long (which I tend to consider a feature) and can be finished in a session or two (but "an act a day" might be best). Due to the short length, the verdict is,Ignore if you think you'd hate it;buy when it drops below 10,- if you think you might love it;buy if it drops below 5,- if unsure. ;)

Posted: September 10, 2016
												Its a hard decision of whether this is a good or bad game. It reminds me of Tom Clancy's The Division: it's incredibly mediocre. The game's mechanics look great and it seems to not take a lot to run, but I personaly have an entry level PC and had to turn the graphics settings down to low despite the characters already looking low rez. I like the art style and the story, but even that seems to be really choppy. A little more effort could've gone into the game, but instead it chose to try to copy the feel of A Story About My Uncle. In the beginning I had a lot of fun with it but towards the beginning of act two it felt like it was droning on. In my oppinion, this game could be summed up by the fact that it's a forgotten PS4 launch title, but I can see how some people like the game. Personal Rating: 6.5/10 Overall Rating: 7.5/10

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												An interesting concept with promise, that sells itself short. The light puzzles are interesting and for the most part straight forward. The storyline is entertaining with a few nice hooks but also fairly straight forward. The art style is a unique with an abstract 20s themed world. The soundtrack including voice acting is very good. The game lacks some final polish to the controls, interactions with the environment and can suffers from occasional random frame drops reducing game immersion, which leave it as only a good - very good game/interactive story. This is a shame because the game had potential to be amazing. Worth picking up, even though you can finish the game in 2-4 hours. The developers show great potential, I look forward to their future projects (just remember that final polish to your game makes a world of difference)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Ok, so. This game is what I would  call a good "sophomore effort", in that it has some really good potentials: the character Didi is a likable enough character (though Dawn seems standoffish and unfriendly, especially for an avatar, and her raison d'etre is critically neglected), the concept of shadow-running is promising, and the set pieces are generally very good. The songs of the soundtrack, when there is any soundtrack, are very nice period pieces (1920's), much like LA Noire uses to establish atmosphere. In fact, a resemblence to LA Noire is strong from the title screen (though it ends there).  The use of shadows is very creative, and watching all of the family drama (I'm not entirely a fan of the non-existence of real people, just their shadows, though I admit it's a good concept) while they also pose the platforms you navigate is well done. Despite its promising start, it requires a considerable more polish before I'd call it great. The action and movement of Dawn, the avatar, is clumsy, sometimes failing to jump into shadows, sometimes not dashing correctly, rather often falling out of the shadow despite your best effort. This is a game requiring dexterous dual-joystick control, one for movement (which was by default absurdly inverted, and required some inner-game config editing to fix) and another for camera, and both need to move to execute the required jumps in places. The character model herself is rather unappealling, in running, turning, and standing. Like Papo y Yo (a game with a similar feel in playing), Contrast feels outdated even while you feel you should be enjoying it more. I suspect is has a lot to do with its use of the Unreal Engine, which (I can't confirm this, not knowing much about programing with the UE) seemed an unfortunately easy shortcut to making the game.  This is a game with such good story, concept, graphics, and voice-acting (for the most part, at least) that its central mechanism really unfortunately spoils it. Not to kick it while it's down, but it could really use some more polish in its foley effects and soundtrack generally, and mappable controls. Further, the puzzles are more tedious than challenging, such that, while you can enjoy the ingenuity of the shadow-running, the task you are given is not otherwise particularly difficult outside of trying to manage the game's physics.    6/10EDIT: Having just finished the game (I was only a little way from it before), Dawn's character is very very subtly explained, in part. But the ending was abrupt and poorly done. Short game, nice story, good atmosphere, bad mechanics.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Set in 1920's Paris; the City of Lights is an ideal location for a shadow based puzzle platformer. Consistantly testing your perspective of lighting and which dimension you should be within. The game adds an interesting 3D world aswell as a constant 2D platformer which you have to vary between in order to complete puzzles. Having the power to slip between the open 3D world to hopping from shadow to shadow in 2D at your own will opens up some very clever puzzling possibilities.Throughout the game there's a gripping emotional story line in which follows the main little girl, Didi. As she is always trying to help out her close-to-useless father, having to deal with various mobsters, aswell as an illusionist puzzle master. As Didi’s imaginary friend, you can only see the shadows and hear the voices of the real people within the 3D world, in which Didi interacts with. But again within the 2D world there is great interaction of the real people's shadows and a fulfilling sense of achievment once you complete a puzzle.As with all medium to low budget puzzle games there are a few bugs/glitches but nothing you can't turn your head at. Some of the puzzels can be very cliche: move a box over a button = door opens. But there was a few interesting ones you'll have to think twice about.Overall gameplay was enjoyable and certainly made you want to finish the game, yet only being 3-5 hours long depending on collectables and the narrations. It’s hard to say whether Contrast looks better while playing as one of the minimalist silhouettes or running around in full 3D. The graphics are a key aspect of the game, being set in such a hearty destination the overly cartoon design looks great and is consistant throughout. 8/10

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												This is a good game with a mechanic that is reminiscent of the Shift games, which I think did it better. It could be because I played them first, or because I found the 3D to 2D in Contrast imprecise at times, which made some of the jumps pretty frustrating. It was also sometimes unclear how to set up the environment to successfully get yourself where you need to go, but I actually enjoyed how freeform these parts were and would have liked to see more of them, with a bit more polish.I really did like the atmosphere and setting, though I don't think the whole shadow idea meshed well with the rest of the game, and the locations felt more like they were pieced together based on how interesting they would be to play through instead of being used to create a cohesive narrative. Despite this, it was a very charming game with some interesting puzzles, and is worth picking up on sale to satisfy your curiosity.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												This is a wonderful game.  The story and music are really well done and the characters are incredible - if you are nostalgic for the big band, gumshoe era, this game is right up your alley.  Loading it is a little tricky as you will likely need a patch, but once you get it working there are very few hitches or problems.  The game play is unique with you playing a character that moves in and out of shadows and helps a little girl find her way in the world.  Most of the puzzles are fairly straight-forward and are somewhat portal-like in their layout.  I was able to solve most without assistance.   It is not a super long game but creates characters you will cheer for and love.  Gets a little metaphysical toward the end but doesn't attract from the story.  Definitely worth the price - not sure why such a lower metacritc score - was certainly better than a 66

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												There are only 3 cons I could list for this game : Linear&Repetitive, Short and you need to "get" the main character to appreciate the story, otherwise, it will feel a bit dull and ininteresting.Now I'm done with the negative stuff, lemme tell you how this game is nice: I'm usually not into platformers but this one kept me interested due to the real/shadow plan duality. Use lights in reality to affect shadow and create new shadow plateforms, then switch back to reality to activate a lever ect...Another great thing is the game being enjoyable and controllable even when not using a controller. Keyboard and mouse are an okay combo for this game.Gameplay wise, it's good. Like I said in the beginning, it's linear&repetitive but not too much. The short lenght might be a con, it helps : short and repetitive is better than long and repetitive.But all that... It's not what you should buy the game for. Actually, it is a little but.. Man, the ambience. This game truly has a magical ambience. My rating : 73/100

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This isn't a game. It is interactive art. In the first few moments there's this song that pulled me in and intrigued me. I hit start and the graphics were so nice to look at. It was very immersive in those first few moments. That experience, I think, is worth the price when on sale. There is nothing to actually play however. I control the character in a very linear fashion and listen to the dialog as the story unfolds. With cutscenes every few minutes I'm never actually allowed to play. Then with all the things I learned from the tutorials I climb one tower with puzzles in and the game is through. So if you want an okay story with pretty things to look at then this is for you. If you want to play a game; look elsewhere.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												[Pros]-First of all, I really love the unique gameplay merchanic. You have the ability to jump in and out the shadows to progress the game and solve very well design puzzles.-Oooh!! I love the Puppet Theater part!!! So enjoyable!!! -The music is beatiful, especially the song of Didi's Mother. Suitable for the special world the developers created.-Likeable main character. Even if your character you control doesn't speak or doesn't show a lot of personality, if you pay attention and collect the extra items, you will learn more about her.-By the way, the Extra items you collect actually is woth finding. You learn interesting and in my opinion important details about the whole plot of the game and for the characters.-A surprise twist at the end of the game. Not a twist like "HOLY SH*T SON!!!!! FDfkmdnmmsEDf!!!", but more like "very interesting. I need to learn more". [Cons]-Didi..........shut the f*ck up. At first you where ok girl, I really liked you, but after 1 hour, your voice become irritating to my nerves....I really wished the main character had a voice so I had a break from Didi's yapping.-The shadows of the characters needed more work. This sound strange, but when you notice that the shadows don't move their lips [except Didi] and their hands movements sometimes are lifeless [except Didi again], you will understand my nitpick. -The controls are ok.....but at some point if you are not precise with your movements, you will see yourself jump back and forth from a shadow without wanted to do it. At some point I wanted to pass a moving gear while I was a shadow, but every time I wanted to move, I became normal and fall down.........20 times I think.....f*ck. -The story is ok, but not something very exciting. I was more interested in the extras, than the main story with the exception the ending.-Very short game. I finished in less 3 hours. -Very unsatisfying. Being a very short game, it let you with a desire to learn more about this world. I hope for a sequel to cover my curiosity for some details I wanted to learn.[Final Thought]I really liked this game, even with the some frustrations I had while playing it.However because the game is very short and a not very interesting story, I suggest you buy it when it get cheaper.With that said, I hope for a sequel for this game. Good work.7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Incredible. The music, the design, the voice actors, the constant thought of "where the hell am I and what in Hell's half-acre is happening?"  A few rough edges in the interaction, but I'm sure that will be as smooth as the jazz in the sequel. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE MAKE A SEQUEL!The music and vocals are of notable quality in both art and fidelity. A bit short, yet some of the puzzles seem to take longer than they should AFTER you have figured out it mechanic. Although you can also spend a lot of time playing with then dancing on shadows. There are also a couple of very arbitrary obstructions.  What I hope are typical growing pains for an ambitious project worthy of a SEQUEL!  I compare it to Trine(without the sleepy time story) in the way that Trine was a bit buggy, a lot control quirks but had a great core mechanic and atmosphere.  Then Trine 2 just nailed it.  What the first one could have been if they had the time and budget. Contrast 2 will be great. So get invested now.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												I got a new computer, so I decided to try out Contrast as my first game. I couldn't stop! It was a lot of fun - not too challenging, interesting storyline. Wonderful graphics, audio, and characters. It was shorter than I expected, but I enjoyed it a lot and really hope for a sequel. I am sick to death of fighting games, so a game with no fighting at all that was still fun, interesting, and different was a very pleasant change of pace. Its replayability isn't /too/ high, since once you've figured out the puzzles, it's easy to breeze through, but I would play through again simply because it was fun and I loved playing. All in all, I would very much recommend this game to anyone seeking a new game that's challenging, but not to hard, without any fighting, and a great soundtrack.

												This game innovates by the integration of shadows into gameplay. Also most of the puzzles involve shadows in one way or another. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												I got a new computer, so I decided to try out Contrast as my first game. I couldn't stop! It was a lot of fun - not too challenging, interesting storyline. Wonderful graphics, audio, and characters. It was shorter than I expected, but I enjoyed it a lot and really hope for a sequel. I am sick to death of fighting games, so a game with no fighting at all that was still fun, interesting, and different was a very pleasant change of pace. Its replayability isn't /too/ high, since once you've figured out the puzzles, it's easy to breeze through, but I would play through again simply because it was fun and I loved playing. All in all, I would very much recommend this game to anyone seeking a new game that's challenging, but not to hard, without any fighting, and a great soundtrack.
