number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Time for another Timeraider Reviews :P  (SMALL SPOILERS INSIDE, NONE STORY-RELATED THOUGH) (30-11-2014)So.. Contrast. Lets first get some things and negative points out of the way:The game is very short. About 3-4 hours, 4-5 if you want to get all the collectibles.I bought it during a 75% off sale, thus i cant judge well if it would be worth the full price. I would advice to wait for a sale .. like 50%-75% off :D Do keep in mind.. this is only based my normal 1 euro = 1 hour of gametime, nothing else.Though it plays fine with a keyboard and mouse and has not a single problem while using those devices, as always i would advice playing a platformer with a controller. (Game has amazing controller support btw, even switching from keyboard to controller in the middle of a tutorial text, the line will change the keys the text redirects you to)Now the good things:The music is amazing. The jazzy style with some sweet vocals now and then made me finish this game quicker then expected due to being able to play longer without getting bored.The atmosphere in the game is the other big part. It feels as if you got trown back into the past.. back to the time of the blues, gangsters and burlesque. Alot of the game being darker colored with not that much massively bright colored objects make it an amazing experience.Now the platforming. When i started playing i felt trown back into another one of my favorite games in the past years.. Alice: Madness Returns. A 3D world from third-personview with platform elements while getting you further into the story in between. Even though Contrast doesnt hold any combat, the platforming parts are quite active... it doesnt just stop with moving platforms..nooooo.. because Contrast has something else.. shadows. You are able to go into the light reflecting on walls etc. and go inside of your own shadow, allowing you to go alot further then just walking on physical objects. Combine this with being able to dash and be able to become a shadow even when mid-air makes for some exciting puzzles. Its not THAT hard but i can see some people taking their time at some puzzles for sure.The story is great. Because your own personage stays on the background, you get fully emerged in the story of the child you are taking care of. Lets just say it has some nice twists and emotions (Not as emotional as Brothers: A tale of two sons (of which im not afraid to admit is the only game in history that literally made me shed a tear for a sec) with a good plot (though it might be slightly confusing for some ;D). I wont spoil anything of the story so enough about that!Now the conclusion. Great game, nice controls, gameplay and atmosphere feel amazing and suck you in. Not supermemorable game that will change your life entirely but still a very very well-made game.I would rate this game 7.5-8/10.Not sure if i would pay full price since im a cheapass :P but at least worth looking into and certainly worth buying with any discount.Its on 75% discount till 2 December (2014) btw.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												I'll start by saying I paid full price for this game. Contrast is one of those games that could be a joy to play, if it didn't have those moments in game where clipping makes you restart your chapter. The graphics are excellent, but the game has difficulty knowing what it is - they list the 3d to 2d transisitions as a selling point, but it's by far the game's largest drawback. Well, that and the one song they replay over and over and over and.....While the game is fairly easy to play, there are moments when it is simply impossible to pass a puzzle for unknown reasons. Note that I did play this game offline, so my total hours played is incorrect. I quickly and easily made it through the game until I hit the "carousel"  challenge. No matter what I did, I could not complete this puzzle as for no apparent reason the game would dump me back into 3D mode causing me to start over, and over and over. Am I doing something wrong? Perhaps, but you would assume after 3 hours of trying the same puzzle I would accidentally get it right once. I didn't. Compared to the overly simplistic gameplay of the rest of the story, this insanely difficult challenge made me stop playing. Simply put, I hate this game. Is it well done? Certainly.Is it playable? No, if you like a challenge and No if like a relaxing gameplay. Perhaps a means of skipping a buggy puzzle would have kept me playing (I'm sure it would have), the fact is there is no reason to continue. I'm not vested in the characters or the story. This game is all setting with almost no plot. There is no payoff for playing, especially when I could have spent the 3 wasted hours enjoying a quirky game like Kentucy Route Zero. I feel angry that this glitchy mess was funded by me as a tax payer in Canada (Canada Media Fund) and I'd like to see fewer tax payer funded games on steam - and more creativity being rewarded, because Contrast would not have stood on it's own had the developer not accessed Federal tax dollars. It's quite clear that this game was funded because of it's visual style, not it's playability or storyline. Contrast does nothing to enhance our Canadian image or enrich me as a Canadian on a personal level, no but we do know who it enriched. 99% of the developers on steam seem to get by without tax dollars. My hope however is that the development money was refunded to the tax payer out of the profits.

Would recommend buying the soundtrack and looking at some fanart instead of buying the game. Very disappointing experience in my opinion.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Background: Was attracted by the striking 'French' visuals and intriguing gameplay that put me in mind of the film and game of 'City of Lost Children'.The Good:* Oozes atmosphere with elegant visuals and design* Ingenious light based mechanics* Sound design is pitch perfect in all aspects* Cutscenes are brilliantly incorporated* A mature story that draws you in as it unfolds* Plays well with mouse and keyboard despite the very consoley feelThe Bad:* Some (rare) glitchy mechanics spoil the flow* Gamespeed/movement feels too fast on high powered machines* Too short (4 hours) and you want more Impressions: I was strongly put in mind of the films of Jeunet (like a cross of 'City of Lost Children' with 'Amelie') and was impressed at the inventiveness of the puzzles and that the developer resisted repeating themselves just to pad out the game. That said 4 hours will be enough for a run through and another 1 to pickup missing achievements.Some have criticised the game for not answering questions but the answers are all there if you listen, read the clues you collect and join the dots in your head.Recommended for: Puzzle fans and those who like ingenious but forgiving platformers.Conclusion: 9/10. Charmed me and tugged on my heartstrings from start to finish, just wanted more of it.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												PROS:Story - the writing and voice acting in this game were greatNovelty - introduction of an innovative game mechanic that lends itself well to creative and challenging puzzlesCONS:Controls - movement is awkward and occasionally a bit frustratingUnpredictable triggers - Use key on the wrong item and you will be taken to the next part of the story before you've had a chance to try and find everything in the current levelLength/Price ratio - This game is a bit expensive for being so short. Totally worth picking up on sale though.Many people complain about glitches but I didn't see anything too obvious. There are some kind of annoying places where you fall through decorative parts near the edge of the level that look like they should support you, but you'll only notice this if you are off exploring. It won't impede progression through the actual game content.Don't expect this to be game that's going to help hone your precision platformer skills. The controls, collisions, and physics are too wonky for that. The puzzles, story, music, art, writing, etc. however, are all very well done, and very cohesive. Nice little game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Starting out, I had mixed feelings about this game that ranged from confusion, to flat out elation at what I was seeing it bring to the table. It's story line left me asking what exactly was going on straight out of the gate, but then the art style the game had, and it's mechanics made me giddy with delight at how awesome playing it was! The ability to turn yourself into a shadow on the walls, and then traverse the landscape by walking along OTHER shadows was just the coolest thing to me, and the art style maanged to keep the world looking dark yet plesent and beautiful at the same time.That said, the only gripes I had was that the game was WAY too short. Someting I was able to hammer out to the end in just a couple hours.... and the story line left me with more questions than answers about what was happening in the games world. Other than that, Contrast was great!

number of helpful: 7 of 22 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Contrast is a unique 3D platformer (2D when you're in the shadows). I played it some time back so I cannot write out an exhaustive review, but suffice to say the setting, story, soundtrack and voice-acting were all decent here. The artstyle especially was unique though. The game mechanics are interesting, but they were never fully fleshed out. The puzzles are mostly of moderate difficulty, but one or two of the later ones might frustrate you for a while.The game is a bit rough around the edges with texture pop-ins, some wonky animations and some other minor control bugs. The ending felt a bit rushed for the story. Length wise, it is pretty short at 3 hours or so, and you should be able to 100% the game in around 4 hours. If you go in with your expectations in check and manage to get this game on a discount, I'd be pretty certain you'll come away liking it. At least that's how I saw it in the end - a unique game that did not overstay its welcome.

Posted: March 10
												Contrast is an enjoyable puzzle platformer that has some unique mechanics, a great storyline but suffers from a few small gameplay issues.The shadow / light mechanics are unique and they work (most of the time) very well, making for some intriguing puzzles. The storyline is ambiguous but definitely interesting.The music and graphics are also fantastic, and better than I thought there'd be. I'd also recommend the soundtrack if you enjoy soundtracks.The game does have a minor annoyances when it comes to gameplay. Occassionally I found the controls a little clunky which made some more technical puzzle jumps hard. There were also a couple of glitches when trying to jump and shift into a wall.Overall those were only minor grievances and I easily lived with them. For its price, it's still great value for money.I recommend it if you want a nice but relatively quick puzzle platformer with some unique mechanics, a great storyline and fantastic music; just don't expect a 100% perfect gameplay experience.

Posted: November 24, 2013
												When I saw Contrast at Steam Greenlight I knew that was a title I was going to play.Those who know me will easily understand why: Contrast has female protagonists, something I'm always looking forward to,  beautiful character and environment design, with an aesthetic close to my heart, an interesting mechanic and was non-violent, which is something I'm beginning to appreciate, even though I love to hack and slash things. So, as soon as it was available for pre-order, I decided to buy it, even if I was not at my best financially. It was worth it. First, the whole game was translated to brazilian portuguese, with the exception of the audio (which would've been really costly). Although I have no problem understanding english, this was a nice touch, specially when most people at my country don't have easy access to english lessons. Second, the game is beautiful, entertaining and interesting. I almost gasped at the final revelation: something I thought to be just an aesthetic choice, in the end, had much more meaning within the story. The puzzles were difficult enough to keep me interested, not hard to the point of making me want to give up nor easy to the point of leaving me bored. I once or twice thought of looking through a walkthrough, 'cause I'm lazy and always craving for more pieces of information surrounding a game's story, but I'd always close the window and decide to solve the puzzle myself. I loved when you activated some sort of "memory" and interacted with the shadows. There were glitches and bugs, like getting stuck between shadow-world and "real-world", but nothing really troubling. The controls were a bit weird at the beginning, I felt like Dawn walked too fast or something, but I got used to it quickly.  I could complain that the game is short. It is, really, but I honestly think it's worth it. It's an engaging experience and I think it lasts enough.  My only true complaint is that sometimes the cut-scenes would break the pace of the game. You'd walk a bit or solve one short puzzle and have a cut-scene right after it in a way that felt a tiny bit out of place. In the beginning of the game I felt there were too many short cut-scenes happening all the time. Still, it's not something that takes anything out of this wonderful game. This is a game you can show your non-gamer friends and family members too and I think would grab their attention. If you are open to it, you could ask them to help solving some puzzles, to make them engage more with the game.Visuals are lovely, gameplay is nice and the story is interesting.I'd recommend it for sure.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												I was drawn in to this game by the unique game mechanics and the amazing jazz music. I stayed for the decent gameplay and good story. It is a platformer, which naturally sets out its automatic good and bad points. My only sadness with the title was that it was over a bit earlier than I would have liked. This game is seriously a diamond in the rough. The music and art is combined and woven into a good story. There aren't too many games out there like this.

Posted: May 8, 2014
												This game was quite odd. As a game its nothing special; it would even be fair to say its gameplay is just bad. I often felt as though I tricked trough some levels by takng advantage of the hit-and-miss gameplay like making jumps that would avoid the puzzles. The stories execution is equally questionable, with a protagonist who serves to guide you through the game without any real finesse. And by that I don't mean your character; you seem to serve more as a tool for her tasks but that is the point.TO THE GOOD!This game had a very specific feel about it which I felt made it worth playing. The art style and music marry so well together that I forgave the shaky gameplay (at least for the most part). Depite its dodgy execution, I got what it was trying to show and it made for an enjoyable experience. The story wasn't as linear as what I've come to expect; whether thats a good or bad thing, im not entirely sure. Its fair to say Didi (the young girl) was a bit 'pushy' in trying to force you into the story, but I didnt really mind as my character is there to help her and the interactions of the character felt right for the situation.Theres plenty to find out beyond the game through exploration. I actually think these bits were what made the game as it added another level of story beyond Didi's life to something more personal for the character Dawn (who never speaks IIRC), also - great name without being something cheesy. I would throughly recommend you endevour to find the 20(I think?) hidden media snippets! It reminded me of Bioshock in that the information you find explains the situation youre in; but in a modest way.This game however is by no means difficult! I did the entire story in a single 2 hour sitting and found everything in that time. This wasn't even deliberately to finish it, I just felt like the game never lost traction and felt so, almost, calm to play that I kept casually playing. This isnt to say the story was good; it was weak with the hidden snippets making it interesting but it was solid enough in terms of character and situation.Overall, as someone who does try to game as much as possible, I can't honestly say its a great game. But for me, it was incredibly playable and I will revisit it again gladly. It was like listening to music, I did indeed just easily loose track of time and do it. I found it quite charming if I'm being honest.I played it with a controller if that means anything? You wont need the precision or focus of a kb+m but thats just my preference for this game. I would also say if youre on the fence about it, its probably best you wait till a sale comes around. I don't think I paid full price and despite enjoying it, don't know if its worth it. Definately feels like it should be £6.99 or similarly priced. Wouldn't be upset if I did pay retail though.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												I have just finished playing this game; I completed it within about just over 4 hours. I will admit that they game is extremally short for the cost of the game (Although I did buy my copy on sale - I recomend that you wait till the sales come on) I was left feeling like the game wasnt really finished and that a lot of things where unexplained. But!!! I did really enjoy this game, I wont lie, its a good game and maybe the ending is suppose to be a mystery? its a very mysterious game. You play as Dawn a very interesting looking lady, that you really feel cool to play as, with her cool concept design and awesome abilities like turning into a shadow. Dawn follows Didi - a little girl who wants to sneak out to go see her mother singing and suddenly you discover the story behind Didi and her family and what is going on with them. The game is set in the 1920's and has wonderful music and a lovely Jazz theme to the story. The animations are amazing and some of the little pick up items you find along the way give you more detail as to whats go on and can be really interesting! You will find yourself becoming attatched to some of the characters and not wanting to pause the game :)Overall I would recommend the game as its interesting and unique in the story and game play and I would play this game just to listen to the music and feel the atmosphere:Pros-------- Great music and atmosphere all the way through- Great characters and concept art for items and puzzles and different areas- Good voice acting and dialogue is interesting and sometimes funny / sweet- Unique and fun ideas like turning into a shadow - Very interesting game - will make you hooked!!Cons-------- Minor glitches in gameplay and once in dialogue- Extremally short game....- Game ending will leave you wondering mosre about the story and will feel slighty unfinished...- Puzzles are very easy

Posted: February 16, 2014
												The main mechanic of the game is very unique and quite fun to wrap your head around. Music is both haunting and enchanting all at once and the visual style is beautiful in an artistic- rather than purely technical, polygonal county way.Controls are responsive though edge detection could use a little polish. There were times when a jump looks like it should've landed but the character 'bumps' the edge and falls. Luckily, the checkpoint system is very forgiving and no more than 5 minutes of progress was ever lost through multitudes of jumping off edges.Level design Is a little inconsistent with a lot of levels containing linear solutions while others allow solutions that skip the entirety of the puzzles via jumping on objects in the 'real world' and dashing into the 'shadow world'. However, this is hard to fault as the shadow mechanics are very complex melding 2D and 3D puzzles across the levels.The way the story is told is very unique as well. Since pretty much all the story is told in the 'shadow world', each scene feels like a snapshot of what's happening with a slight time leap in between each one. The pacing of the story is well enough that it never feels like a drag. There is a drive to see what's next. This is all backed up by some pretty fantastic voice acting with moments of melancholy, angst, and anger delivered with emotion. The developers have left the ending a bit open for interpretation so those who are looking for a clear cut finish where everything is answered will be a bit irked. However, those who enjoy discussing interpretations with others will find a nice conversation with others in the same boat.Though it might be a bit short time-wise, it doesn't artificially inflate the time to beat. So it's enjoyable from start to end.

Posted: December 6, 2013
												Well where to start ? Okay I have been waiting for two years to play this game. It finally came out and so I did. It is simply like a critic once said ''It is like Limbo and Bioshock had a child together and Contrast is that child''. So rightous but also very indipendent from those games. Contrast has some references from both Bioshock and Limbo which I love them both and after I saw them I felt very touched. It's gameplay is very very unique and it has some science in it too like quantum physics and parallel universes as A.Einstein stated. My only complain was about the puzzles. Yes I know this is a puzzle platformer but it gives you so much puzzle and a little story on the sides that you would like to have some more because I think it was awesomely fair. Soundtrack is amazing if you are into Jazz/Blues. Modelling and artwork is also dashing. Ofcourse game has its problems when it comes to performance but then again this game never got a big budget so I can not blame the producers. Story is depressive and gloomy but with that being said, I like that kind of stories because life is like that too. To sum it all up, I am perfectly OK with the money I spent on this game (which I preordered it) and easily can recommend this to people around me.

Posted: July 7, 2014
												Contrast is a very well-done and innovative Indie game. It falls into the puzzle genre, but utilizes first-person character control and does require a bit of speed.Like all games, Contrast has its merits and pitfalls. Some things I really liked about the game are:- A very well-thought-out and touching story- Beautiful soundtrack (especially "Kat's Song". Youtube it!)- A unique gameplay mechanic- Some decently challenging puzzles- Beautifully done art. Many noir games and movies nowadays are just creepy and Sin City-like. This is a much more refreshing take on the noir theme.And some things that weren't so great:- I don't know anyone who has clocked more than 10 hours to beat this- Some minor bugs- a reference to Albert Einstein in an earlier time period (learn your history, people!)Simply put, Contrast is very well-done and a must-buy for any Indie fan. People who liked story-intensive games such as Bastion will definitely enjoy Contrast more than most. Of course $15 for a game this short may pinch wallets, so do wait for a sale. And of course, we hope to hear of a second game from Compulsion Studios soon. =D

Posted: February 26, 2014
												Contrast, to put into a single word, is marvelous. Its graphics are well detailed, and the way that light is used in this game is borderline genius. The voicework is well done for all characters. The music is excellent, being very rythmic and jazzy. And the story is quite interesting. The collection of collectable that you can obtain is both expansive and impactful for the length of the game. The Bioshock-esque way of using collectables to explain plot points was well done. It was always interesting to read an article about a missing person, or seeing a picture of the "scientific" explainations of the shadow world. The light puzzles that are used are especially interesting because the game mechanic of switching between two worlds is wonderfully unique and fun. All of these factors really combine to create an incredible atmosphere.However no game is without its imperfections. Though I do, in fact, recommend this game to anyone who wants a interesting experience, I must also explain the game's faults. Contrast has 2 major flaws which both fall into the gameplay category. The main problem is that Dawn, the main character, is incredibly floaty. She's a tad hard to control because her jump arc seems a tad unnatural. The second would probably be the camera. See the having the camera be controlled by the mouse is fine in third person, but when you enter the shadow world the camera tends to be kinda random, causing you to have to adjust your mouse in odd ways. The small gameplay flaws that Contrast has pales in comparison to the experience of playing it though. Playing through the game is honestly just a marvelous experience, because of it's brilliant atmosphere, as well as its unique concept.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												This is probably one of the best puzzle games I've played. If you have any liking for French jazz culture, this is the game for you. It is all about using light in creative ways to solve puzzles, most of which are platforming. My favorite pieces are the music which was put together with care. The vocalist they hired to sing a couple songs has the perfect voice for this type of jazz. All of the voice acting is quite solid. The other piece that drew me in was the use of shadows to represent characters rather than physical beings. I think that is explained through collectibles, but I haven't spent much time with it. Contrast also manages to portray a sense of innocence surrounding Didi while giving some very adult conflicts when she's not around. The only real issue I had was with either the controls or the design, I'm not sure. Sometimes when something seemed easy to accomplish, like a jump, you'd be force off the wall for some reason and have to start over. Basically I think some of the shadows in the environment were unintentional and created surprise blocks for you to avoid. It could also just be I'm not very practiced at platformers. The puzzles seem well designed and not too challenging to figure out. After figuring out what needs to be done, you may still need to take a few tries at it before succeeding, but it isn't usually too frustrating.It is quite a short game if you figure out the puzzles quickly, it took me maybe 6 hours. So I probably wouldn't buy it for full price just because of the length, but I would definitely buy it on sale. Also, the soundtrack is a great jazz compilation.One last note: at I believe the end of the first act, there are two endings depending on if you just stand and watch, or actively do something (I don't want to give spoilers) If you don't do anything, you'll fail the level and be put back to the beginning of the dialogue, so I recommend just listening first, then actually doing what you're supposed to.

												Really good puzzle-platformer with an intriguing, dark, but ultimately heart warming story about a family in shambles, and a daughter that will do anything she can to bring them back together.  Plays really smoothly, and the puzzles, while not challenging until maybe the last few of the game, are very logical and well thought out.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												A clever but underachieving adventure / puzzle game elevated at times by an interesting setting and story.For those of you that don't know, your character can blend between 3d person and 2d projected platforming by stepping into the light projected onto walls. Shadows become walls, floors and even lifts to new areas. At its best it feels like a mix of fez and portal, but at its worst the shadow stepping can be awkward and unreliable.The pacing is acceptable and there seem to be multiple ways to approach some puzzles, but there's no serious challenge here.The setting falls somewhere between Bugsy Malone and Alice in Wonderland, but doesn't fully deliver on either. The noir story is a nice touch, but not gritty enough for my tastes, and whilst the worlds warp and float like a fever dream this fact is entirely ignored by the characters. I would not have been shocked to see: "But it was all a dream. The End"There were some beautiful moments towards the end of the game where a deeper meaning is hinted, but it arrived a little late.If you're curious, pick it up on a good sale day, but you're looking for puzzle, platforming or story, this game hits under average on all accounts. [5.0]

Posted: February 13, 2014
												I'm really enjoying the atmosphere, and the story is both intriguing and mysterious to a degree. The puzzles have been challenging, varied, and entertaining. My one complaint is the platforming bits. Many of them are timed based on a spot of dialogue that is playing, which means that everytime you make a mistake, you basically have to listen to a whole cutscene over again. This wouldn't be so bad if not for the fact that the shadow puppets you are walking on sometimes move in ways that "throw" you off of them, which is very difficult to predict. So part of these challenges becomes memorization, and trial and error. Which coupled with the replaying dialogue, makes a really interesting, innovative, and gorgeous blend of story and gameplay somewhat tiresome to replay until you get it right.I'd definitely recommend it, since it is otherwise very, very good so far.

												This is an old-school platform adventure game with a new-school twist. Gorgeous artwork and fantastic scenery left me in awe. This game made me believe there is a future for gaming, away from all the mindless sequels and Call of Battlefield: Total Warfare 3. Posted: May 4, 2014
												Beautiful piece of bliss to play. Charming story, characters and atmosphere, and astoundingly good music. The game in itself is rather short, but personally I find that that's part of the whole "magic" of it. It's sweet, and touching, but it doesn't get boring with needless hours of repetitive gameplay. Speaking of which, the whole jumping in and out of the "shadow dimension" is amazing. Awesome idea, really difficult to implement. The quality of this game in general is dazzling. Contrast had me with a dumb smile on my face whenever I wasn't frowning over a particularly challenging shadow puzzle (yes, Vincenzo, I'm looking at you and your lab). I sincerely loved this game and would recommend it to anyone, even if you aren't really a puzzle fan. The music alone makes it worth it. And if jazz ain't your cup of tea, the story and the atmosphere ought to do the rest. Truly, truly a jewel. I am forever in debt with my past self for spending the twenty bucks it cost me then (I got myself the collector's edition, with the soundtrack and stuff).

I feel it takes on the Bioshock type of feel of mystery is a plot itself but in reality a bit more of exploration and discovery would be nice. There are very little if a handful of "extra" things you can do in this game. Being gathering collectibles or luminaries which dont have any impact on the game or seem to give you extra completion or unlock more content, which would be interesting if it was that way. Overall it was a good game but it definitely could be better. Posted: February 17, 2014
												This game was innovative and fun.  Has a very dark dreamlike aspect that reminds me of American McGee's Alice.  The story and the atmosphere also work very well together.  The only issues I have with the game are the mismatch between the visuals and the actual collision points (there was even a light beam that was not properly aligned with its source). Posted: January 9, 2014
												Wow! This is a wonderful little game. The music, the visuals, the story... they're absolutely fantastic. Dawn, your character, is an acrobat with this awesome ability to 'shift' into the shadows, helping you and your little friend, Didi, to traverse the world and help out Didi's pretty complicated family. When you're in the shadows, it's very Limbo-esque, though not quite as rage-inducing. When in the normal world, it's got a great♥♥♥♥♥♥Tracy feel to it, with sleazy gangsters and classy dames everywhere.My only issue with it is the length. 3.8 hours later and I'd completed the story, collected everything, and 100%ed the achievements. However, I can forgive it for this, as the story was great, and the puzzles were fun to solve, particularly as you have to think in both normal and shadow terms.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Contrast is one of those games that has a good premise - the idea of use light and shadows to create a separate bit of 2D puzzle gameplay from the normal 3D world, but the implementation from a story and setting as well as design is a bit disconnected.  The technical approach is good in how you can shift in an our of shadows, but the problem is that the areas you can do this in are very limited and separated from each other, making each puzzle its own microcosm.   The puzzles that use this aren't that difficult as well, with the most difficult ones being where you can either move objects to change shadows or the location of the light source. Again, with the puzzles being separate entities, these are one-stop problems as opposed to part of a larger difficult mechanism to figure out.The story is interesting but it's hard to get into and leaves some questions on getting into the characters. Whether this is a fantasy, a dream, or something else isn't clear, and whether it is a flashback or the like.  As such, the game quickly devolves into just moving from puzzle to puzzle with story getting in the way.It is still a decent game, but it's one I'd wait for a sale for, getting about 3 hrs of playtime from it.

Posted: February 20, 2014
												Extremely short, but very good game.  Unless you are a collector and want to find everthing in this game you can beat it in about 2 hours.  If you like collecting and learning a bit more about this lore of the game it take about 3.5 hours depending how good you are at solving these puzzles.Over all  The controlls where excellent, a little sticky here and there in certain spot probably from my own doing.There are a few spots in the game though if you lose a critical piece to the puzzle you must killl yourself to restart that part to get that critical piece back.  It was kind of annoying to have to jump off a ledge to respawn a box that I needed to have for a very small part of a leve.Overall the visuall are fantastic, the use of light and shadows are amazing and it takes into effect 2D planes.Over all if you want to kill a few hours with a very good puzzle game I would download this, But due to the shortness of the game I would suggest to buy it on a sale or give it to a friend when it goes on sale.

Posted: February 20, 2014
												A living embodiment of 3d puzzle combined with the 2D style platformer such that of Limbo. The atmosphere of the game set around the 1920's with its Jazzy influences and the developments of magic shows really opened up a spectacular mystery genre to the art of the game. Posted: February 20, 2014
												The trailer does not do this game justice. My initial reason for purchasing this game was mostly for the jazz album I would get as part of the collectors edition ;) But as soon as I started playing it, I was hooked. I really like what they did with the game; the graphics are amazing (for anyone who appreciates abstract, almost creepy, beauty); the characters were very well created, the puzzles are challenging, and overall a good game. However, I feel like the story line lacks a little bit. Gameplay is roughly 5.5 hours (even going through slowly and doing all the "extra" stuff), and consists of a girl basically reuniting her parents. There is so much potential the producers could have done with this game, and that's my only complaint. I really wish they would have done more with it because this game was so great! Even though the size of the map doesn't compare to that of Rust (for those of you who are familiar with that), it was so beautifully and artistically created. Very glad I invested in this game and I would definitely play it again to get the collectables I didn't find ;) Plus, if you purchase the collectors edition, you will get a bunch of artwork including details of the making of the characters and other such things, as well as 15 jazz songs that you can save right to your iTunes library :)

Posted: February 23, 2014
												The theme, writing, and and atmosphere kept me through to the end in a single sitting. The fact the puzzles were designed to be solved with real world skills rather than "find the key ring to combine with the ham bone to give to the guy who will blah blah blah..." makes Contrast a great mix of 2D, 3D, and puzzler games all while cutting the bullcrap that bars new players to the genres.I'd recommend this to anyone with a pulse.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												Contrast, to put into a single word, is marvelous. Its graphics are well detailed, and the way that light is used in this game is borderline genius. The voicework is well done for all characters. The music is excellent, being very rythmic and jazzy. And the story is quite interesting. The collection of collectable that you can obtain is both expansive and impactful for the length of the game. The Bioshock-esque way of using collectables to explain plot points was well done. It was always interesting to read an article about a missing person, or seeing a picture of the "scientific" explainations of the shadow world. The light puzzles that are used are especially interesting because the game mechanic of switching between two worlds is wonderfully unique and fun. All of these factors really combine to create an incredible atmosphere.However no game is without its imperfections. Though I do, in fact, recommend this game to anyone who wants a interesting experience, I must also explain the game's faults. Contrast has 2 major flaws which both fall into the gameplay category. The main problem is that Dawn, the main character, is incredibly floaty. She's a tad hard to control because her jump arc seems a tad unnatural. The second would probably be the camera. See the having the camera be controlled by the mouse is fine in third person, but when you enter the shadow world the camera tends to be kinda random, causing you to have to adjust your mouse in odd ways. The small gameplay flaws that Contrast has pales in comparison to the experience of playing it though. Playing through the game is honestly just a marvelous experience, because of it's brilliant atmosphere, as well as its unique concept.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												Contrast is a unique little game. While the storyline is considerably brief, the puzzles can be intriguing, especially when the mechanic of switching in/out of the shadows becomes a touch glitchy. I will admit, it's not a jawdropping experience. There are technical aspects that need tweaking, such as a puzzle I was basically able to skip without noticing on the first try, but the effort is heartfelt and a bizarrely cute experience.That being said, I would not pay the list price for this game. I bought it when it was 40% off (around $8), and that was good enough for me. I would be onboard, however, if the studio were ever to invest in a larger scale version of the game, with some of the mechanics polished up.

Posted: February 27, 2014
ConceptA 2D/3D platformer where you can merge with walls to become a shadow. Utilize this to explore new possibilities in platforming.StoryThe game is divided up into chapters and acts, which you can select from the main screen if you wish. However, the game is really short. I clocked in with about 4 hours on my first playthrough, an hour of which I don't think I was playing. In addition, some mechanic frustrations also prolonged my playthrough.You play as a character named Dawn, whom only Didi can see. Didi is a child of a broken family who is trying to get back together leading to the different levels you encounter. Sometimes this leads to some interesting levels.The game also tries to induce a little mystery of if Dawn is real or not and what exactly is she. However, the game doesn't go too far along that route that it doesn't really matter, especially at the end.GraphicsThe graphics are okay. I had to run this on low settings so I cannot testify how great it can be besides online videos and pictures. I also wonder if the lack of some environment is a result of my computer or design. It does lead to some cool views. The shadow style is a pretty nifty idea that helps distract the player. As I was watching the cutscenes, I was wondering if people can be charmed by simply a shadow on the wall and a voice.SoundThe game has a Jazz music style. It fits with the setting, and the vocals aren't bad in that respect.


YouTube™ Video: Contrast: Music Trailer 

			Views: 110,952		

			Pre-order now on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/224460/ Site: http://www.contrast-thegame.com FaceBook: https://www.facebook.com/ContrastGame Twitter: https://twitter.com/ContrastGame...		

The vocals are actually fairly good too. Didi can get annoying sometimes, but sometimes her actions actually brought a smile. It's interesting that Dawn is voiceless but I guess that's to keep the player guessing what she is exactly and if she's real.GameplayThis game had a lot of promise. The idea of manipulating shadows to create solid platforming makes it a small thinking game as well. When I was little, I used to contemplate how interesting it would be if you can become a shadow. This game allows me to play with that idea a little bit, but not as much as I would have liked.You are given 5 basic controls for most of the game. Movement, Interaction, Shifting, Jump, and Dash. You also have control of the camera, which leads me to controller preferences. You do not want to play this game with a mouse and keyboard if you can avoid it. The camera is controlled with the mouse, which you also use for Dash and Shifting. This becomes a problem when you accidently move the camera while meaning to shift or dash. It has led me to many frustrations. The camera setting with the mouse is also too sensitive even after I adjusted it to get it right. When I switched to a 360 controller, the experience improved greatly. The camera was fine and my hands were less confused with which button was shift and which was dash.This game has no action in it, which is good for this style. Since there are no enemies to fight, you can focus on the platforming and puzzles you are given. The promise of the game expands with the different mechanics you find in the different chapters. There is some room for exploration, but not too much freedom. ONe time when I wanted to wander, Didi would interfere and force me to continue.Speaking of Didi, this game started to make me think about useless companions in video games; Didi is one of them. While you need to follow her to know what you next mission is, she never really helps you out. There is one occasion where she helps you out in the story and that is it. It's a shame because the image I posted near the top seemed to promise that you can use Didi to create an environment for you. There is one particular scene where I wish I could have controlled Didi to use something she was right next to instead of me doing something more complex than it needed.One of the things that could use some fine tuning is the mechanics. I resorted to Gamefaqs for one thing only to find that I was doing it right all along, but the game mechanics would screw it up.  The glitch I'm referring to is the game forcing you or an object to shift out where it shouldn't. Eventually I got it to work, but I was still upset over the whole thing. Unfortunately, the mechanics would still be glitchy every now and then, forcing me to restart multiple times when I should have easily progressed. It's a shame too, because if it wasn't for the occasional glitchy mechanics, it would have been a solid platformer. The game does have some redemption on the matter by giving you multiple checkpoints to restart from when you die and it doesn't take too long to reload.ReplayabilityAs mentioned before, the game is short and you can select specific chapters to play again. However, with the frustrations I encountered with the mechanics, and the story not being so grand, I probably would stay away from it for a while before trying to play again.OverallThis is one of those little disappointments for me. The game has promise and it shows it in sparks throughout the game. Unfortunately, it never completely capitalizes on it's potential. It can give you an interesting experience, but I think I would have more faith if they did a sequel with solid mechanics. This is a game where you might want to wait for a good sale before you buy it (maybe $5-7).My recommendation is for platforming fans who want to try something a little different. If you play with a controller and on a computer that can run it smoothly, then it is less frustrating and possible to enjoy.Taken from my blog at http://www.ign.com/blogs/falconrise/2014/02/16/game-review-contrast-for-pc

Posted: August 4, 2015
												Contrast is a very stylish fantasy-noir. For some reason it has drawn some unfair and rather harsh criticism for one reason or another, presumably by a few gamers expecting a lot more.For me, Contrast's platforming gameplay relies on some exceptional lighting physics: the phasing in and out of shadow showcases some astounding programming by the developers.The period-noir setting is a nice touch - whilst there are references to Einstein, the turn-of-the-century-science and experiments with quantum physics and the 4th dimension could have gone a lot deeper.But as it is, Contrast is a satisfying and very enjoyable game. Of course it has a few glitches and quirks, but in the case of Contrast, the developers came up with an ambitious proposal, and pulled it off with aplomb.

Posted: August 3, 2015
												Contrast is a Puzzle/Adventure game developed and created by Compulsion Games. In this game, you play as Dawn, a young woman who has the supernatural ability to morph into her own shadow and interact with other shadows. You get to play in two dimensional worlds: 2D and 3D worlds, as you help a little girl, to whom you are friends with, fix her parents' problems and renunite them under a more peaceful bond once more.This game is a Puzzle game, meaning that as you continue along your adventure, you will be faced with puzzles that you must solve in both 2D and 3D worlds. What do I have to say about this game?Perhaps a marvel of creativity with non-stop interest as to what will happen next. Truly, this game is its own genius in Optics.

Posted: November 5, 2015
												The wasted potential in this game physically pains me. It has so much to offer and right when you think that you'll get more it's over. Considering its price i wouldn't normally recommend it. ConsThe controls are brokenThe graphics are mediocre Glitches everywhere The transition from 3d to 2d is a nightmareThe story is flatPros (and why i recommend it)The idea is lovely and if it was 4euros or even free  i would say 10/10. The mechanics are simple and there's only a main story to follow. No confusion as to where to go, no useless sidequests. I really liked moving though the shadows and some quests nailed it. Also the shadow cinematics on which you have to walk, in order to get some items where very aesthetically pleasing, a really nice touch to be honest.  I want to see more of this and i also have great hopes for We Happy Few so i want to support the team.  Since my main problem with this game is that it needs more of everything, i guess that also means more money, therefore, more support. I recommend this because i think this team can do better and i want to see a sequel.  The story could definitely still go on and i think it should. tl;dr: It's worth playing but don't get your hopes up

Posted: October 11, 2015
												A great little game. And the little part only comes because it's pretty short. That shouldn't make you look away though. The idea behind it is pretty original and refreshing. Going in and out of shadows definately sounds cool! The story is interesting yet a bit rushed. It felt like the creators ran out of ideas or twists to make it a bit more lengthy and try to flesh more out of the characters' pasts and personalities. And boy did they neglect Dawn's part concerning that! The collectibles offer a bit of information on some stuff but still it felt lacking. Apart from that (and a bit clunky camera) the game is beautiful. The 1920s atmosphere is given pretty nicely and the visuals seem like taken out of a painting. Plus it also gives off a feeling that you are actually in a dreamworld. The music draws you in before you even press start with that song in the title screen and it continues to accompany you pretty well throughout most of the game. The controls were ok. The puzzles were simple and fun, except a couple of times where you might not do it the correct way thus leading you in a dead end (hint: pirate ship) and you are forced to reload the last save. Thankfully the game autosaves frequently so you won't have to go back a lot, usually just before you start the puzzle event.Although i doubt it, i hope we get to see a sequel sometime in the future, but that's just me. The ending could be seen as both conclusive and open at the same time. Depends on each person and how they interpret it. All in all a great experience. If it's on sale grab it asap. 7.5/10

Posted: March 15, 2016
												This is a platform adventure game with a twist.  The 3-D setting is nice to look at, but the scope of it is limited.  Most of your focus will be on how to properly manipulate light and shadows to get around obstacles and reach "hidden" items that are actually quite visible but hard to reach.  In most cases, the solution is obvious.  There are no enemies to defeat.  You are an acrobat, not a fighter!  As for the setting and plot:  it is the 1920's (think film noire but in color) and you are the imaginary friend of a little girl with a broken family.  The girl is trying to find a way to keep her family from splitting up, and you are trying to help.  Most of the hidden items you find are clues to what is happening in the real world while the poor girl slowly goes "crazy" because she sees the world differently from the grown-ups.  Her madness is evident in the twisted and broken state of the world in which you travel, which is a reflection of the girl's mental state and memories.The game is VERY short, you can finish it in just a few hours.  The path is always obvious and you have strict limits about where you can go; you can never stray much outside of the world known to the little girl because you will find great chasms at the edges of her memories.  The way you can become a shadow when you stand against any well-lit surface is pretty cool though.  In many instances you will need to move objects in the 3-D world in order to open a new path in the shadows in order to progress in the game.  It really is a unique and fun game mechanic.So, the bottom line...yeah this game is fun, but very short and straightforward.  There are no enemies, no boss fights, no NPCs to talk to or get side quests from, no level-up system... just platforming with travel through shadows.  The story is a nice mix of sweet and sad but really nothing to write home about.  The setting and graphics are stylized and cute, but not exactly beautiful.  So, I'd say go ahead and grab this game if it's available for a really cheap price.  If you pay more than $5 for it, you're paying too much.

Posted: October 4, 2015
												In this game you play as an imaginary friend of a little girl and you can switch between moving in 3D and in 2D running on the shadows. You spend the game being ordered round by the little girl to help sort out the failures of her screw up step father but he is not a likeable bumbling failure like Inspector Gadget he just seems like a walking disaster where the family would just be better off without him. The story is short (less then 4 hours to complete the game with all achievements)  but it does have its moments. The environment is excellent with its slightly subverted cityscape, striking lighting, 1920s atmosphere and good music. The platforming mechanic is the weak point of the game, the trailers show really fast paced smooth gameplay but in actual fact it is rather awkward there is a lot of slightly moving objects round and repeatedly jumping at things until you get it just right. Overall I am still going to recommend this game it is a very nice unique platforming mechanic it is just not quite as good as I expected.

Posted: November 15, 2015
												Contrast is a puzzle based platform game, developed by Compulsion Games.In this game you follow the story of a small girl Didi Malenkaya who has an imaginary friend called Dawn.No one else can see Dawn, but that does not mean she does not exsist.Didi found herself in a world where she only sees people as shadows.Her parents are having relationship problems and many debts to pay off. They both are too busy to take care of Didi, her mother Kat Malenkaya works as a singer at the Ghost Note cabaret while her father Johnny Fenris has been kicked out of the house because of doing business with gangsters in order to make some money.Child services have threatened to take Didi away from her mother.Didi can't stand this situation anymore and together with Dawn she sneaks out of the house to save the situation between her parents.Contrast is set in a 1920 Nior atmosphere.In this game you play as Dawn who has the ability to shift into the 2D shadow world and back into the 3D world. Throughout the game you have to help Didi solve puzzles that vary from moving objects between the physical 3D world and the 2D shadow world. Manipulating light sources in the 3D world such as spotlights, film projectors etc. will create shadow paths. These paths will lead Dawn to new areas containing collectibles like Luminaries (light sources) and Documents that reveal more about the story.Contrast felt like a very unique game because the ability of shifting between the physical 3D world and the 2D shadow world was something I have never seen before in games.Everything I already knew about puzzles games couldn't always match up to the puzzles in Contrast.This will make you think more out of the box, requires a little more creative thinking and raise the bar of puzzles.I must admit that Contrast has a short length of gameplay and the story itself does not have that much depth than I expected it to be.I really recommend Contrast for its unique experience but I don't think it's worth the full price, purchase the game when it's on sale.

												I recommend the game with this caveat: it's about the experience of an art piece that has a few fun puzzles rather than the game as a whole.Pros:Beautiful art from top to bottom, with music to match.Story is just interesting enough to keep your attention between the likable protagonist and metaphysical plot points.Some genuinely clever puzzles to solve using the unique game mechanics.Cons:Controls/camera are not 100% solid. Posted: March 23
												BLURS THE LINES BETWEEN DARKNESS AND LIGHT In this game, you fight for no side as you need both darkness and light to get from Point A to Point B. I have never been this frustrated and fascinated with a game before. The controls take some time to get used to, so some necessary actions may take a while to do. I absolutely hated the moving shadow parts that you had to climb in order to get somewhere or in order to obtain an object. That, and the parts where you have to jump or speed past a shadowless area while in shadow form. It took me forever to get past them, but I pushed through anyway because I wanted to know how the story would end. Didi is a little girl with the misfortune of belonging to a broken family. Her father is nowhere to be found and her mother is a singer at a nightclub. Dawn is her imaginary friend-slash-babysitter who literally has the ability to walk in the shadows. Together, they try to solve the puzzle that is Didi's true identity and save the day. Speaking of puzzles, those are exactly what this game consists of. You'll have to think your way in, out, and around everything. It pays to be curious as there are collectibles to gather as well. These play a big part in explaining what the story is about. You also need to collect luminaries to power up certain objects. A good tip would be to think out of the box. Some solutions may surprise you and make you go, "Why didn't I think of that before?". I loved the graphics of this game. It's a bit dark, but charming in its own quirky way. It would have been better if they used more musical pieces though. This game is pretty quiet and, therefore, anti-climatic, but you'll be too busy listening to the gears in your head moving anyway, so it's a passable requirement. All in all, the game is a good mix between challenging, fun, and eye-opening. 7/10

Posted: January 22, 2016
 Save the circus, or jump to your death multiple times trying...  ...But it's not just Kat and Johnny's relationship that needs saving, you also get to repair a funfair ! 	Contrast is a fairly short game, which has its charming moments. It's atmospheric and witty but also has a very significant rage potential.	Biggest problems I've had : lack of checkpoints, and the controls are wonky. No, I mean really wonky. If Didi has to rely on an imaginary friend who can't jump onto a box right in front of her, or keeps dashing off the edge of the world and plummeting to her death, that kid had probably better join the circus... but we all know where that got her father...	The plot starts out fine, but the end feels rushed. Was personally expecting a bit more Didi, since she's meant to be the main character. However, I felt like the kid gets left out, both by her family and the game, replaced with quite a bit of fragile masculinity (see Johnny or Fred the Knight), and marriage issues (also Johnny).        On the whole, would recommend Contrast as it's very atmospheric and I loved the concept, but if you're unsure, I suggest waiting until it's on sale. ( + ) Positives  :+ visually pleasing+ great soundtrack+ amazing concept, mixing 2D and 3D+ fun puzzles (others not so much... trial and (t)error) ( - ) Negatives  :- A carousel of broken controls- Tragic lack of checkpoints making the game very much like Kat and Johnny's relationship : very difficult to save.- Game involves explicit language... on my part (mostly because of the previously mentioned points).- Broken fingers (see previous points)- … gurshdarn Fred the Knight

Posted: December 30, 2014
												This is a fun game. Think Portal, if Portal were also Psychonauts.You play as Dawn, an acrobat with the ability to merge into her own shadow - and a curious inability to directly see or be seen by anyone other than Didi. This at first seems like simply an odd quirk, until the ending draws attention to it and refuses to actually offer explanation.The controls are good, if a little more responsive on the camera than I expected. The shadow-merging mechanic could use a little more polish - I often found myself popping out of the wall without being able to figure out why, and occasionally ended up across the room from where I had been a moment prior.The story is simple, which simply leaves more room to showcase the central mechanic and the world. Most characters (seen via projected shadows) talk with their hands a lot, presumably so you can tell who's talking as lips' shadows are very small.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												Contrast is like Bioshock Infinite, but a lot shorter.It revolves around that you as a player can fuse into shadows and move around in it, and by doing so clearing obstacles. You can mess around with objects and light sources to help you with the puzzles, and its a very interesting concept. But in some parts I feel the platforming in the shadows are a little bit clunky, and I have no idea why I would just jump out of the shadows sometimes without hitting any obstacles (well I assume i didnt hit anything).Music is great, voice acting is great, story can be better, controls are a bit awkward at times for both keyboard and controller,Good game overall, short but worth it. Posted: June 18, 2015
												The pros:- The story is fantastic, and the voice acting is well done. The main character, Didi, is particularly good considering her age- The music creates a wonderful atmosphere, and the world is creatively put together. There are fascinating details throughout, that make you want to explore every nook and cranny- The platforming is clever, and for the most part the mechanics work. A few hiccups here and there, but usually there are work-arounds if you're patient enoughThe cons:- It doesn't say a controller is mandatory, but it should. You should be able to get through the first Act with just a mouse and keyboard, but after that it becomes more challenging. A controller will give you the freedom to maneuver that you're looking for.- Exploration is all but banned. Step too far to get a good look at something and a solid road may actually cause you to fall through the world. There's a lot of hand-holding, particularly in the quest objective that you can never remove from the screen. This is a pity, because it's tempting to take a lot of beautiful screenshots, but you can't without "Follow Didi" and "Go back and meet Didi" being scrawled on the upper right-hand side almost constantly.- There are few save points, no checkpoints, and no manual saves. This means that if you break a puzzle (it's possible) then resetting from the last save may put you behind a couple hours' worth of work, forcing you to do conquered puzzles over again.Overall, though, this very a very good game and very imaginative. Since the developers plan to make another game (though not a sequel) it will be interesting to see what they have in store.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												Here are the cliffnotes of a review I wrote for this game elswhere:I’ve had this game on my Steam wishlist for a few months now and decided to grab it during the Winter Sale last week. I’m glad I did because, in retrospect, I wouldn’t have wanted to waste more money than I already did on it.  This is not something that I would call a puzzle game. A puzzle implies that there is an intricate mental test to perform that has a rewarding outcome if you can find and place all the pieces. To solve the puzzles in this game you just have to perform trial and error because there really is no intuitive puzzle to be had. You platform around as a shadow on the wall to perform an arbitrary task and that’s about it. The “puzzle” aspect comes in, I GUESS, when you turn a wheel or press a button and the shadows move and you continue platforming. Maybe it’s that some of the buttons are on timers? I suppose some people would consider that a puzzle……But if you find those people, please, remind them to take the plastic bag off of their head once in awhile. Bottom line: I wouldn’t recommend this game unless you have a big hard-on for platformers….But there ARE better platformers…..Much better. I’ve played about an hour and a half of the game and I’m over half done. I just simply don’t see any point in prolonging the review. I’m probably not even going to get around to finishing this game.

												The atmosphere, soundtrack and story are all good. Posted: December 29, 2014
												In Contrast you play as Dawn, who may, or may not, be the imaginary friend of a young girl called Didi. The game is set in a surreal fantasy city with strong tones of 1920’s Paris. Your role in the game is to accompany and guide Didi on her adventures around the city. The story takes place during a single night when Didi has snuck out, to try and reunite her mother and her estranged father.Contrast is a platform game with environment traversal puzzles. The game is fully 3D, but its unique feature is the ability to shift into the 2D world of shadows cast upon walls. Dawn uses the shadows to reach areas inaccessible in the 3D ‘real’ world.Contrast is a short game, I finished it in two sittings over the course of a weekend. Far from a criticism, the longevity was one of the aspects I appreciated most. It never outstayed its welcome or outlived its enjoyment. Unlike most games I finished it because I enjoyed it and wanted to see how it ended, rather than feeling obliged to grind on to the finish line hours after it ceased being fun.Contrast is also a fairly easy game. No 3D platform game is without a few tricky jumping sections and Contrast is no exception. But I never encountered anything that caused me to quit in frustration and I never felt lost in the game world or became stuck overlong on any particular puzzle. I never encountered any bugs, crashes, glitches or clipping errors during my play through.I enjoyed Contrast, particularly the art style and character design. I have a feeling that I would have enjoyed it less if it had been longer. But as it stands it was the perfect length for me. I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and beautiful platform-game experience that doesn’t require a substantial investment of time.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												I really want to love this game.  It has a great soundtrack, I love the 3d 2d game mechanic, and the story started nice and dark.  I found a few of the puzzles challenging and it felt very rewarding to finish them. What I love more is that when they introduce a new game mechanic there isn't a lot of hand holding that walks you through the puzzle, its mostly trial and error. Unfortunately the controls are very bad and were almost a deal breaker.  I died so many times due to broken controls I rage quit a few times which says a lot; I am not sure how one rage quits multiple times on a 4 hour game.  The story was beautifully dark at first but became whimsical and rather unfulfilling.  The protagonist felt wooden and like she had no purpose except to pull levers.  Of all of the reasons as to why she has this 2d ability and why the world looks so disjointed the actual reason feels lazy, tacked on and overdone.  My last gripe, which feels very nit-picky, is that someone on the team needs to do fact checking.  I don’t know a lot about the 1920’s or quantum physics which made a few of the blunders I did catch that much more jarring.  Grumble grumble.I recommend it if it’s on sale for a couple of bucks.  I couldn't recommend paying full price for it.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												Allow me to shed some light on this for you.Pros:-Accessible and creative art style-Great music-Charming personalities and characterization from start to finish (even if a little thin at times)-Charming atmosphere, overall-Excellent pace; definitely held my attention w/o letting it drag on forever-Spoiler: Oh my goodness the puppet show was so adorable.Cons:-Not very long (~4 hours to near-full completion (100% in-game collectibles, 19/22 achievements))-Engine/mechanics feel a little clunky and never really feel 100% intuitive (but they get the job done, they're responsive, and you can adapt to the flow, even if it feels a little off)-The voice acting and writing can be a little incredulous at times, but not immersion-breaking.Neutral, but notable:-No difficulty settings (not really appropriate for this kind of game type, so, no biggy)-No save function, but automatically saves at chapters-Not incredibly challenging, but has its moments.  Definitely not a hardcore puzzle experience, but not tremendously casual, either-Passable plot--keeps the theme consistent, ties things together, but isn't complicated.Overall, I definitely recommend this.  This would make a great game for someone who wants an atmospheric game with a great pace to story, without too much head-knocking challenge.8/10.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												I'm only making this negative, because I have to give it a recommendation.If my play time doesn't say it all, I don't know what does, I'm already done and only a few achievements short of completion, and I beat this in two days.The game is far too short and is more of a short movie than a video game. The mechanics are not used to their full potential, it's mostly just a 2d platformer with a 3d overworld in between each section. The puzzles are way too easy they never get too complicated. Where this game really shines is in its story and atmosphere, but both of them feel underdeveloped in the short time you're given. I don't want to spoil anything, but a lot of the explanation for what is going on in this game makes no sense, when you really think about it, and after act one the story starts to go downhill. The game really shines in act 2, by far the best part of the game, but it's still way too short, and the puzzles aren't too amazing. I really did enjoy this, but I could never recommend this, I paid three dollars for this, and I don't feel I got my money's worth for it. If you ever do buy this, get it on sale otherwise you're waisting a huge sum of money on a game that will last you 3 hours tops, because the replayability is almost nonexistent.Overall opinion is it's a clever story and mechanic that doesn't live up to it's full potential and is too lacking to be considered much of a game 5/10 won't say you shouldn't buy it, because I did enjoy it, but I could never recommend this to anyone, especially at full price. 												Contrast is very good game and most importantly, it is fun to play. It has several logic puzzles and generally combines adventure with action arcade. Posted: July 5, 2015
												(Note: I completed the game in about four hours while offline, which is why I have no play time.)An enjoyable puzzle/platformer that hinges on the idea of snapping between 3D and a 2D realm in which you can platform areas using the shadows of a surface. Even if the overall level design and physics engine don't always fully utilize this super-cool concept, discovering ways to explore each area between both dimensions is rewarding nonetheless. Surprisingly, I think I enjoyed the game's narrative a bit more: It's a simple yet mature and heartwarming tale of a little girl fighting to keep her estranged family together that's presented in a way that pays homage to 1920s film noir. There are some obvious flaws to Contrast though, most notably the all-too-common ability to get stuck between objects (you can usually free yourself without a lot of hassle, though) and the moments where creativty is marred by archaic box-and-switch puzzles. Still, I think it's a game with a lot of style and a lot of heart.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												This is a good game based on a great concept. The music is lovely, the atmosphere is rich, and the platformer puzzles are lively. Except... the game is too short. I feel like I just started to enjoy the music and story and setting and puzzle concepts, just got into savouring all those tasty bites, and then my plate was empty.Additionally, I'm not a fan of the silent protaganist approach that this game took. With every other character having lively voice acting, the one sided banter between Didi and Dawn falls flat. Finally, while I was okay with the ending, it's not for everyone and further adds to the feeling of our protagonist being an incomplete and two dimensional (heh) character.Do I reccomend this game? Absolutely.  The developers here have executed something new here and that creativity is it's own reward even if you wish there was more depth to the game. If you're unsure about the $17.00 price point, put this game on your wishlist and grab it when it goes on sale.

Posted: July 3, 2015
												This game dares to be different and does some things well, but it would benefit from a longer and less cliché story. The puzzles strike a good balance; not too easy to be boring, but not too challenging to be frustrating. Overall, I appreciate the developer's attempt at a fresh and distinctive title.Things I like: The gameplay, which involves solving puzzles by switching between a shadow 2D world and the 3D world and emphasizes observation and planningThe (noir) art style and (cabaret jazz) music is pleasing to the eyes and earsThere is a bit more depth to the story than what is revealed in the gameplay and I appreciate the effort to flesh out the story. However, I don't like that it requires doing the chore of getting all the collectibles to uncover.Things I dislike:The story is formulaic, the game is short --under 5 hours--, and the in-game world is tiny --it's basically a city block-- with each act fencing the player into a sub-area within that world.The default gamepad movement control (down for upstage and up for downstage) is the opposite of what I expected and there's no option to change it (not in-game, at least). This probably added an hour to my time to beat the game because of mistakes from moving in the wrong direction.There's no replay value. Once you've solved all the puzzles and gotten all the collectibles, there's no reason to return. The dialogs are really corny and stereotypical and make the characters two-dimensional. (pun!)

Posted: July 19, 2015
												Contrast is the arty game that gives arty games a bad name.It's got a really good idea, and squanders it with horrible, unresponsive controls, endless cliche and the kind of poorly envisioned puzzles that make me want to scream at the screen.Bouncing around on umbrellas and canopies may be a fine game element in a goofy 16 bit platformer, but in a game that dresses, speaks and walks as though it wants you to take it seriously, it doesn't fit, and becomes completely unforgivable when the bad controls and the gimmicky linear level design combine to make the trick virtually impossible.There is an achievement for failing a wallrun jump near the beginning of the game, and if you play that section, there is no risk whatsoever of missing the achievement, because the controls for initiating the wallrun are so terrible that even if you do hit the right keys, your character will probably tumble off the world before she realizes you want her to actually do something.Yes, the shadow people are neat, the circus aesthetic is pretty, and running on shadows is a gimmick with a lot of promise; but Contrast is the perfect living proof that a good idea isn't enough to make a good game. I wish it had not been made, so that another developer could have taken on the project, and done it better.I might return to the game just to enjoy screaming at it. This game might manage to be "so bad it's good", depending on your taste. But it's definitely bad.

Posted: August 21, 2015
												This is a very tentative recommendation with some BIG caveats – if you are looking to buy this game, I would recommend getting it on sale, as I did, or borrowing off a friend. The reason for this is that the game feels very half-baked. Contrast is only a couple of hours long, ending before the game’s mechanics have really had a chance to flex their muscles. The story also seems to be truncated and cut down from what was originally intended. Further evidence of the game’s apparent rushed development is its controls and mechanics; the third-person camera controls feel very loose and wobbly, which is, to put it lightly, less than ideal for a game that features platforming as a central mechanic. Combine this with some inconsistent “shifting” controls and some poorly-designed puzzles and you are left with a game that often causes frustration where it should instead inspire satisfaction.So why am I still recommending Contrast in spite of these issues? In short, its central puzzle-platforming system is fascinating, one of the more creative mechanics I have seen in recent memory. As Dawn, the game’s silent protagonist, you have the ability to “shift” yourself and certain objects from the real, 3D world into the 2D world of shadows. This ability is the central focus of the game’s platforming puzzles, which may involve manipulating light sources and shadows to create platforming surfaces in more strategic puzzles, or using the shadows of moving objects to reach an objective in more fast-paced platforming action sequences. This interplay between the worlds of darkness and light forces you, the player, to see the world in a new way by placing shadows (things we often don’t even notice in games or otherwise) at the forefront of a scene. For this reason alone I would recommend this game, if only to game designers looking for interesting ideas.However, their is a second redeeming quality of Contrast and that is the game’s style. The game’s charming aesthetic and focus on playing as a young girl’s imaginary(?) friend can’t help but make you smile. Additionally, its 1920’s setting, a refreshing change to a period not often depicted in video games, provides us with a nice jazzy, big-band soundtrack. What little story there is features some quality voice acting and an intriguing sub-plot - it’s just a shame Compulsion didn’t have the time or resources to flesh the story out further.In summary, Contrast is a game that is full of potential but needed a few more months in the oven to be worth the $15-$20 asking price. However, if you’re looking for something that is short, charming, and original, Contrast may very well be right up your alley.

Posted: August 25, 2015
												Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed playing the game, it was fun, but only for 3 hours. It's just too short! The story starts out all right, then ends too quickly. The gameplay and puzzles are nice, if not a bit easy. Find a wall, become a shadow. You always know what objects to interact with, so you will eventually figure out what to do if you can't see it at once. Shadow world platforming is glitchy at times, the cutscenes could be smoother, but I'd say you need some patience to play puzzle games in general.I wouldn't buy it at the full price, because it's much shorter than expected, but if you are interested in trying something new, get it when it's on sale.Also the brightness/contrast hurts my eyes *hisses and slips into the shadows*

Posted: August 23, 2015
												I recommend the game with this caveat: it's about the experience of an art piece that has a few fun puzzles rather than the game as a whole.Pros:Beautiful art from top to bottom, with music to match.Story is just interesting enough to keep your attention between the likable protagonist and metaphysical plot points.Some genuinely clever puzzles to solve using the unique game mechanics.Cons:Controls/camera are not 100% solid. 												This game features some very clever mechanics, a rather touching story, if a bit 'trope-y', and some great ideas. Basically, it's beautiful to look at, and fun to play... That said, I still recommend it, though not at the full price, it's simply too short for $15. But overall, while it won't blow your mind, it is very cute, endearing, and has some great ideas, and most importantly, it's fun.
