Posted: September 11, 2015
												Allow me to shed some light on this for you.Pros:-Accessible and creative art style-Great music-Charming personalities and characterization from start to finish (even if a little thin at times)-Charming atmosphere, overall-Excellent pace; definitely held my attention w/o letting it drag on forever-Spoiler: Oh my goodness the puppet show was so adorable.Cons:-Not very long (~4 hours to near-full completion (100% in-game collectibles, 19/22 achievements))-Engine/mechanics feel a little clunky and never really feel 100% intuitive (but they get the job done, they're responsive, and you can adapt to the flow, even if it feels a little off)-The voice acting and writing can be a little incredulous at times, but not immersion-breaking.Neutral, but notable:-No difficulty settings (not really appropriate for this kind of game type, so, no biggy)-No save function, but automatically saves at chapters-Not incredibly challenging, but has its moments.  Definitely not a hardcore puzzle experience, but not tremendously casual, either-Passable plot--keeps the theme consistent, ties things together, but isn't complicated.Overall, I definitely recommend this.  This would make a great game for someone who wants an atmospheric game with a great pace to story, without too much head-knocking challenge.8/10.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												I'm only making this negative, because I have to give it a recommendation.If my play time doesn't say it all, I don't know what does, I'm already done and only a few achievements short of completion, and I beat this in two days.The game is far too short and is more of a short movie than a video game. The mechanics are not used to their full potential, it's mostly just a 2d platformer with a 3d overworld in between each section. The puzzles are way too easy they never get too complicated. Where this game really shines is in its story and atmosphere, but both of them feel underdeveloped in the short time you're given. I don't want to spoil anything, but a lot of the explanation for what is going on in this game makes no sense, when you really think about it, and after act one the story starts to go downhill. The game really shines in act 2, by far the best part of the game, but it's still way too short, and the puzzles aren't too amazing. I really did enjoy this, but I could never recommend this, I paid three dollars for this, and I don't feel I got my money's worth for it. If you ever do buy this, get it on sale otherwise you're waisting a huge sum of money on a game that will last you 3 hours tops, because the replayability is almost nonexistent.Overall opinion is it's a clever story and mechanic that doesn't live up to it's full potential and is too lacking to be considered much of a game 5/10 won't say you shouldn't buy it, because I did enjoy it, but I could never recommend this to anyone, especially at full price. Plus any game you can completely and still be eligible to return on Steam is far too short to be considered a game in my mind.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												The main mechanic of the game is very unique and quite fun to wrap your head around. Music is both haunting and enchanting all at once and the visual style is beautiful in an artistic- rather than purely technical, polygonal county way.Controls are responsive though edge detection could use a little polish. There were times when a jump looks like it should've landed but the character 'bumps' the edge and falls. Luckily, the checkpoint system is very forgiving and no more than 5 minutes of progress was ever lost through multitudes of jumping off edges.Level design Is a little inconsistent with a lot of levels containing linear solutions while others allow solutions that skip the entirety of the puzzles via jumping on objects in the 'real world' and dashing into the 'shadow world'. However, this is hard to fault as the shadow mechanics are very complex melding 2D and 3D puzzles across the levels.The way the story is told is very unique as well. Since pretty much all the story is told in the 'shadow world', each scene feels like a snapshot of what's happening with a slight time leap in between each one. The pacing of the story is well enough that it never feels like a drag. There is a drive to see what's next. This is all backed up by some pretty fantastic voice acting with moments of melancholy, angst, and anger delivered with emotion. The developers have left the ending a bit open for interpretation so those who are looking for a clear cut finish where everything is answered will be a bit irked. However, those who enjoy discussing interpretations with others will find a nice conversation with others in the same boat.Though it might be a bit short time-wise, it doesn't artificially inflate the time to beat. So it's enjoyable from start to end.

Posted: January 28, 2015
												If I were to give this game a rating, it would be 5 out of 10. The genre is very intrguing and does very well for being a game where the player does not commit violence. The shadowplay is incredible, the voice acting great, and overall, this game deserves more than 5 our of 10 if it weren't for...The controls and movement. Buggy at best, infuriating at its worst. The player character lurches when changing directions which sends you sailing into the abyss more often than not. Switching from a 3D control style to a 2D control style lends a natural use of the W key for jump but this is not the default mapping. It is a complete world unto itself but does not lend itself to immersion. It is clear that Didi ("diddy", if you prefer, since she's always looking for her real "diddy) is going through her memories either with the help of a friend, an imaginary friend, or as an adult hoping to fix her issues and this surreal landscape lends itself well to that. However, beyond that it is clear that it is a "bubble" world that doesn't really hold you. There's enough missing from the environment and gameplay and world that you constantly realize that this is a game with a story of a dysfunctional set of actors. The puzzles start off very easy and tend to stay that way until the end of the game when an entirely new mechanic with jumps and shadow-merges at a difficulty level previously unencountered is introduced. When going into the lighthouse, you are expected to understand this mechanic and how to use it with no instruction or hints. For a hardcore gamer, this will likely be fine but the gameplay lends itself more to a casual style so this sudden leap in difficulty is jarring and frustrating in and of itself. Once you figure out the difficulty of the new mechanics, however, it becomes little easier to understand. It is not reasonable to use hints that previously indicated an object to interact with as hints for some other part of the mechanic of the puzzle. Changing the rules like that makes the hint system unaffective and almost useless.That said, the storytelling is indeed superb.And finally, this game is far too short and the idea of shadowplay is not explored as well as it should have been. If you want a casual game that requires no real commitment and one or maybe two days play, this game is for you. As a matter of comparison, I played casually and only logged 4 hours on it. I think, however, that gamers of today will be disappointed with the lack of content and linear gameplay. This game feels more like a proof of concept than a finished idea however polished the end product is. This game is worth purchasing but if you pay full price, you're paying too much unless you just want a short distraction and aren't paying attention to cost.

Posted: April 4, 2015
 The Good This game is full of good ideas, and is short enough that you never get bored of the mechanics. The visuals are pretty good, if only a bit washed out, but that's intentional I guess. I actually think the game looks a bit better on "low" because the colour filter is removed, but with it so are the pretty lighting effects. The story is quite compelling, and it has a unique take on interactive story-telling. The music and sounds are nice, fitting and well-implemented, the game-feel is pretty good and for the most part I can recommend this game to anyone who likes puzzle games or platformers... The Bad But I do have one enormous gripe with it. It has an obnoxious tendency to constantly take control away from the player. This is very common with games nowadays but it is so bad here that I got annoyed and stopped playing at one point, just because of it. I don't think there is a single 5 minute stretch of gameplay without a cutscene, or extremely slow camera-pan across a level to point something out. Even standing on buttons triggers a bloody cutscene, and not just the first time; every time. I get that you need to show the player what each button triggers, but it's better to naturally design the level so that the player can notice it in-game. Or at least only have the cutscene play the first time. Most of the triggered cutscenes are there for seemingly no reason, and the game would have looked almost identical if it just played out in-game. Sometimes the game simply freezes you in place while a character speaks with absolutely no camera angle changes.If it wasn't for this one annoying tendency, I would have absolutely adored this game. TLDR Great puzzle-platformer with a unique mechanic. Looks and sounds good, controls well. Unfortunate amount of pointless cutscenes.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												Contrast is a great, non-violent 3D and 2D platformer.Much of the gameplay involves navigating the protaganist Dawn around a 3D 1920s city.  The boundaries of the city are warped in a twisted MC Escher way which is a far more stylish way of focusing the player in the playable space than invisible walls would be.  Dawn is led around this space by another character Didi to various areas where the player is to overcome various platforming puzzles to advance the story.The platforming is very clever.  Against most walls on which shadows are cast, Dawn can phase into the wall becoming a silhouette that can jump on the shadows cast by objects in 3D.  Prior to phasing in, Dawn can interact with objects to move the shadows into more traversable platforms.  She can also phase some 3D objects into the shadows with her to help solve puzzles and reach collectible items.  The 3D navigation is occasionally interrupted with a jittery camera and the player will occasionally pop out of shadows while phased without notice.  It seems the idea is to keep the camera perpendicluar to the wall while phased, but at bends or corners in the wall, this can get tricky.  Other than that, the controls are decent.The story is touching with a focus on family and the characters are unique, except for Dawn who is essentially a mute avatar.  Didi, the child who accompanies and directs Dawn, is adorable and determined to help her father Johnny.  Johnny is the reformed tramp that to whom the player immediately yields his sympathy.  Kat is at her wit's end with the unreliable Johnny as she raises Didi on her own.  Didi's--more so than Dawn's--resourcefulness and her comments--especially during the puppet show--highlight a theme of female empowerment without being heavy-handed in its delivery.I completed this game in four hours and would recommend it, especially at the going rate of a movie ticket.  The energetic Didi helps move the heartwarming story along in a stylish world with many ledges and crannies to explore.  Phasing from 3D into a 2D environment is a treat and the creatvity with which the 2D shadow puzzles were designed is impressive.  Despite camera and control issues in the 2D space, it would have been nice to explore this mechanic with more puzzles, but even so Contrast is a standout title.

Posted: March 17
												Some people play Portal (and its sequel) only for its quirky, witty humor, but Portal is one of my favorite games of all time for another reason: its puzzles. Why do I mention Portal? Because if you enjoy the puzzles in Portal and Portal 2, I think you'll enjoy the puzzles in Contrast.Like Portal, Contrast is a puzzle platformer. The challenge isn't just in getting from Point A to Point B - it's also about HOW. And, like Portal, Contrast adds an exciting twist. The shadow-shifting element is perfectly designed: it's very simple to understand how it works, but figuring out how to use it is challenging and fun. The puzzles aren't tear-your-hair-out difficult, and neither is the platforming skill required, but it's still hard enough to be rewarding when you finally get it right. The game's later puzzles have you manipulating the position of light sources and even shifting objects - like boxes - into the shadow world with you, so the puzzles never get stale.The story is short, but interesting. The voice acting is absolutely superb, especially in scenes where tensions are running high. The world is beautifully crafted, and it really does have a fun 1920s vaudevilleIn summary: I desperately wish there were more of this game. In fact, I think the brevity is my only complaint about Contrast. I hope there's a sequel, or at least another puzzle-platformer from this developer. If you like puzzles, and especially if you liked Portal, you should play this game.

Posted: September 12, 2015
												Few games marry platforing and puzzle elements as well as Contrast. Its shadow mechanic allows for a lot of unique solutions to puzzles, usually requiring the manipulation of the play field to set up platforms or move an object from one area to another. The solutions are fairly intuitive once you get the hang of it, and this keeps the pace of the game brisk. While the game is short (3 hours on my playthrough, with time included for exploration), it's exactly as long as it needs to be for the narrative it's telling. And oh boy, what a narrative. I admire the decision to tell a story of a troubled couple from their daughter's point of view, and to tell it in a highly Expressionist way. The noirish setting, the importance of casting light onto darkness and viewing events through projection and found documents leaves the player (and Didi) questioning the amount of agency they have in shaping the events occuring around them, but as the game progresses the player's actions do push the narrative forward, leaving one wondering if there's some reality-bending at play or if we're just in a land of childish wish fulfillment. The question is left to the player, as the narrative focuses less on making sense of the universe and more on the emotions of its central characters.But the experience isn't without a few drawbacks. While I personally found Didi to be a very compelling character, her constant direction can get tiring, as well as break the difficulty of some puzzles. Her guidance may be helpful for younger players or those inexperienced with 3D platformers, but a seasoned player may find themselves wishing for an option to forgo such a built-in hint system. Whether or not you identify with Didi can make or break the game because of this.The platforming is overall very tight and responsive, and the game grants abilities which ease progression later on. However, it has its moments of challenge which require timing so precise that getting it right may feel more like luck than skill. There is an excellent organic checkpoint system integrated into the mix, so failure is rarely punished and trial-and-error solutions are encouraged, so long as frustration doesn't set in too quickly.On a rare occasion, my character glitched into a wall or other fixture, but jumping/dashing out of them seems to fix the problem. Pros:Interesting, varied platforming and puzzle solving for a unique experience.Tight controls made for a gamepad.Beautiful and thought-provoking visual style.Largely well-acted characters with cheesy, but engaging dialogue.Positive portrayal of a female lead.Cons:Little replay value: collectables are included, but a completionist could grab them all in one playthrough.Difficulty is at parts too easy due to too much direction.Game length may affect one's opinion of its asking price.Overall, I found Contrast a fantastic experience, and certainly one that feels artistically-driven. The story and characters are compelling enough to push you forward without bogging the experience down with overlong cutscenes. Collecting all of the found documents in the game reveals an added light to the game's ending, encouraging exploration and abstract thinking, though the core of the game will be Didi's concerns for her father. If you're willing to forgive a young girl asking a lot of favors of you, the unique style and solid gameplay will make the experience worthwhile.

Posted: September 11, 2015
												I'm only making this negative, because I have to give it a recommendation.If my play time doesn't say it all, I don't know what does, I'm already done and only a few achievements short of completion, and I beat this in two days.The game is far too short and is more of a short movie than a video game. The mechanics are not used to their full potential, it's mostly just a 2d platformer with a 3d overworld in between each section. The puzzles are way too easy they never get too complicated. Where this game really shines is in its story and atmosphere, but both of them feel underdeveloped in the short time you're given. I don't want to spoil anything, but a lot of the explanation for what is going on in this game makes no sense, when you really think about it, and after act one the story starts to go downhill. The game really shines in act 2, by far the best part of the game, but it's still way too short, and the puzzles aren't too amazing. I really did enjoy this, but I could never recommend this, I paid three dollars for this, and I don't feel I got my money's worth for it. If you ever do buy this, get it on sale otherwise you're waisting a huge sum of money on a game that will last you 3 hours tops, because the replayability is almost nonexistent.Overall opinion is it's a clever story and mechanic that doesn't live up to it's full potential and is too lacking to be considered much of a game 5/10 won't say you shouldn't buy it, because I did enjoy it, but I could never recommend this to anyone, especially at full price. Plus any game you can completely and still be eligible to return on Steam is far too short to be considered a game in my mind.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Contrast is one of those games that has a good premise - the idea of use light and shadows to create a separate bit of 2D puzzle gameplay from the normal 3D world, but the implementation from a story and setting as well as design is a bit disconnected.  The technical approach is good in how you can shift in an our of shadows, but the problem is that the areas you can do this in are very limited and separated from each other, making each puzzle its own microcosm.   The puzzles that use this aren't that difficult as well, with the most difficult ones being where you can either move objects to change shadows or the location of the light source. Again, with the puzzles being separate entities, these are one-stop problems as opposed to part of a larger difficult mechanism to figure out.The story is interesting but it's hard to get into and leaves some questions on getting into the characters. Whether this is a fantasy, a dream, or something else isn't clear, and whether it is a flashback or the like.  As such, the game quickly devolves into just moving from puzzle to puzzle with story getting in the way.It is still a decent game, but it's one I'd wait for a sale for, getting about 3 hrs of playtime from it.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												I really like indie games, so when I saw this I thought that the concept was amazing, and it really is, but the fact that it is an indie game is the reason it could do with some work, the soundtrack and style of the game are mesmerizing and the character design has been done well, that's all good. Then there are the aspects that need tweaking, the shadow jumping, platforming and the AI aren't all that good. When attempting to scale or run a wall, the game is too unforgiving, basiclly you get caught on all the little details of a shadow, which may make it seem realistic but no. it gets frustrating. The platforming is also, of course, based around the shadow dimension so you can already guess what I would of said there, another big annoyance is that even though solid objects wouldn't hypothetically affect the dimension of a shadow, in the game, for example, if you try to walk past a pillar on the wall you will generally get thrown out of the shadow world. The last complaint is about the lack of AI for Didi, your young, female companion, whenever travelling from one mission area to another, she will walk exactly where she is programmed to and then stand there for as long as it takes you to get there, making no comments or attempt to follow you around while you search for collectibles (a main feature in the game) or admire the scenery. All together this game is a little expensive for $15, it was a great puzzle experience with an excellent soundtrack and an amazing ending, but for $15 it seems a little expensive. I would give this game an 8/10 and send a request to rename it "Contrast: Prepare to Die Edition"

Posted: December 31, 2014
												Game was really short, not too difficult, and maybe a bit glitchy.  It had an interesting concept but the puzzles aren't that difficult to figure out once you figure out all the items at your disposal.  You could do alot with the game but it didn't really last long enough to really amaze me with a whole lot.  Phasing into the shadows is fun but its annoying getting kicked out of the shadows when it seems like you should be fine.  At one point during the Merry-go-round, there was clearly open space that kept kicking me out of the shadows for no reason, and after going around and taking another route, it stopped doing it.  There's far more that could be done than simply putting boxes into the shadows, then moving the spotlight around.  Outside of getting kicked out of the shadows at random sometimes, the puzzles aren't overall too difficult to figure out once you pick out every option at your disposal.  The last stage introduces the idea to focus the spotlight but you cant keep it focused and is only used to raise a box higher and its only used once.  Its fairly useless to introduce something out of nowhere just to solve one puzzle, especially since you need to tell the player the controls so you're basically telling them what to doOn top of getting forced out of the shadows at odd times, the models for the shadows are clearly screwed up.  Johnny's hat is often floating half off of his head, the character's limbs seem to disconnect, and you can see glitches like this even with Dawn in the shadows.  It was most noticable when you had to float down on an umbrella and it disappeared whenever I faced a specific direction.The game overall seemed a bit like Vincenzo's act in the end.  His act seemed cool but I could only see the shadows of it, and it was also over very quickly.  In fact, he seems to hint that there may be monsters in the Shadows that could prove to be an obstacle for Dawn but its never followed up on cause all thats left to do in the game is follow Didi then its over.  The game was very interesting, especially for the concept, but again, it only took 2 hours to complete.  Judging from the other reviews, it seems I may have gotten it down quickly, but in order to get 10 hours of gameplay, you would have to be looking for every luminary and every collectable, or have played through the game multiple times.  The game does have some good music and a good story, but its far too short and gameplay wise, not interesting enough to be worth the $17 (canadian) it costs normally.  I got it during a sale but even then, there's other games you could spend your money on instead

Posted: December 31, 2014
												Its a unique game, the shifting into the shadows gameplay is it's major selling point but it also has quite nice art, music and storyline.  As some of the other reviews hinted - everything in this game is really good but it's lacking some tiny bit of extra wowfactor which would really make it amazing.  I didn't find any terrible bugs.  But it does have issues, sort of like you would expect an infinite possibility sandbox environment to have issues.  It uses the dynamic shadows cast by the graphics engine as part of the gameplay, and sometimes that isn't going to work out right as there's just too many possible shadows that can be created.  I imagine it's damn near impossible to test properly as shadows can be different in a thousand ways.  The shadow play can be a bit annoying as you fall out of the shadows and back into the 3D world a little too easily.  And once (spoiler!) I shifted an item with me into the shadows and managed to lose it completely somewhere.. take care of your precious metal balls! :)But anyway, the game is short and sweet, play it if you like unusual games.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												Here are the cliffnotes of a review I wrote for this game elswhere:I’ve had this game on my Steam wishlist for a few months now and decided to grab it during the Winter Sale last week. I’m glad I did because, in retrospect, I wouldn’t have wanted to waste more money than I already did on it.  This is not something that I would call a puzzle game. A puzzle implies that there is an intricate mental test to perform that has a rewarding outcome if you can find and place all the pieces. To solve the puzzles in this game you just have to perform trial and error because there really is no intuitive puzzle to be had. You platform around as a shadow on the wall to perform an arbitrary task and that’s about it. The “puzzle” aspect comes in, I GUESS, when you turn a wheel or press a button and the shadows move and you continue platforming. Maybe it’s that some of the buttons are on timers? I suppose some people would consider that a puzzle……But if you find those people, please, remind them to take the plastic bag off of their head once in awhile. Bottom line: I wouldn’t recommend this game unless you have a big hard-on for platformers….But there ARE better platformers…..Much better. I’ve played about an hour and a half of the game and I’m over half done. I just simply don’t see any point in prolonging the review. I’m probably not even going to get around to finishing this game.

Posted: November 29, 2014
												I really liked Contrasts style, and the puzzles weren't too hard (though the carousel I messed up on a tonnnnn of times). The shadow animations weren't always that great, the controls were a bit wonky at times, and the story wasn't that unique. But, the level design I liked--the pirate ship and the entrance to the puppet stage the most, though there wasn't really anywhere in the world that didn't look nice. Dawn is a really pretty character, and that aspect was well-displayed in her model, but Didi was kind of...gross-looking? Her textures were messed, her overall model looked wonky, and it didn't seem as much care was put into making her as there was for Dawn. Being that Didi is the only other character you see in the game that isn't a shadow, and being that she's a much more essential piece to the story of Contrast than Dawn, she should look much better all-around. I get that it might be tougher as she's playing out a string of specific animations, but there could have at least been an 'inside' to her mouth, instead of a weird, shallow, flesh-colored concave that you have to look at each time she speaks.I almost 100%'d Contrast on the first try, and it only took a couple hours to play, so I can definitely say that as the game stands I'd play it again.

Posted: October 30, 2015
												Bought this game for under 4 bucks thanks to the Halloween sales and honestly, I don't regret it.The artistic direction of Contrast is beautiful, the characters are well developped and the story is pretty catchy. Posted: July 7, 2014
												Contrast is a very well-done and innovative Indie game. It falls into the puzzle genre, but utilizes first-person character control and does require a bit of speed.Like all games, Contrast has its merits and pitfalls. Some things I really liked about the game are:- A very well-thought-out and touching story- Beautiful soundtrack (especially "Kat's Song". Youtube it!)- A unique gameplay mechanic- Some decently challenging puzzles- Beautifully done art. Many noir games and movies nowadays are just creepy and Sin City-like. This is a much more refreshing take on the noir theme.And some things that weren't so great:- I don't know anyone who has clocked more than 10 hours to beat this- Some minor bugs- a reference to Albert Einstein in an earlier time period (learn your history, people!)Simply put, Contrast is very well-done and a must-buy for any Indie fan. People who liked story-intensive games such as Bastion will definitely enjoy Contrast more than most. Of course $15 for a game this short may pinch wallets, so do wait for a sale. And of course, we hope to hear of a second game from Compulsion Studios soon. =D

Posted: October 26, 2015
Overall Appeal - 5/5The premise of the game is fantastic. Being a character that only a child can see but still being able to change the real world is quite fun and amusing. The puzzles are not always straight forward... it's not always as easy as 2D vs 3D... sometimes you have to dig deep.Fun Factor -  4/5Can't really say much without giving it away. It was, at times, incredibly annoying. But no matter how much I hated it at the time I turned it off, I always came back.Replay Value - 1/5Unfortunatly, I believe this is one of the few areas where this game fails. Though the game is awesome, the only replay would be collectables missed in your previous playthrough.Presentation/Graphics - 4/5The game didn't make use of all the mechanics available to it... but that's okay... It wasn't meant to. It's done in a depression era art kind of way and is part of it's appeal. Fluidity of the transition between 2D and 3D was nice. The only complaints I had were that, at one point, an object I needed started floating above me where I couldn't reach it and had to reload and near the end, as I started to fall (to my death, I missed a ledge).... just stopped... couldn't jump, couldn't fall, couldn't move. Other than those two things, marvolous.Storyline - 4/5Don't get me wrong, the story in, and of, itself was absolutly flawless. I loved the backgroud (loved the ending even more). My only complaint is that it was too short. The game could have been a little longer (maybe 5-10 more hours of gameplay).Summary/Overall Score - 3.6 of 5Overall, a solid game. If I am to read the game correctly, I expect another. I do hope that, if true, the sequal will be a little more developed and incoorporate a longer storeyline, more gameplay, and an answer to the question thrown in our faces at the end. I would reccomend this, if only to help the developer to make a new one and continue this intriguing story.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												Don't think of this as a game per-se. Think of it more like an interactive film and you probably won't be disappointed. Also - get it on sale. It takes 4-5 hours to complete, getting all achievements, and it's a pleaesant ride.The noir tone of the game is fun without getting really dark. It stays squarely within the child's perspective. Visually, this game is fantastic. The plot keeps you engaged, but isn't anything special.The mechanics are pretty solid and controls work well (assuming you're using a controller and not keyboard / mouse - haven't tried those). It can occasionally be tricky to figure out what you need to do, but it's nothing anyone should have that much trouble with.As long as you go into this from the perspective of a brief sojourn into a gorgeous fantasy world, you won't be disappointed. The closest game I'd compare this to is Papo & Yo. They both sort of feel like a day in the life of a child, although that one's a touch more fleshed out. Both are good.

Posted: January 8, 2015
												Good Game, good history, nice atmosphere! But it has drawbacks. The game has some interesting mechanics. You can basically change between your "3D form" and the "shadow form". The main aspect of the game is to figure out your way through the puzzles with this shadow form to proceed through the history. The gameplay is not the best and I found some "bugs" (some ways to complete the puzzle that the developer did not intend, like climbing a vertical wall by getting stuck into it). But the main problem (in my opinion) was the fact that the puzzles aren't difficult (there isn't really any challenge on the puzzles for myself at least). I would like to see what they can do with this interesting mechanic in a bigger game.Is it worth the money they ask for? Well it is a really short game (near 4 hrs for me) but for the atmosphere that this game submerged me, it was worth.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Contrast is a beautiful and entertaining game. I found the environment, story and gameplay very intriguing from the get-go. As the game progresses the puzzles get more difficult and challenging, in mind as well as execution, just the way I like it. One could argue it was borderline too short, but fit me and my current schedule well enough. As for something negative I believe they could have elaborated the ending. If finding the all collectables, finds throughout the game giving hints and details to the story, you are able to realise the big mystery and thus get the ending. But I feel like the developers relied to heavily on finding the collectables being the "big giveaway" and surprise factor that the ending just felt a bit anticlimactic. It was a shame as the game had been bold and exciting up until that point. Either way it's a game I truly recommend. If you have a thing for puzzles, are fascinated by the 20's and/or like good soundtracks I believe you should give it a go.

As it is, both are not really that great.I often found myself skipping the cut scenes because I was bored and just wanted to finish the game as fast as possible.On the other hand the puzzles seemed awefully contrived in their environment. Posted: November 30, 2014
												8/10Cool game with pretty graphics, great and atmospheric music, a unique gameplay mechanic making for fun puzzles, and a neat little story. Only rating it an 8/10 however because of bugs and other issues (note: my computer exceeds the recommended requirements and played the game fine on high settings). At times, Dawn will slide around at high speeds or suddenly stop moving due to some invisible obstruction. That's annoying while walking down the middle of the road, but downright frustrating when trying to solve puzzles, especially while in shadowland. These movements sometimes cause Dawn to shift out of shadows at inopportune times as well, requiring restarting entire puzzles. The worst issue, however, are the occasional times when something that is supposed to sparkle (such as an item that can be used or a collectible) does NOT sparkle, and thus can't be used. Collectibles don't stop you from completing the game, but the usable items not sparkling certainly will. I was able to solve this issue by restarting the game, but it's still annoying and meant lost progress. All in all though, I would still recommend Contrast.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												Though visually stunning and in employ of a very interesting game mechanic I'd never seen before-- the manipulation of lights in order to traverse through a shadow-world to allow the player access to areas that are otherwise unreachable,-- I felt that these two points were not enough to make up for the amount of glitches and the weak plot that I found in an otherwise palatable game. For the amount I bought it for, I felt this game was not polished very well, and it certainly doesn't help that the secondary character you follow was written in a very annoying manner. Noir games are often hit-or-miss because of the amount of stereotypes the genre builds upon, and Contrast followed the routine noir atmosphere and plotline.In short, this was a very imaginative game, but I don't see myself going back to it for another playthrough. I would recommend it for the shadow/light manipulation, however.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												Contrast is a puzzle platformer that combines 3D and 2D gameplay to its problems, while telling a story of a family going through a crisis in a 1920's dreamlike bohemian Paris. Mixed with the story are some fantasy mysteries of other realities and a tiny bit of film noir gangsters. To top it all the game has pretty nice, if fairly short, soundtrack with some sultry jazz.The game lacks some depth, hardly any of the mysteries introduced are explained, and game mechanics could have used some tweaking. Despite that, Contrast is a nice short little game with a unique setting and interesting ideas that could carry on for some deeper exploration. For its regular price the game is short, but it is something to consider if one is after a light puzzle platformer.

Posted: February 21, 2015
												Contrast is an incredibly well written and well implemented platform/puzzler.  All accented by an incredible sound track.  While it certainly has some control issues from time to time, none I encountered were game breaking.  It is also incredibly short, finished in only a few hours.  But, the unique mechanics never over-stay their welcome.  Each chapter builds upon previous chapters' lessons, allowing the player to experience something new while not feeling like their previous lessons were wasted.  The story is surprisingly deep, even if it feels a little rushed from the player's perspective.  Overall, even at full price, it’s a great buy if you like platform/puzzlers.  On sale, it’s a definite buy for anyone wanting something different and new, that won't eat too much time.

												It's an alright platformer where you can merge with shadows to solve puzzles (e.g. placing a box in front of a light source to cast a huge shadow, then jumping on the box's shadow to reach a platform). Posted: May 4, 2014
												Beautiful piece of bliss to play. Charming story, characters and atmosphere, and astoundingly good music. The game in itself is rather short, but personally I find that that's part of the whole "magic" of it. It's sweet, and touching, but it doesn't get boring with needless hours of repetitive gameplay. Speaking of which, the whole jumping in and out of the "shadow dimension" is amazing. Awesome idea, really difficult to implement. The quality of this game in general is dazzling. Contrast had me with a dumb smile on my face whenever I wasn't frowning over a particularly challenging shadow puzzle (yes, Vincenzo, I'm looking at you and your lab). I sincerely loved this game and would recommend it to anyone, even if you aren't really a puzzle fan. The music alone makes it worth it. And if jazz ain't your cup of tea, the story and the atmosphere ought to do the rest. Truly, truly a jewel. I am forever in debt with my past self for spending the twenty bucks it cost me then (I got myself the collector's edition, with the soundtrack and stuff).

Posted: May 8, 2014
												This game was quite odd. As a game its nothing special; it would even be fair to say its gameplay is just bad. I often felt as though I tricked trough some levels by takng advantage of the hit-and-miss gameplay like making jumps that would avoid the puzzles. The stories execution is equally questionable, with a protagonist who serves to guide you through the game without any real finesse. And by that I don't mean your character; you seem to serve more as a tool for her tasks but that is the point.TO THE GOOD!This game had a very specific feel about it which I felt made it worth playing. The art style and music marry so well together that I forgave the shaky gameplay (at least for the most part). Depite its dodgy execution, I got what it was trying to show and it made for an enjoyable experience. The story wasn't as linear as what I've come to expect; whether thats a good or bad thing, im not entirely sure. Its fair to say Didi (the young girl) was a bit 'pushy' in trying to force you into the story, but I didnt really mind as my character is there to help her and the interactions of the character felt right for the situation.Theres plenty to find out beyond the game through exploration. I actually think these bits were what made the game as it added another level of story beyond Didi's life to something more personal for the character Dawn (who never speaks IIRC), also - great name without being something cheesy. I would throughly recommend you endevour to find the 20(I think?) hidden media snippets! It reminded me of Bioshock in that the information you find explains the situation youre in; but in a modest way.This game however is by no means difficult! I did the entire story in a single 2 hour sitting and found everything in that time. This wasn't even deliberately to finish it, I just felt like the game never lost traction and felt so, almost, calm to play that I kept casually playing. This isnt to say the story was good; it was weak with the hidden snippets making it interesting but it was solid enough in terms of character and situation.Overall, as someone who does try to game as much as possible, I can't honestly say its a great game. But for me, it was incredibly playable and I will revisit it again gladly. It was like listening to music, I did indeed just easily loose track of time and do it. I found it quite charming if I'm being honest.I played it with a controller if that means anything? You wont need the precision or focus of a kb+m but thats just my preference for this game. I would also say if youre on the fence about it, its probably best you wait till a sale comes around. I don't think I paid full price and despite enjoying it, don't know if its worth it. Definately feels like it should be £6.99 or similarly priced. Wouldn't be upset if I did pay retail though.

Posted: April 4, 2015
 The Good This game is full of good ideas, and is short enough that you never get bored of the mechanics. The visuals are pretty good, if only a bit washed out, but that's intentional I guess. I actually think the game looks a bit better on "low" because the colour filter is removed, but with it so are the pretty lighting effects. The story is quite compelling, and it has a unique take on interactive story-telling. The music and sounds are nice, fitting and well-implemented, the game-feel is pretty good and for the most part I can recommend this game to anyone who likes puzzle games or platformers... The Bad But I do have one enormous gripe with it. It has an obnoxious tendency to constantly take control away from the player. This is very common with games nowadays but it is so bad here that I got annoyed and stopped playing at one point, just because of it. I don't think there is a single 5 minute stretch of gameplay without a cutscene, or extremely slow camera-pan across a level to point something out. Even standing on buttons triggers a bloody cutscene, and not just the first time; every time. I get that you need to show the player what each button triggers, but it's better to naturally design the level so that the player can notice it in-game. Or at least only have the cutscene play the first time. Most of the triggered cutscenes are there for seemingly no reason, and the game would have looked almost identical if it just played out in-game. Sometimes the game simply freezes you in place while a character speaks with absolutely no camera angle changes.If it wasn't for this one annoying tendency, I would have absolutely adored this game. TLDR Great puzzle-platformer with a unique mechanic. Looks and sounds good, controls well. Unfortunate amount of pointless cutscenes.

Posted: May 24, 2015
												the game is beautiful. the artwork was great, and the music was pretty good. the atmoshere of the game though is intriguing which was one if it's best characteristics. you always have questions on your mind about the world you are in. not many games are like that. you just accept where you are and play the game. not this one though. i was always wondering where i was and trying to guess why things were the way they were. the only problem i could find with the game was that the ending was rushed and things left unanswered:the story was pretty short, which wasn't a bad thing, but the details on what happened and were you were wasn't "concretely" explained. you you have to figure it out yourself with collectables, which you find throughout the game which did pretty much tell you, but it wasn't enough for me. i guess i wanted more back story for your character and the world you are in. there are a lot of questions on my mind about everything. maybe i'm just over thinking it, but i really liked the setting of the game, it's characters, and what was going on so i want to know everything haha.the ending also left on one of those "cliffhangers" where you know there isn't going to be a next time, but something happened that you want to see more, and it pisses you off because it kind of makes it seem like there is going to be a sequel which will go into more detail about what just happened, but you know there won't be one.[POTENTIAL SPOILER] as for being rushed, i guess i just don't like how fast and easily everything wrapped up with the family due to the circumstances and their past......its hard to describe with out any spoilers.over all, it was a very enjoyable game and i'm glad i bought it. i would like a sequel with more detail about the characters and setting.

Posted: May 12, 2015
												Contrast is a game I can't help but really enjoy. A new mechanic done in an interesting way couched in gorgeous art direction can really make up for rather stilted... everything else. The concepts are there. The skill level is there. What's lacking is the actual execution.It comes across the worst is the dialogue - decent lines read by good voice actors come across with too little impact simply because the delivery wasn't quite right, the pacing not quite right. The music is spare and doesn't serve much to hype whatever's going on, and many scenes feel bare without it. This is all a shame, because clearly there's something going on here - the dreamlike world, the shadow-people, the family drama. All of this is sorely under-embellished. There's no weight or time given for these scenes, no gravity - except for when you're jumping through them (which I actually found really neat!)But what IS there is largely delightful. Didi has pep and zing, even if her voice actress is a little bit unpleasant to listen to. I was more than happy to help Didi make a change in her family's life and make their business her business with an aplomb and positively not often seen in games. The environment is fun to explore in and has a wonderful feel.Oh and the gameplay is fun and okay.There's a solid 3-4 hours of gameplay here - you decide what that's worth. I enjoyed this different kind of tale told in a different kind of way, and I'm very eager to see how this developer will grow in future games.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												How and where to begin this review? Like most story driven games, I shall begin with the plot and the setting. Both of these strive very well indeed; however, due to the game's short length (roughly four hours for me), the story unravels greatly towards the end. You can see where Compulsion Games were wanting to go with it, but unforunately the developers were told to wrap it up, and it shows in Act III.It was disappointing because the noir setting was surperb, and the story soars in Acts I and II. The music and voice acting are top notch. I also loved the idea of Dawn being an imaginary friend and the concept of traveling from the real world to the shadow world.However, the controls in this game is what did it for me. The game is a platformer, which I admit that I am okay at them. Dawn would not stop getting stuck on little things or would pop out the shadow world even when there weren't any conflicting shadows nearby. There were also numerous times in which you should be able to jump onto a simple ledge in the 3D world that was only waist high; however, Dawn would refuse to jump onto it. And due to the game's short length the puzzles weren't that hard to solve. The mouse is what controls your camera angle, and it felt like you had to barely move it or else everything goes haywire.All in all, Contrast is a game that had so much potential and soars through the air in the first two Acts. Then, it faceplants in the third act. I did buy this during the Steam Summer, so for just $7.99 (got the soundtrack as well) I did get my money's worth....just wished that there were tighter controls and a longer game length.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												While "Contrast" is certainly not a "AAA" game - the gameplay is a little rough around the edges in ways that can put a hitch in some of the platforming puzzles, and the graphics look like they belong a generation earlier - it's filled with style and atmosphere that invokes Tim Burton, focused gameplay, and a feel that throws back to the earlier days of 3D platformers that kicked up a nice nostalgia trip.And it has some strong thematic similarities to Bioshock Infinite.Having clocked about 3 hours in it from start to finish, for what it is, the length feels just about right. This is a game you play for the overall experience, so it does what it wants to do without overstaying its welcome.Cool game.

Very imaginative creations. On the other hand, a few puzzles were a bit frustrating because of the picky mechanics and I found myself forgetting simple things like how to climb because I was busy with shadow walking. Overall it was worth the buy.

Posted: August 12, 2014
												I'm a sucker for engrossing environments, and poking around through Contrast's surroundings feels like perusing a Dali exhibit at times. While you're enjoying the ambience, there's a story about a little girl with family troubles that likes to sneak around at night. You play as her mute shadow-friend, swapping between 3Dspace and the 2D shadows cast upon the world.The puzzles are fairly straightforward, although some will take a bit of experimentation. Solving them is less about flipping switches and more comparable to turning the hands on a clock to the correct time: it's difficult to get them in the precise orientation for success, but more often than not you'll get "close enough." As a result of this, a good number of the puzzles left me feeling like I'd somehow found an alternate, unintended solution from point A to B. This was actually the case once or twice, as I had found a way to sneak past a goal and into the next room with no way to continue since I didn't take the expected route. Reloading a previous save and checking online for the actual solution was my workaround that one time. I've uploaded a screenshot of this area so you don't get stuck like I did.The shadow-swappy controls are fun, and the game doesn't overstay its welcome, being relatively short to complete (give or take if you go find the hidden locations of stuff). There aren't any badguys to shoot here, and it's a fairly comfy game despite its flaws.

Posted: August 13, 2014
												I loved the aesthetic and puzzle-like gameplay of Contrast. Though the story wasn't particularly complicated, it was well-executed and pulled all the right heartstrings. I only wish it were a little longer!

Posted: August 10, 2014
												Contrast is a very short game, even without much hurry it can be finished within 4-6 hours. Might be worth waiting for the next Steam Sale. Nevertheless, Contrast is what I call "art". The game is sparkling with creativity. The initial idea of switching from 3D "surreal reality" to 2D where you become a shadow and walk on shadows is clever and fun. This is what the game is mostly about: solving riddles and tasks by making use of light and shadow, mixed with a lovely story. The world of Contrast is beautiful and very atmospheric and a bit bizarre at the same time. It's pretty much like a dream. The art design, both graphics and sound, is just wonderful, and I very much enjoyed my trip through this game. A short adventure, but clearly one to remember.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												Contrast: Endgame Review(TL:DR Quick 'n' Dirty Version: Love it despite its faults. Worth supporting the developers even if just on sale) I'll be honest - I went in prepared to love the sshit out of this game. The artwork was sublime, the music was orjazzmic and the concept was brilliant. Venturebeat had me at "It's as if Limbo and Bioshock Infinite had a baby while watching Pan's Labyrinth" - given that I'd just finished Limbo, and, well, I'm sure my avatar tells you all you need to know about Infinite. Unfortunately, however, Contrast is not without its flaws, like the characters the game adeptly depicts. The story was well paced and engaging and there were some genuinely clever puzzles in the piece, but an overuse of cut-scenes and needlessly fiddly gameplay detracted from the overall satisfactory experience.You play as Dawn, nine-year-old Didi's imaginary friend. Dawn helps Didi solve puzzles and navigate a troubled maze of family relationships by manipulating light and shadow in a sometimes third-person 3D puzzly, sometimes 2D-ish platformy, surreal depiction of the interwar era. The game marries the music of the Jazz Age with high-contrast film noir aesthetics and archetypes, and largely makes this work. It just looks and sounds beautiful, and the voice acting is realistic and moving, especially Didi. There were lots of things the designers managed to get right - little things I really appreciated, like colour-coding the on-screen button prompts (Call me crap, but I'm still SO confused with the XBox buttons because they're the wrong way around from Super Nintendo!) or making it optional to collect everything, but easy to go back; this goes for Luminaries and collectibles. The final puzzles were immensely satisfying; I successfully put to use everything the game had taught me, which meant the learning curve was well thought out. Another thing was the inclusion of the soundtrack and a PDF of the collector's booklet. And now for the whinge. The plot was engrossing, but I got sick to death of being interrupted by cut-scenes every few nanoseconds. The developers, again, got things right by making these skippable, but I felt I couldn't skip them anyway because I didn't want to miss the story. This and the way the camera kept getting yanked out of my control while trying to solve puzzles were some of the irritating aspects of the game: these interruptions kept breaking the flow so that things never really settled into a decent rhythm. The consequence was that, when it came time to jump around, some of the puzzle-solving was quite hard to execute. I opted for a controller over keyboard and mouse, but wasn't entirely satisfied with either option. Shadow-world play is really fiddly; the camera doesn't neatly snap to a 2D view for this mode and I was forever accidentally leaping off into space and having to try again because of this. A lack of micro-save exacerbated the problem. When not in shadow mode, the camera was at times so far up Dawn's bum it was nigh-on impossible to have a good look round for problem-solving, and at other times I'd solved the puzzle mentally but found the solution needlessly difficult to perform... Why have little bumps on the wall just to break you out of shadow mode and make it more difficult? For other puzzles, there was no intermediate feedback to show when the player was on the right track; the light had to be in exactly the right spot or things didn't work, and I had no idea whether I was right in theory or just all wrong. The game's physics also seemed inconsistent; there were loads of times when it looked like Dawn could easily make a certain jump, but wouldn't. I found all this incredibly frustrating to the point of controller-biting and rage-quitting, actually... But Contrast wasn't all bad. As infuriating as the negatives were, the narrative was sustaining with its emphasis on family and dysfunctional relationships. I enjoyed the fact that the characters, though archetypal, were flawed individuals making the best of their respective situations -  a contemporary theme that will resonate with any mature, thinking player. Add it to your wishlist and grab it next time it pops up on sale; you'll enjoy the cheap quickie.

												The music and voice acting are top notch.  It is an interesting concept and fairly well done.The only problem I have with it is that there are some weird glitches and bugs that will basically cause you to have to restart a level from the beginning. Posted: October 12, 2014
												Contrast is game that I liked, but I can easily see why some people might dislike it, and why it got so low score on Metacritic. 1) GameplayContrast comes up with a great concept, but it's been poorly made. The idea of changing from 2D to 3D really inovates (even though there was already a game that came with a concept a lot like that called Perspective, it's a f2p game, go and check it yourself), and brings lots of great moments, but also buggy ones. There were moments where the puzzle wasn't the challenge it self, but the glitches.There were also mechanics that could have been more exploited.2) Art/ Soundtrack/ VoiceactingThe atmosphere of the game is well built by the scenario and the sound track, art desgin really fit's in, but there are problems. The animations weren't much organic (and seem really half baked), there were buggy shadows and some halfbaked props, missing collison on places where it clearly should have something. The voice acting actually impressed me. It's not exceptional, but it fits in to the characters really nicely.3) StoryThe story of Contrast may be for some one of the strogesnt points, but I have to disagree a little bit on that one.The story really intrigued me, and it really got me thinking, but there were some really strange moments. Sometimes it's to obvious that the developers didn't have in mind much about the story, only about the gamplay. But it's a nice story, and the gap for theories are wide open for interpretetions. There are some people making some deep theories, but to  be honest, I don't think they really thought about all that. 4)Conclusion:It's a nice expirience, but it seems like the game was rushed, it's short and there are lots of things that could have been more polished. It's worth a try

Posted: October 13, 2014
												Now here's a unusual game.  I'm all about the story. For me a game can get away with average gameplay and a great story, but this game does well in both aspects, great story and great gameplay. Add to that the great artwork, a noir atmosphere, some sad jazz tunes, and you have a game worth keeping.I'm still about halfway through (I suppose). But I've been hooked onto this game. You get to play a silent protagonist who can shift from the real world and into shadows. Shifting into a shadow makes you able to use shadows as a 2D platforms to traverse otherwise impossible to cross areas. You can use shadows as bridges or a sort of transportation device. In the real world (or should I say 3D), you get around just like any 3D platforming game. While in 3D mode you can move objects or light sources to arrange shadows in a way that could help you through some obstacles. The combination of 3D and 2D platforming make for interesting puzzles and a unique gameplay. Definitely, a game worth buying, sale or no sale.

Posted: October 13, 2014
												Contrast is nothing short of a work of art. The atmosphere immerces you right away as the art style, astounding music and the overall world feeling come together in fleshing out the film noir setting. The game mechanic is also very interesting, sure to satisfy both those who look for a puzzle and those who enjoy platforming, and if you like exploring and collectables you're gonna find plenty of that as well. Special mention to the sound track that might be worth the game price by itself if you're into that kind of music.

Posted: October 13, 2014
												A stunning game. Brilliant concept backed up by some really nice graphics. The storyline is so engaging that I found it hard to put down. The puzzles were often a touch of genius. Not that they were difficult, only one or two stumped me and even then only for a short while. The genius is in the way they suck you into the story a little more each time. Especially the 'flashback' puzzles which can be tricky but never frustrating because the scene you are replaying is always a poignant moment in the story.The soundtrack sets the tone just right and the voice acting is spot on. In particular Teale Bishopric was amazingly good as Didi.Yes I have a few gripes. Jumping could be frustrating at times because it's a little to sensitive to collisions and it would have been nice to be able to customize the key mapping but that's about it.It's a short game but one I will remember for a long time. I think it's almost the perfect length for the story. Yes I would have liked more but that's because I enjoyed it so much.

Posted: October 14, 2014
												Contrast is a platformer/puzzle game with good graphics and a fair story. I can honestly say if it is patched and expanded on it could lead to something really great. As a stand alone game it shows heart in design and creativity. It is not without its faults it that collision could be a little finicky and the story is not tremendously detailed but i guess you can say that is the charm of the game. Its a simple game with plenty of heart and a small price tag so that anyone can afford it. If your looking for a long game with alot of story look else where but if your looking for a simple game with a creative way of looking at things then pick it up. its worth it.

Posted: October 15, 2014
												In short: this is a little gem. It is clearly a work of love from some caring people.That said it is also 'little' as in very short.Contrast has innovative gameplay and a good 'girl and family story' set in a very well presented 20's environment. (though kind of missed out on the meaning of the ending ). One of the main characters has an eery resemblance to Tesla by the way.I picked this up in last weeks sale for just under 4,-. I guess it is worth a bit more, but in hind-sight happy that's what it cost me.Basically once finished there is no real replay value. Posted: November 16, 2013
												Despite the easy puzzle difficulty (just don't overthink it), it's one of those feel-good games that has relatable characters, a unique surreal art style, and good-for-what-it's-worth game mechanics.The bugs are noticeable, but given the small development team, that shouldn't be a surprise to everyone.  The puzzles are easy, given that I beat the game in around 2-3 hours.  They can be hard if you don't know what you're doing, tho. Posted: December 24, 2013
												Contrast has you swapping between 2d and 3d platforming on the fly as your character has the ability to meld into walls with high "contrast" lighting. Shadows become navigable platforms that allow you to reach places other wise inaccesible. As you can imagine this creates some interesting puzzles involving moving objects around in 3d space to create your own path way from shadows. The puzzles throw a few monkey wrenches in to try to keep the mechanic from getting stale, but cant maintain the same sense of accomplishment in discovering new way of thinking for the entire 4-5 hour experience.The story does a good job at keeping you interested in the game. You follow a girl and her "imaginary" friend as they try to piece together her parents failing relationship. It takes a bit of a weird turn towards the end but it doesn't ruin the rest of the game.It's worth a look if your into platformers at all. Even with the market seemingly flooded with them this one has enough original ideas to float above the rest.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												A very charming puzzle-platformer with a very impressive motif and soundtrack. The story of the game largely revolves around a broken family trying to piece itself together and is at its best when it focuses on their trials and tribulations. (It takes a weird turn near the end trying to answer questions I never asked about the broken shadow dimension that protagonist Dawn inhabits that just end up raising even more questions, but that treads into spoiler territory.) Manipulating shadows so that Dawn can become a shadow and platform across them proved to be an interesting challenge that had me scratching my head more than a few times, and they were never afraid of introducing new elements (even if some of those elements involved box-switch puzzles seen in many games before). The game is definitely a bit on the short side, however, and the only thing that kept me from clearing it 100% on my first run was a few collectibles and one item that was only available for a short time frame and ended up being lost forever. It's also very story-focused, and relies heavily on cutscenes to tell its tale. Overall, it's definitely flawed (probably rushed a bit to be a PS4 launch title), but it's an enjoyable game that should be tried.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												A good experience from beginning to end. The music and art style of the game is probably what sold it to a lot of people and it is endearing as is the voice actor for the young girl.There are some frustrating moments with the gameplay where it does seem a bit janky and encountered a couple of glitches which required a reload of a chapter but overall still very enjoyable and nice to see some experimentation with new platform mechanics.Story was good and leaves you wondering about certain points during the game even if some small parts come across as cliche the fresher parts more than make up for it. Overall I'd say it's worth the time and money for it, it's fairly short running at 4 hours for full completion but I don't feel short changed and hopefully there'll be a further game following the possible success of this one.

												A platformer with style! It has a great story, fun puzzles, and a classy noir setting that provides for a great adventure. Posted: December 26, 2013
												Rating 8/10Contrast is an interesting little platformer. Taking place in a 1920's setting it uses the setting to make for some great songs and soundtrack. The singer they picked for this was definitely the right choice. The gaming mechanic for this game is that the main character, Dawn, can turn into a shadow person along a wall. They use this very well and it never feels like mechanics are taking a backseat to the progression of the story or that the mechanics are being shoe-horned in.If I had any complains it would be that the game is too short. It didn't take me very long to finish the game with most of the collectibles. That was the only thing that disappointed me. There could of been build up to conclusion to the game's story at the ver least. I would definitely say it's worth the price for anyone who doesn't mind a short, but enjoyable game.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												Coming away from Contrast after some thought – it’s come to me that this is a game that I enjoyed more for its theme. I stuck with the game for its amazing setting, lovely soundtrack and to see the end of the story, rather than staying for its 3D-to-2D shifting gameplay. The shortness of the game means that the puzzle mechanics are never given the time to fully grow. Mix this up with some questionable glitches and you’re left with a game that isn’t as well constructed as one would like.Contrast is a curious, fair attempt at a puzzle platformer with some neat ideas that make it somewhat enjoyable, but is a slightly frustrating experience that in the end won’t be remembered for its gameplay, but more for its world, visuals and sound.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												A dark noir atmospheric tale set in the 1920s that is reminiscent of the Dark Horse graphic novel "Misty Circus" or many other tales of this genre inspired by Neil Gaiman or the "Beautiful Stories for Ugly Children" series. Every aspect about the game is wonderfully enchanting, from the sad storyline of a broken family and child neglect, the beautifully rendered graphics, to the melodic soundtrack. This game successfully transports you to and immerses you in a world of wonder.The mechanics are simple, crossing between a 3d world to a 2d platformer by using light and shadows. The puzzles aren't overly challenging, and neither is the platforming, nor is it necessarily a walk in the park. It's challenging enough to make you feel proud of yourself when you quicly come up with a solution, but not so challenging that you ever get frustrated.Many complaints about this game stem from there not being a tutorial, which IMHO would have ruined the allure of exploring a unqiue world. The only other complaints others have voiced is about bugs which must have been fixed because my playthrough was flawless and entirely bug-free. Pesonally, the only complaint I had about the game is that it is too short and left me wanting more! A word of warning: It can get a little dusty if you take the time to examine the collectibles in the game which may threaten your FPS machismo. You may want to keep your handkerchief nearby if you do.

Posted: December 4, 2014
												Although a bit over-priced considering it being so short (I didn't stress through the game what-so-ever and still beat it in three hours) I recommend this game, but I would advice picking it up when it's on sale, since three hours for 14 euro is a bit on the expensive side. A beutifully designed game, with an engaging and sad little story about a young girl. Filled with economical issues, romantic affairs, mafia-involvement and drama.  With heavy elements of film noir, and with a graphic style that in many ways resembles a german expressionist silent film, with a touch of Tim Burton-esque quirkiness as the beutiful cherry on top. The humoristic elements such as hidden mature jokes really made me happy and sometimes I even laughed out loud. The puzzles are interesting, all though not that hard if you're used to puzzle-solving in games. But I still feel this game brought something new to the puzzle-genre. The gameplay mechanics are very well scripted and you quickly forget what buttons you have to click and just do it on impulse, immersed in the quirky little world that the game takes place in. Overall I really enjoyed this game, but it's far too short.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												Contrast, to put into a single word, is marvelous. Its graphics are well detailed, and the way that light is used in this game is borderline genius. The voicework is well done for all characters. The music is excellent, being very rythmic and jazzy. And the story is quite interesting. The collection of collectable that you can obtain is both expansive and impactful for the length of the game. The Bioshock-esque way of using collectables to explain plot points was well done. It was always interesting to read an article about a missing person, or seeing a picture of the "scientific" explainations of the shadow world. The light puzzles that are used are especially interesting because the game mechanic of switching between two worlds is wonderfully unique and fun. All of these factors really combine to create an incredible atmosphere.However no game is without its imperfections. Though I do, in fact, recommend this game to anyone who wants a interesting experience, I must also explain the game's faults. Contrast has 2 major flaws which both fall into the gameplay category. The main problem is that Dawn, the main character, is incredibly floaty. She's a tad hard to control because her jump arc seems a tad unnatural. The second would probably be the camera. See the having the camera be controlled by the mouse is fine in third person, but when you enter the shadow world the camera tends to be kinda random, causing you to have to adjust your mouse in odd ways. The small gameplay flaws that Contrast has pales in comparison to the experience of playing it though. Playing through the game is honestly just a marvelous experience, because of it's brilliant atmosphere, as well as its unique concept.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Contrast is one of those games that has a good premise - the idea of use light and shadows to create a separate bit of 2D puzzle gameplay from the normal 3D world, but the implementation from a story and setting as well as design is a bit disconnected.  The technical approach is good in how you can shift in an our of shadows, but the problem is that the areas you can do this in are very limited and separated from each other, making each puzzle its own microcosm.   The puzzles that use this aren't that difficult as well, with the most difficult ones being where you can either move objects to change shadows or the location of the light source. Again, with the puzzles being separate entities, these are one-stop problems as opposed to part of a larger difficult mechanism to figure out.The story is interesting but it's hard to get into and leaves some questions on getting into the characters. Whether this is a fantasy, a dream, or something else isn't clear, and whether it is a flashback or the like.  As such, the game quickly devolves into just moving from puzzle to puzzle with story getting in the way.It is still a decent game, but it's one I'd wait for a sale for, getting about 3 hrs of playtime from it.
