Posted: February 27, 2014
ConceptA 2D/3D platformer where you can merge with walls to become a shadow. Utilize this to explore new possibilities in platforming.StoryThe game is divided up into chapters and acts, which you can select from the main screen if you wish. However, the game is really short. I clocked in with about 4 hours on my first playthrough, an hour of which I don't think I was playing. In addition, some mechanic frustrations also prolonged my playthrough.You play as a character named Dawn, whom only Didi can see. Didi is a child of a broken family who is trying to get back together leading to the different levels you encounter. Sometimes this leads to some interesting levels.The game also tries to induce a little mystery of if Dawn is real or not and what exactly is she. However, the game doesn't go too far along that route that it doesn't really matter, especially at the end.GraphicsThe graphics are okay. I had to run this on low settings so I cannot testify how great it can be besides online videos and pictures. I also wonder if the lack of some environment is a result of my computer or design. It does lead to some cool views. The shadow style is a pretty nifty idea that helps distract the player. As I was watching the cutscenes, I was wondering if people can be charmed by simply a shadow on the wall and a voice.SoundThe game has a Jazz music style. It fits with the setting, and the vocals aren't bad in that respect.


YouTube™ Video: Contrast: Music Trailer 

			Views: 110,952		

			Pre-order now on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/224460/ Site: http://www.contrast-thegame.com FaceBook: https://www.facebook.com/ContrastGame Twitter: https://twitter.com/ContrastGame...		

The vocals are actually fairly good too. Didi can get annoying sometimes, but sometimes her actions actually brought a smile. It's interesting that Dawn is voiceless but I guess that's to keep the player guessing what she is exactly and if she's real.GameplayThis game had a lot of promise. The idea of manipulating shadows to create solid platforming makes it a small thinking game as well. When I was little, I used to contemplate how interesting it would be if you can become a shadow. This game allows me to play with that idea a little bit, but not as much as I would have liked.You are given 5 basic controls for most of the game. Movement, Interaction, Shifting, Jump, and Dash. You also have control of the camera, which leads me to controller preferences. You do not want to play this game with a mouse and keyboard if you can avoid it. The camera is controlled with the mouse, which you also use for Dash and Shifting. This becomes a problem when you accidently move the camera while meaning to shift or dash. It has led me to many frustrations. The camera setting with the mouse is also too sensitive even after I adjusted it to get it right. When I switched to a 360 controller, the experience improved greatly. The camera was fine and my hands were less confused with which button was shift and which was dash.This game has no action in it, which is good for this style. Since there are no enemies to fight, you can focus on the platforming and puzzles you are given. The promise of the game expands with the different mechanics you find in the different chapters. There is some room for exploration, but not too much freedom. ONe time when I wanted to wander, Didi would interfere and force me to continue.Speaking of Didi, this game started to make me think about useless companions in video games; Didi is one of them. While you need to follow her to know what you next mission is, she never really helps you out. There is one occasion where she helps you out in the story and that is it. It's a shame because the image I posted near the top seemed to promise that you can use Didi to create an environment for you. There is one particular scene where I wish I could have controlled Didi to use something she was right next to instead of me doing something more complex than it needed.One of the things that could use some fine tuning is the mechanics. I resorted to Gamefaqs for one thing only to find that I was doing it right all along, but the game mechanics would screw it up.  The glitch I'm referring to is the game forcing you or an object to shift out where it shouldn't. Eventually I got it to work, but I was still upset over the whole thing. Unfortunately, the mechanics would still be glitchy every now and then, forcing me to restart multiple times when I should have easily progressed. It's a shame too, because if it wasn't for the occasional glitchy mechanics, it would have been a solid platformer. The game does have some redemption on the matter by giving you multiple checkpoints to restart from when you die and it doesn't take too long to reload.ReplayabilityAs mentioned before, the game is short and you can select specific chapters to play again. However, with the frustrations I encountered with the mechanics, and the story not being so grand, I probably would stay away from it for a while before trying to play again.OverallThis is one of those little disappointments for me. The game has promise and it shows it in sparks throughout the game. Unfortunately, it never completely capitalizes on it's potential. It can give you an interesting experience, but I think I would have more faith if they did a sequel with solid mechanics. This is a game where you might want to wait for a good sale before you buy it (maybe $5-7).My recommendation is for platforming fans who want to try something a little different. If you play with a controller and on a computer that can run it smoothly, then it is less frustrating and possible to enjoy.Taken from my blog at http://www.ign.com/blogs/falconrise/2014/02/16/game-review-contrast-for-pc

Posted: October 17, 2014
												A neat little indie with a cool gameplay hook, but Contrast falls short of its potential.  Contrast has a patchwerk story, which is incredibly unfortunate given the potential of the lore (it's visibly rushed despite a very interesting world).  I love the art style, and particularly love the 2D/3D platforming crossovers.  Contrast cleverly utilises intricate 3D world objects to affect the 2D world (to use a basic example that doesn't spoil the puzzles, dragging an item closer to the light to make the shadow on the wall bigger).  It has a 'cute' companion character and touches on some of the deeper issues surrounding families, but it only lasts about 2-3 hours on a slow playthrough.  I would say about 20-30 minutes of that focuses on the story, and the majority is spent trying to figure out the tricks for the puzzles.  Once you work them out, you could probably play from start to finish in less than an hour, without skipping.There are two types of collectibles.  One type of collectible comes from exploring and overcoming optional puzzles, and is essentially useless outside of the few occasions you need them to progress (When you need them to progress, they're very easy to find).  The other works to build up the lore, and it's quite expansive.  These collectibles flesh out the story in much greater detail than the main storyline, but mostly they serve to highlight just how unfortunate it is that Contrast was cut short.The pros:An old-fashioned setting with a great accompanying visual styleCool dynamics between 2D and 3D elementsSome deep themes around familyClever use of mechanics in puzzlesInteresting loreThe cons:Shallow and disjointed story, with a very rushed ending.The majority of playtime and difficulty comes from initially working out puzzle stylesAn irrelevant collection system (not referring to the lore collectibles)The verdict:Pick it up if you enjoy games with a sense of uniqueness, or the potential for depth (rather than depth itself).  Contrast will test your lateral thinking (though only on a few occasions), and it touches on some pretty cool concepts.

												This game is really charming. You won't find a deep, or intricate story here nor does it present itself that way. There is a lot of love, and care in the art diection, music, character designs and voice acting. The platforming is unique, and an interesting concept. My only problems with the game is that the mechanics of shifting are explained pretty vaguely. The game doesn't really tell you what you can, or can't do when shifting. So puzzles take a bit to solve because of that, and it could frustrate some people myself included. Jumping and movement is pretty sensative which is a big no-no for platformers, but they make up for it with a great jump. Finally the length. If it wasn't for me getting confused with some of the puzzles, and collecting I could've finished this game in 3 hours, or less. But once, again, this isn't a narrative like Bioshock or something, so I'm afraid that if it went on too long it would have lost its luster.All in all I enjoyed my experience, albeit with some frustration. Its a decent game, that's pretty fun, and a cute, charming story. I recommend it if its on Sale.

												This game is quite, quite lovely. The game mechanic is nicely woven into the story and the conceit about why the streets appear empty is consistent with the rest of the game and story. Not one of the characters is annoying whilst the collectables are pointless but very cute.It's almost an Art Game but lacks the self-congratulatory ♥♥♥♥♥♥isms of something like Limbo, or the sixth-form angst of Dear Ester. It is, in short, a precious shining gem of a game: a small story (in a good way) with no shooting, no hitting, and no rock music. It's also short, easy and glitchy, but worth every forced restart.Most importantly unlike every other game released in the last ten years, no zombies. Hooray!

Posted: January 11, 2014
												Contrast is a 3rd person platforming puzzle game that uses the shadows cast on walls as its primary medium. The artwork is reminiscent of the 1920's and the rest of the game follows suit. There are some incredibly good songs in this one but the overall music is just decent.The controls and actual implementation of game mechanics can feel awkward and unpolished at times. The game makes up for this though...by limiting when you actually get to use any that. Level design feels incredibly linear at points, and some of the dialog and writing could have been done better.It's a very short game and the difficulty isn't really there to prolong the length. There are some very obvious and often angering bugs that appear in game, mostly when using your shadows, which happens to be the primary game mechanic..The culmination of all these factors led me to believe that the game was not ready for release. It had a very rushed and unpolished feel to it.It was still an enjoyable play and I would recommend it for most people. When its on sale again.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												I do recommend Contrast, but just barely.  It's yet another puzzle platformer. The hook in this one is the main character can turn into a 2D shadow on the wall to overcome environmental puzzles. It's not that original of a mechanic, but it goes well with the noir look of the game. Objects and light sources get moved around to create the perfect shadow that the player can use to proceed. Unfortunately, this game is pretty easy and the 2D shadow puzzles aren't nearly as creative as they could have been. There's also a melodramatic story about bad things happening to poor people in 1920's France. Another thing too, is the world is all but empty. The game looks fantastic, but it is devoid of any life as only the main character and little girl are depicted as more than shadows on the wall. There's a kind of weird motif in the game where the player is jumping across the bodies of shadow characters acting out scenes on the sides of buildings. The game took around five hours to finish. The voice acting was good. Almost good enough to make me care about the corn ball story that throws every cliché in the book at you to manipulate your emotions. Some of the puzzles were fun and generally exploring the world of Contrast was enjoyable. The best way to summarize this game is that it had a lot of potential that was never fully realized. The actual game is just the 2D shadow projection on the wall from the game that could have been. The people that made this game are obviously talented. I'm looking forward to the next thing they do and hope they learn from their mistakes.

Posted: September 13, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Contrast is a game developed by Compulsion Games, the same people behind We Happy Few. Contrast was Compulsion Games' first game before the development of We Happy Few and the game was published by Focus Home Interactive. Contrast takes place in a Caberat setting where a young girl Didi and her friend Dawn (who you play) set out on an adventure to save Didi's father from losing out more debt on a circus he wants to buildIt seems as if Dawn is an imaginary character and only Didi can see her, Dawn also has the ability to blend in with the shadows, this is the main gameplay concept. You, as the player, have the ability to blend in with the shadows and interact with objects and go up to higher levelsThrough this you solve puzzles and progress through the story. Although this game is in 3D, a heavy amount of the game is puzzle platforming. The platforming in Contrast is the weakest bit, some of the platforming bits in the game were frustrating and outright annoyingAnother issues with Contrast is Dawn's jumping ability, its too weak and so feeble that you have to place Dawn in the exact point that the game wants you to do it, if not, you will die countless timesThe story is good although the game is extremely short (finished the main story in two hours and in one whole sitting) and I was expecting the game to be longer, however, with the annoying puzzle platforming bits and the horendous jumping ability, I was happy that the game ended quicklyThe voice acting is really good. The game camera and animation is the poorest aspect of the game (including the puzzle platforming segments and Dawn's jumping ability) and you could tell that this was Compulsion Games' first game as the animations and camera work greatly improved in their second game, We Happy FewHowever, Contrast is a nice little short puzzle platformer game which although it has a few annoying segments here and there, it is a nice game to play in one whole sitting RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: December 6, 2013
												Well where to start ? Okay I have been waiting for two years to play this game. It finally came out and so I did. It is simply like a critic once said ''It is like Limbo and Bioshock had a child together and Contrast is that child''. So rightous but also very indipendent from those games. Contrast has some references from both Bioshock and Limbo which I love them both and after I saw them I felt very touched. It's gameplay is very very unique and it has some science in it too like quantum physics and parallel universes as A.Einstein stated. My only complain was about the puzzles. Yes I know this is a puzzle platformer but it gives you so much puzzle and a little story on the sides that you would like to have some more because I think it was awesomely fair. Soundtrack is amazing if you are into Jazz/Blues. Modelling and artwork is also dashing. Ofcourse game has its problems when it comes to performance but then again this game never got a big budget so I can not blame the producers. Story is depressive and gloomy but with that being said, I like that kind of stories because life is like that too. To sum it all up, I am perfectly OK with the money I spent on this game (which I preordered it) and easily can recommend this to people around me.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												A very charming puzzle-platformer with a very impressive motif and soundtrack. The story of the game largely revolves around a broken family trying to piece itself together and is at its best when it focuses on their trials and tribulations. (It takes a weird turn near the end trying to answer questions I never asked about the broken shadow dimension that protagonist Dawn inhabits that just end up raising even more questions, but that treads into spoiler territory.) Manipulating shadows so that Dawn can become a shadow and platform across them proved to be an interesting challenge that had me scratching my head more than a few times, and they were never afraid of introducing new elements (even if some of those elements involved box-switch puzzles seen in many games before). The game is definitely a bit on the short side, however, and the only thing that kept me from clearing it 100% on my first run was a few collectibles and one item that was only available for a short time frame and ended up being lost forever. It's also very story-focused, and relies heavily on cutscenes to tell its tale. Overall, it's definitely flawed (probably rushed a bit to be a PS4 launch title), but it's an enjoyable game that should be tried.

Posted: October 12, 2014
												I'm going to recommend this game, but I will give a caveat - I bought it on a good sale, when it was under 4 bucks.  At that price, it's well worth it.  At full price... probably not.This is a nice little game, with a really fantastic concept - the idea of shifting in and out of a 2D shadow world, and solving puzzles by moving objects and lights in 3D in order to properly align their shadows in 2D is very clever.  The music and atmosphere is quite nice as well, and the voice acting is well-done.  The story is a little thin, but I can't complain too much about that.Now, the down sides.  First off, the game is quite short.  I completed it in just a few hours, and I'm sure many players could do it in even less time.  Also, the controls are a little... I don't know how to describe it, exactly.  Often, when working in the 3D world, the camera will drift a little oddly, and you end up running into a wall unintentionally.  In the 2D world, you find yourself occasionally falling out of the shadows for small things - bumping into the wrong shadow, jumping across a wall of a darker color.  Not consistently, and not enough to ruin the game, but enough to make it a little frustrating occasionally.  Control just doesn't always feel right.While there are some good puzzles, and the atmosphere is quite interesting, often it feels like the designers weren't quite sure what to do with the concept.  Finally, gameplay is interrupted far too often by cutscenes.  I understand the desire to tell the story, and to set the stage for each new area, but it is annoying when control is taken from you every 5 minutes or so.This review ended up seeming a lot more negative than I actually feel about the game.  As I said at the start, if you get it on sale for less that 5 dollars or so, I think it's worth it, if you enjoy casual puzzle games with a unique atmosphere.  Ultimately, though, I would love to see this concept fleshed out more in another game.  It's a great idea that this game just couldn't quite do justice to.

Posted: October 17, 2014
												A neat little indie with a cool gameplay hook, but Contrast falls short of its potential.  Contrast has a patchwerk story, which is incredibly unfortunate given the potential of the lore (it's visibly rushed despite a very interesting world).  I love the art style, and particularly love the 2D/3D platforming crossovers.  Contrast cleverly utilises intricate 3D world objects to affect the 2D world (to use a basic example that doesn't spoil the puzzles, dragging an item closer to the light to make the shadow on the wall bigger).  It has a 'cute' companion character and touches on some of the deeper issues surrounding families, but it only lasts about 2-3 hours on a slow playthrough.  I would say about 20-30 minutes of that focuses on the story, and the majority is spent trying to figure out the tricks for the puzzles.  Once you work them out, you could probably play from start to finish in less than an hour, without skipping.There are two types of collectibles.  One type of collectible comes from exploring and overcoming optional puzzles, and is essentially useless outside of the few occasions you need them to progress (When you need them to progress, they're very easy to find).  The other works to build up the lore, and it's quite expansive.  These collectibles flesh out the story in much greater detail than the main storyline, but mostly they serve to highlight just how unfortunate it is that Contrast was cut short.The pros:An old-fashioned setting with a great accompanying visual styleCool dynamics between 2D and 3D elementsSome deep themes around familyClever use of mechanics in puzzlesInteresting loreThe cons:Shallow and disjointed story, with a very rushed ending.The majority of playtime and difficulty comes from initially working out puzzle stylesAn irrelevant collection system (not referring to the lore collectibles)The verdict:Pick it up if you enjoy games with a sense of uniqueness, or the potential for depth (rather than depth itself).  Contrast will test your lateral thinking (though only on a few occasions), and it touches on some pretty cool concepts.

Posted: November 27, 2014
												Took me 9 hours to finish and find all collectibles and all Steam achievements. If you're used to this kind of game it might take even less, so maybe some people will probably think the game is too short.  Except for collectibles and achievements you probably won't play it more than once... However I see it as reading a short novel in a very interactive way. So if I'd pay for a book that would maybe take me 8 or 9 hours to read (and that I wouldn't read again too soon), why not pay for a game as fun as this one? I loved the story and how it unfolded.The puzzles in the beginning are very easy, but later start getting harder. Since it's a short game I definitely don't recommend reading/watching walkthroughs. The feeling of accomplishment in a game like this one is important and puzzles ARE reasonable.The only time I watched a walkthrough was in a part when I was sure there had to be a way to move a light beam and that that would help me find the solution, but I wasn't able to move it. I confirmed that that was the case and figured out by myself that I had to use the mouse (as when moving the camera) because of some probable incompatibility with the controller. So, two hints (no spoilers) you might need that for me were not that obvious and got me stuck for a long while:- Sometimes you have to get very near something to interact with it.- If you use a controller, you might still need to use the mouse every now and then to move the camera and light beams.Other than that, I got no issues with the game. The atmosphere reminds me of Grim Fandango, one of my favorite games of all times!I strongly recommend this game.

Posted: October 13, 2014
												Now here's a unusual game.  I'm all about the story. For me a game can get away with average gameplay and a great story, but this game does well in both aspects, great story and great gameplay. Add to that the great artwork, a noir atmosphere, some sad jazz tunes, and you have a game worth keeping.I'm still about halfway through (I suppose). But I've been hooked onto this game. You get to play a silent protagonist who can shift from the real world and into shadows. Shifting into a shadow makes you able to use shadows as a 2D platforms to traverse otherwise impossible to cross areas. You can use shadows as bridges or a sort of transportation device. In the real world (or should I say 3D), you get around just like any 3D platforming game. While in 3D mode you can move objects or light sources to arrange shadows in a way that could help you through some obstacles. The combination of 3D and 2D platforming make for interesting puzzles and a unique gameplay. Definitely, a game worth buying, sale or no sale.

Posted: October 13, 2014
												A stunning game. Brilliant concept backed up by some really nice graphics. The storyline is so engaging that I found it hard to put down. The puzzles were often a touch of genius. Not that they were difficult, only one or two stumped me and even then only for a short while. The genius is in the way they suck you into the story a little more each time. Especially the 'flashback' puzzles which can be tricky but never frustrating because the scene you are replaying is always a poignant moment in the story.The soundtrack sets the tone just right and the voice acting is spot on. In particular Teale Bishopric was amazingly good as Didi.Yes I have a few gripes. Jumping could be frustrating at times because it's a little to sensitive to collisions and it would have been nice to be able to customize the key mapping but that's about it.It's a short game but one I will remember for a long time. I think it's almost the perfect length for the story. Yes I would have liked more but that's because I enjoyed it so much.

Posted: October 14, 2014
												Exactly what it says on the tin:  a puzzle platformer requiring you to shift between the 3D "real world" and the 2D "shadow world." Even the real world has its own strange characteristics however, such as bottomless pits, which makes you wonder just how "real" it is.  I recommend this game for those of you who like platformers or atmostpheric stories.My one complaint about the game is that the collision boxes are sometimes unpredictable, such that you may occasionally misjudge your jumps or object interactions.  However, this doesn't really affect your ability to complete the game, so you may consider this a minor nitpick.The story is of the "small and personal" kind.  You're not saving the galaxy; you're just taking care of a little girl.  Depending on your attitude towards precocious children, this girl may or may not be annoying to you. Posted: October 24, 2014
												Amazing game! Not only do you get to explore a nice French 1932 environment with some interesting achievements, you get to run along walls and use the light and shadows to your advantage. Can't reach that high up balcony? Shift the light around until shadows form for you to walk on. Simple, short, but so much fun!Does this game have downsides? Yes, it does, but nothing much to make you stop playing. For one, this game is fairly short, only three acts. I played 8 hours and got all the collectibles and achievements. And I'm not even too great at platformers. Also, as demonstrated in the trailer, the little girl you with helps you along the shadows by holding up a stick. Sadly (SPOILER), that is the only time that happens. I think they could've used that mechanic better.Still, I'd say this game is a definate must-buy, if you can get it on a discount. 8/10, mostly because of flawless gameplay, beautiful art-design and great jazzy music.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												In the end everybody should stand up and give a round of applause, so impressive and nicely done.The mechanics through entering the shadows and having to exit creates such awesome puzzles.Gameplay and graphics are well done, actually much more than that.However the masterpiece in this game is the soundtrack, FABULOUS. When I first opened the game while hearing the song over the menu, really, that was an awesome sensation. It was literally music to my ears and this high level of soundtrack keeps going during all the game.I don't know if it is kind of a spoiler but at first I was like in doubt in the first scene where Didi is in her room and her mom appears through the shadows, but that makes sense over the ending.Only a few issues with my controller that would not jump in certain occasions that would soon enough become normal.(I think the problem really is in my controller not really how the game adapted it, but...)Only a few bugs with the character and the scenario, nothing like would destroy the game, because it doesn't even affect the gameplay (like the carousel would spin and the character stands still).The studio created their own style, of course people will compare it limbo (black and white through the shadows) and I still don't know why but gave me a déjà vu of bioshock infinite like the theory from multiverse and portals used between shadows, people will say that somehow the appearance of Dawn remembers Elizabeth and the city is in the sky?(That's what it looks like to me). Congratulations for the studio and keep the hard work to develop others great pieces of art like these. (And let me know about it, I would love to play again any other creation).

Posted: July 4, 2014
												Contrast left me wanting more. I loved the shadow world you get to explore with Dawn and Didi. Its style and story is the kind of thing you best see in foreign films and the magic realism of Neil Gaiman (Mirrormask in particular kept cropping up as I played).Didi has a friend no one else can see named Dawn, who looks like she's an acrobat of some kind. What is her story? How did she gain her powers? Is she real or a figment of Didi's imagination? None of this is ever truly explained over the game's short running time (I finished it with all the achievements in a little over 3 hours), but what does happen is Dawn getting involved in the story of Didi and her parents. Her mom is a lounge singer and her father is a shiftless dreamer in debt to the mob. Jonny has one more scheme up his sleeve to get back in Didi's mom's good graces, and Didi will do everything in her power to help make it happen (with Dawn's help, naturally).It's hard not to get excited as you run and jump through Contrast's levels. The music and art design sell the world well, and the voice acting draws you into the struggles of its inhabitants, told enough enough as shadow plays. These are just for story design either; oftentimes you'll have to make use of the shadows you see to reach a switch or a puzzle piece. Collectibles take the form of either documents that reveal the game's backstory or glowing globes also used to power some of the game's puzzles.A lot has been said about the game's controls. I found them as tight as could be expected with the mechanics, with a handheld controller the best way to go. A keyboard and mouse setup could work but the best experience I think would be found with a controller if able.Contrast decides not to overstay its welcome, but I hope that the game devs do come back for an encore performance.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												While I recommend this game for its tremendous style, awesome soundtrack and clever concept, I feel there are two warnings for prospective buyers. First, a skilled player can probably complete it, achievements and all, in about two hours. In this day and age of hundred hour rpgs and unlimited online play, some may feel this affects the value. Secondly, there were times when I really felt that the controls didn't work as they should and I found it very frustrating. I'm not the best at platformers by a long shot, but I feel like their were times I missed jumps and it really wasn't my fault. Overall, I would say this game is like a short art film. It oozes style and tells a sweet, albeit simple story. Wonderful to experience, I think anyone who made it so far as reading this review should pick it up, because the factors that likely drew them to this point are all there and in spades.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												It's kind of hard to give an all out recommendation for this game. I love the idea and when the gameplay works, its fantastic. The trouble is that the gameplay is a little buggy still, particularly the mouse controls (maybe it was designed to work better with a controller) and the whole thing feels a bit short with the world shifting and light mechanics a little under utilized for what they could have been. Seeing as the game is pretty cheap and even a bit longer than other clever puzzle games like Portal, if they patched it to run a little less buggy, I could whole heartedly recommend it. What I'd really like to see would be a better funded, or at least better polished sequel. That would be awesome!

Posted: July 5, 2014
												You know when you find a game that has fantastic setting and story, but the soundtrack is off? Or the voice actors don't sound like they mesh with the characters? The story is nice and the characters are believable but they just don't fit the setting? Well, this game is a finely crafted work of art. Everything about it just fits. the music, character design, everything aesthetic about this game was chosen by people who clearly not only care about how well the game fits together but independently enjoy every aspect of this game from the art direction to me imaging the game devs just sitting in a coffee shop listening to this style of music while reading a book. It is clear to me that the team responsible for this true gem of a game were not making this because someone higher in the company food chain told them to, the love wouldn't be there, they made this game because they loved and believed in it. Whatever issues I have with the controls are minuscule compared to how enjoyable the game is to experience. My only…I guess complaint is the best word for it, is that the music doesn’t play throughout the game play. I was stuck on a puzzle for about 10 mins before finding a simple answer and all I could think was how little I would care about being stuck if I could just hear some of the wonderful music.  I cannot wait to see what this crew of dreamers puts out next.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												A dark noir atmospheric tale set in the 1920s that is reminiscent of the Dark Horse graphic novel "Misty Circus" or many other tales of this genre inspired by Neil Gaiman or the "Beautiful Stories for Ugly Children" series. Every aspect about the game is wonderfully enchanting, from the sad storyline of a broken family and child neglect, the beautifully rendered graphics, to the melodic soundtrack. This game successfully transports you to and immerses you in a world of wonder.The mechanics are simple, crossing between a 3d world to a 2d platformer by using light and shadows. The puzzles aren't overly challenging, and neither is the platforming, nor is it necessarily a walk in the park. It's challenging enough to make you feel proud of yourself when you quicly come up with a solution, but not so challenging that you ever get frustrated.Many complaints about this game stem from there not being a tutorial, which IMHO would have ruined the allure of exploring a unqiue world. The only other complaints others have voiced is about bugs which must have been fixed because my playthrough was flawless and entirely bug-free. Pesonally, the only complaint I had about the game is that it is too short and left me wanting more! A word of warning: It can get a little dusty if you take the time to examine the collectibles in the game which may threaten your FPS machismo. You may want to keep your handkerchief nearby if you do.

												I must say that i've wanted to play Contrast really badly because of the fluent 3d-2d in game mechanics transitions, and I was not dissapointed. Posted: July 3, 2014
												I might not be able to explain why Contrast is so amazing, but that doesn't mean I'm not going to try.Basiclly, the takes place in 1920's France and you take control of Dawn, the imaginary friend of a little girl named Didi. As of imaginary friends, only Didi can see you. You also find out her dad, Johnny, was kicked out because resulting in him trying ridiculous ideas to get back. Kat, Didi's mother, is a singer in The Ghost Note.Johnny tries go get famous illusionist Vincenzo to perform for him to get money for some gangters, ofcourse, thing's goes wrong, so "Didi" (Dawn) fixes everything.I'd rather not spoil anymore, as the story is quite amazing, and needs to experienced for yourself.Oh, did I mention you can shift between the real and shadow dimension?That allows great platforming due to shifting lights.However, I only have two problems with the game:1. The humanoid shadows sometimes have holes and are abit glitchy, but that can be forgiven!2. The platforming sometimes screw abit up, sometimes you fall out of the Shadow World randomly, and falling in 3D is very easy.Might be one of the best games I've ever played, with a great storyline, score and gameplay.10/10

Posted: April 30, 2016
												I enjoyed this game a lot, but I really recommend getting when its on sale.  The story is very interesting and whimisical in its own way, but this is definitely one of those games that could have benefited from a bit more content.  I feel like a lot of content was cut or scrapped before it made it in which is unfortunate because there is a completely different story that it sounds like never made it in.  I beat the game in just over 3 hours, but I did that while still taking the time to poke around in the corners and retrying the more difficult puzzles multiple times (during the shadow puppet show I would intentionally die so the narrator would have to interupt himself and mention how I died, that was probably a good 20 plus minutes right there).  Someone good at platforming could probably clear it in less than 2.  Also, the shadow jumping is not as smooth as the trailers imply, just a heads up.  Several things they imply you can do in game aren't viable moves.  Aside from that?  I would definitely pick this game up for $5.  The story is fun, the game play is interesting, and while short I did enjoy the game.  Most of the other reviews touch on the things I liked and disliked so check them for more details.

												The game lives up to the other reviews on the novelty it introduces and it was a pleasure to play as Dawn and merge/transit between both worlds and is a magical beauty to see such world rendered.As a true puzzle game you will find both puzzles in 3D and 2D, and why not: both :)Soundtrack is something quite good out of an indie game, albeit repetitive and small in its reporteur.Story is linear and with not to handle much surprises, perhaps best enjoyed by gathering all collectibles.Only a couple downsides for me:- Game physics engine: it really is a nag sometimes.   Although the transition between 'universes' is crisp, elements in a scene can (and most likely will to you?) render the play frustrating at certain point.- Small game but from an indie production don't expect much. That said, the label price cam be quite hefty whilst I got my copy on Steam Sales and see the price adequate (instead of something nort of £8+).Overall: a good game. Play it if you can, a good experience and great concept.P.S. - Oh, I got the the soundtrack as well. This should really come standard with the game.

												This game is quite, quite lovely. The game mechanic is nicely woven into the story and the conceit about why the streets appear empty is consistent with the rest of the game and story. Not one of the characters is annoying whilst the collectables are pointless but very cute.It's almost an Art Game but lacks the self-congratulatory ♥♥♥♥♥♥isms of something like Limbo, or the sixth-form angst of Dear Ester. It is, in short, a precious shining gem of a game: a small story (in a good way) with no shooting, no hitting, and no rock music. Posted: June 29, 2014
												As someone who went into this game with little expectation - due to ignorance not due to any negative view point - I can say that I'm incredibly impressed.  The shadow mechanic that is the main aspect of this game is incredibly well done and the puzzles and platforming are challenging without feeling as though they are impossible.  The plot was thick and gripping enough to keep me interested in the characters I interacted with, but not so overwhelming that it felt like the puzzles were filling in the space between cut scenes.I would absolutely recommend playing this game if you're intersted in puzzle or platforming games.  I would also recommend it if you enjoy playing games that are plot-heavy.

Posted: December 4, 2014
												Although a bit over-priced considering it being so short (I didn't stress through the game what-so-ever and still beat it in three hours) I recommend this game, but I would advice picking it up when it's on sale, since three hours for 14 euro is a bit on the expensive side. A beutifully designed game, with an engaging and sad little story about a young girl. Filled with economical issues, romantic affairs, mafia-involvement and drama.  With heavy elements of film noir, and with a graphic style that in many ways resembles a german expressionist silent film, with a touch of Tim Burton-esque quirkiness as the beutiful cherry on top. The humoristic elements such as hidden mature jokes really made me happy and sometimes I even laughed out loud. The puzzles are interesting, all though not that hard if you're used to puzzle-solving in games. But I still feel this game brought something new to the puzzle-genre. The gameplay mechanics are very well scripted and you quickly forget what buttons you have to click and just do it on impulse, immersed in the quirky little world that the game takes place in. Overall I really enjoyed this game, but it's far too short.

The puzzles are not always straight forward... it's not always as easy as 2D vs 3D... sometimes you have to dig deep.Fun Factor -  4/5Can't really say much without giving it away. It was, at times, incredibly annoying. But no matter how much I hated it at the time I turned it off, I always came back.Replay Value - 1/5Unfortunatly, I believe this is one of the few areas where this game fails. Though the game is awesome, the only replay would be collectables missed in your previous playthrough.Presentation/Graphics - 4/5The game didn't make use of all the mechanics available to it... but that's okay... It wasn't meant to. It's done in a depression era art kind of way and is part of it's appeal. Fluidity of the transition between 2D and 3D was nice. The only complaints I had were that, at one point, an object I needed started floating above me where I couldn't reach it and had to reload and near the end, as I started to fall (to my death, I missed a ledge).... just stopped... couldn't jump, couldn't fall, couldn't move. Other than those two things, marvolous.Storyline - 4/5Don't get me wrong, the story in, and of, itself was absolutly flawless. I loved the backgroud (loved the ending even more). My only complaint is that it was too short. The game could have been a little longer (maybe 5-10 more hours of gameplay).Summary/Overall Score - 3.6 of 5Overall, a solid game. If I am to read the game correctly, I expect another. I do hope that, if true, the sequal will be a little more developed and incoorporate a longer storeyline, more gameplay, and an answer to the question thrown in our faces at the end. I would reccomend this, if only to help the developer to make a new one and continue this intriguing story.

Posted: November 25, 2015
												Contrast grabbed me right from the get-go with its cover art, and after I saw the trailer, I knew I had to play it.Contrast is not perfect, if I'm being totally honest.  It's kind of short, and sometimes a little rough around the edges when it comes to trying to finesse the tricker bits.  It's also mabye a bit too easy, and platforming pros will blow right through it.However, Contrast has an amazing atmosphere and aesthetic, and good music to boot.  There's a nice story that will keep you moving through the game.  Also, the whole concept, having a 3D character who can merge into shadows for some 2D platforming, is a stroke of genius.  Navigation using this mechanic just delights me every time I use it.  It's seriously that much fun.I played this one to a fairly easy 100% completion a while back, and I'm surprised by how often I get the urge to replay it.  Every time I scroll past it in my library, I think, "Man, I should play Contrast again soon".  Do yourself a favor and give it a shot.  Even if you don't like it as much as I do, I think you'll agree that it was worth your time.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												Recommending this game was a hard decision, and in fact it is by no means worth its regular price. I got the collectors edition for 6€ in a sale, which is still on the upper end of what I think the game should actually cost. You can beat the game in under two hours. If you speedrun a second playthrough it's probably one hour flat. But there is no real replay value. I missed one collectable and I can't picture me hunting that last piece any time soon.I only have 15 hours on this title because I alt-tab'ed out of it and finished it the next day. But it's not a bad game. The story and dialoque are simple yet ok, the visual style is quite nice as is the 3D/2D shift mechanics.It's one of those short indie games you wish it would've had the development time and budget of a AAA title.So grab it the next time it's 75% off, solve a few puzzles with Didi and Dawn ... and dream of what could've been ...

Posted: November 15, 2015
												This is a very charming story-driven platformer with a wonderful little mechanic. It runs very smoothly even on the highest settings and while it's a fairly short game, a lot of work went into it. The voice acting is great, the story is very cute, and the concept is just brilliant. I'd definitely suggest giving the game a try. It's graphically stunning and the art style is so clever.That being said... I do warn against a few frustrating puzzles. Not because the puzzles are particularly challenging, but because sometimes the mechanic can be frustrating. There are times that the controls aren't sensitive enough, or are too sensitive, and there are a few minor glitches that can be annoying. Sometimes the slightly wonky controls can break your enjoyment. But all in all, the game is charming.

Posted: November 15, 2015
												Contrast is a puzzle based platform game, developed by Compulsion Games.In this game you follow the story of a small girl Didi Malenkaya who has an imaginary friend called Dawn.No one else can see Dawn, but that does not mean she does not exsist.Didi found herself in a world where she only sees people as shadows.Her parents are having relationship problems and many debts to pay off. They both are too busy to take care of Didi, her mother Kat Malenkaya works as a singer at the Ghost Note cabaret while her father Johnny Fenris has been kicked out of the house because of doing business with gangsters in order to make some money.Child services have threatened to take Didi away from her mother.Didi can't stand this situation anymore and together with Dawn she sneaks out of the house to save the situation between her parents.Contrast is set in a 1920 Nior atmosphere.In this game you play as Dawn who has the ability to shift into the 2D shadow world and back into the 3D world. Throughout the game you have to help Didi solve puzzles that vary from moving objects between the physical 3D world and the 2D shadow world. Manipulating light sources in the 3D world such as spotlights, film projectors etc. will create shadow paths. These paths will lead Dawn to new areas containing collectibles like Luminaries (light sources) and Documents that reveal more about the story.Contrast felt like a very unique game because the ability of shifting between the physical 3D world and the 2D shadow world was something I have never seen before in games.Everything I already knew about puzzles games couldn't always match up to the puzzles in Contrast.This will make you think more out of the box, requires a little more creative thinking and raise the bar of puzzles.I must admit that Contrast has a short length of gameplay and the story itself does not have that much depth than I expected it to be.I really recommend Contrast for its unique experience but I don't think it's worth the full price, purchase the game when it's on sale.

Posted: April 4, 2015
												   If you like small but good games this a really good purchase, otherwise if you prefer bigger fully developed games i wouldn't really recommend it. The game itself is awesome, the ideas are amazing and the soundtrack and environment can really blow your mind. But theres a problem in the middle of all the amazing stuff. The game itself is underdeveloped. That makes some really nice characteristics seem bad a lousy and end up ruining your experience.    Overall you can pass the game 100% in less than 4 hours. There are some colectiables but most of the time you dont even need to search for them because they are right in front of you. The devs probably wanted the general environmetn to be bigger but something went wrong and they ended up giving a huge amount of content in a place where it shouldn't exist and only made the entire plot more confusing than it already is. The story is amazing but a lot of details where left untold just because the game lenght wasnt big enough to carry all of them. There are some bugs that shouldve been fixed and sometimes the entire shadow-person mechanic feels a bit cluncky. it would be awesome if you could change not only into a shadow but also to a difrent shadow size. overall the shadow you trnasform into is you in 2D instead of your other stange amazing reallity. Overall its a preatty decent game but that could be improved in various aspects.I would compare my gameplay Story experience of this game with my gameplay experience i had with bioshock infinite. There is however a huge difrence amoung them. Bioshock is fully developed and is almost bug free. It has an awesome replayability, an awesome story, awesome mechanics and the colectiables are hard to find and pretty damn awesome to get entirely. Contrats on the other hand is poorly developed, has a lot of bugs, almost no replayability since you cant change the way you play to make the story a difrent experience, super shor game length, the story is awesome and really good but lacks detail in many ways, the mechanics are awesome but you end up barely having to use them and the colectiables end up giving you a worse experience overall.I really realy want to tell the world about this game because its really awesome. I would pay 50 bucks for it if i needed to. But this game is not finished. I would say thats in its current state the game is 70% away from behing the best game ever made. And im talking about 70% off wich 10%would be bug fixes, 20% increasing the scenario availible to explore, 10% actually making the colectiables hard to find and woth finding, 10%making more puzzles and 20% increasing the story told to the player soo it can actually mean something more. TLDR. This game has the capability to have a 90+ rating however lacks some development that reallly ruins some important gameplay details. I consider it a must play tho just for the overall experience.

												I don't know why it only says 23 minutes played... This game is great, a fantastic debut from Compulsion Games creators of the ever increasingly anticapated We Happy Few. Posted: June 19, 2016
												Got this on sale and finally play through it.Is this a good game?Well if I could, I would give it a netrualBut if you can get it on a sale, go for it. It will properly take you 2-4 hours to complete it.The Good: 1) The mix with shadows are a fun and enjoyable2) The artstyle is interesting and for me appealing3) The puzzles are aren't hard or to easy - most will see the solution without to much hassle.4) The english voice acting is pretty goodThe Neutral:1) The story is cute, but the ending is a bit disappointingThe Annoying: 1) Controls, controls and the bloody controls. This pulls the game down, for me. Almost to the point where I don't want to recommend it. The character seems floaty and often slide of things she should be able to stand on. Or falls through objects or out of shadows for no apparent reason. It makes the game more difficult than it has any right to. And interacting with objects, is camera based - oh the camera.2) The camera, isn't there to help you. It's doesn't follow your movement and often so close navigating is a pain. And best of all, when you want to interact with objects - the camera is the deciding factor which object is chosen. Example: Lets say there are 2 objects, the character is standing facing object A the camera is slitghly turned to object B - Object B is the object that will be used. I have spend just as much time playing camera man as controlling my character through the puzzles.But in the end, it was a neat 3 hours in the company of Contrast.Hope this helps you, in your quest for good games and sorry for any spelling mistakes :)

Posted: June 29, 2016
												This game is truly unique, and absolutely stunning, both visually and story-wise, but WAY too short for full price.  I wandered quite a lot, have an incredible knack for getting lost, suck at platformers*, and got most of the collectibles all in 5 hours.  I was completely thrown by the ending, not because of how it ended, but because it ended so abruptly.  I feel like it was only about half finished when they realized they had a deadline so instead of compromising on ANY aspect of gameplay, they decided to leave the ending as a Sopranos-esque sharp cutoff.  I can respect that a hell of a lot more than rushing through and releasing a clunky mess of a game full of bugs. *During the play, a shameful number of times - ".... unfortunately, she impaled herself on the bamboo.  Wait, no, that's not what happened!"8/10 ADORED the game, but wish there was more of it. Immediate purchase when on sale, though!

Posted: September 22, 2016
Great concept, great visuals... but is it worth its price?Contrast is a fun single player Platformer with the great concept of switching between 3D and 2D. At one moment you wander around in the colourful yet desaturated noir style world, when you have to plunge into the nearest wall to let your shadow finish a certain puzzle. For me, the visuals, and the way certain parts of the game are changing throughout the level was pretty cool.While providing 2-3 hours of gameplay (depending on how skilled you are as well as how much time you spend exploring), Contrast tells the story of the girl Didi Malenkaya. In the 3 acts provided, the player gets to play as Dawn - Didis imaginary friend - and learns a bit about their past as well as discovers new details about Didi and her family's past. While not being the most complex of stories ever told, it's still an interesting tale that gets completed by gethering collectibles throughout the levels.The puzzle and platforming elements themself are pretty well executed but sometimes lack of difficulty. I do know, that Contrast was not intended to be an overly difficult game, yet some parts seemed just too easy, while some had the perfect mixture of difficulty in figuring out what to do and actually doing so. Sadly, like in many other games, there were one or two plain frustrating parts in the game, when the objective was figured out quickly, but the execution took a lot of time because of "bad" level design or more often bugs.As just mentioned, bugs were one of the only negative aspects of the game. While (most of them) most of them were not game breaking, they were pretty constitant throughout the game. By that I mean, wierd clipping through walls (that can be performed on purpose to get some stuff earlier), gettig shot out of the wall when being in 2D or getting stuck in places you shouldnot reach. For me, especially the Pirate Cove part was a bit of an issue as I got stuck in some of the ships placed throughout the level several time withozut being able to get out again. Because of this I had to repeat the level three times, as Checkpoints are sometimes set a bit weirdly.While being a bit short and having some minor flaws that could be fixed "easily", 10$ might seem a bit pricy, but in my opinion, when bought on sale, Contrast is a great gaming experience, if not for just it's Shadow Puppet part and general visuals alone.  7/10

Posted: September 11, 2016
												Contrast is a very nice little platformer with a really interesting game mechanic; in well lit areas you can turn yourself into a 2d shadow and platform with the shadows on the walls to solve puzzles. This mechanic allows Contrast to give players both a 3d and 2d world to solve puzzles. Great voice acting and good, period appropriate music draw you into a well written story about a little girl and her (imaginary?) friend, as they navigate through the lives of her and her parents. And wonderful animations and artwork help craft this world into a very interesting environment for the player to solve the puzzles that are put into the characters paths.That's not to say the game is perfect. It isn't. There are some camera issues here and there, not enough to ruin the game but it can pull you out of the story every now and then. Also, if you only play on a keyboard then you may well hate the control scheme. The controls were picture perfect on my Steam Controller but oddly delayed on my keyboard and sometimes locking out certain commands until I reloaded. Stick with a controller. And once it was all complete I really found no reason to go back.Anyway, for a 3-4 hour game experience Contrast is well worth checking out, but you might want to wait for a sale. Pros:Beautifully animatedWell WrittenGreat controller supportinnovative level design and game mechanicsNice soundtrack and localesExcellent voice actingCons:Very shortBad keyboard supportNot much replay value

Posted: September 13, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Contrast is a game developed by Compulsion Games, the same people behind We Happy Few. Contrast was Compulsion Games' first game before the development of We Happy Few and the game was published by Focus Home Interactive. Contrast takes place in a Caberat setting where a young girl Didi and her friend Dawn (who you play) set out on an adventure to save Didi's father from losing out more debt on a circus he wants to buildIt seems as if Dawn is an imaginary character and only Didi can see her, Dawn also has the ability to blend in with the shadows, this is the main gameplay concept. You, as the player, have the ability to blend in with the shadows and interact with objects and go up to higher levelsThrough this you solve puzzles and progress through the story. Although this game is in 3D, a heavy amount of the game is puzzle platforming. The platforming in Contrast is the weakest bit, some of the platforming bits in the game were frustrating and outright annoyingAnother issues with Contrast is Dawn's jumping ability, its too weak and so feeble that you have to place Dawn in the exact point that the game wants you to do it, if not, you will die countless timesThe story is good although the game is extremely short (finished the main story in two hours and in one whole sitting) and I was expecting the game to be longer, however, with the annoying puzzle platforming bits and the horendous jumping ability, I was happy that the game ended quicklyThe voice acting is really good. The game camera and animation is the poorest aspect of the game (including the puzzle platforming segments and Dawn's jumping ability) and you could tell that this was Compulsion Games' first game as the animations and camera work greatly improved in their second game, We Happy FewHowever, Contrast is a nice little short puzzle platformer game which although it has a few annoying segments here and there, it is a nice game to play in one whole sitting RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: January 22, 2016
 Save the circus, or jump to your death multiple times trying...  ...But it's not just Kat and Johnny's relationship that needs saving, you also get to repair a funfair ! 	Contrast is a fairly short game, which has its charming moments. It's atmospheric and witty but also has a very significant rage potential.	Biggest problems I've had : lack of checkpoints, and the controls are wonky. No, I mean really wonky. If Didi has to rely on an imaginary friend who can't jump onto a box right in front of her, or keeps dashing off the edge of the world and plummeting to her death, that kid had probably better join the circus... but we all know where that got her father...	The plot starts out fine, but the end feels rushed. Was personally expecting a bit more Didi, since she's meant to be the main character. However, I felt like the kid gets left out, both by her family and the game, replaced with quite a bit of fragile masculinity (see Johnny or Fred the Knight), and marriage issues (also Johnny).        On the whole, would recommend Contrast as it's very atmospheric and I loved the concept, but if you're unsure, I suggest waiting until it's on sale. ( + ) Positives  :+ visually pleasing+ great soundtrack+ amazing concept, mixing 2D and 3D+ fun puzzles (others not so much... trial and (t)error) ( - ) Negatives  :- A carousel of broken controls- Tragic lack of checkpoints making the game very much like Kat and Johnny's relationship : very difficult to save.- Game involves explicit language... on my part (mostly because of the previously mentioned points).- Broken fingers (see previous points)- … gurshdarn Fred the Knight

Posted: January 2, 2016
												Contrast is a challenging puzzle game that has you leaping back and forth between corporeal and shadow form to help a little girl fix things for her father. The game has a film noir feel, set to a lovely jazz soundtrack. You have to play with light and shadows to solve a lot of the puzzles. Contrast provides a truly unique experience. I enjoyed it all; from the background story, to the music and ambience, to the challenge of figuring out the puzzles. I highly recommend it.

												This game has an interesting plot and game play which makes me want to recommend it.  DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Contrast is a game developed by Compulsion Games, the same people behind We Happy Few. Contrast was Compulsion Games' first game before the development of We Happy Few and the game was published by Focus Home Interactive. Contrast takes place in a Caberat setting where a young girl Didi and her friend Dawn (who you play) set out on an adventure to save Didi's father from losing out more debt on a circus he wants to buildIt seems as if Dawn is an imaginary character and only Didi can see her, Dawn also has the ability to blend in with the shadows, this is the main gameplay concept. You, as the player, have the ability to blend in with the shadows and interact with objects and go up to higher levelsThrough this you solve puzzles and progress through the story. Although this game is in 3D, a heavy amount of the game is puzzle platforming. The platforming in Contrast is the weakest bit, some of the platforming bits in the game were frustrating and outright annoyingAnother issues with Contrast is Dawn's jumping ability, its too weak and so feeble that you have to place Dawn in the exact point that the game wants you to do it, if not, you will die countless timesThe story is good although the game is extremely short (finished the main story in two hours and in one whole sitting) and I was expecting the game to be longer, however, with the annoying puzzle platforming bits and the horendous jumping ability, I was happy that the game ended quicklyThe voice acting is really good. The game camera and animation is the poorest aspect of the game (including the puzzle platforming segments and Dawn's jumping ability) and you could tell that this was Compulsion Games' first game as the animations and camera work greatly improved in their second game, We Happy FewHowever, Contrast is a nice little short puzzle platformer game which although it has a few annoying segments here and there, it is a nice game to play in one whole sitting RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: March 10, 2016
												I only got this game based off of a short trailer featuring the unique gameplay aspects of this game, and I must say everything else about it, to my delight, took me by surprise. The French 1920's noir setting with mystery and hints to the lasting effects of the World's Fair really make this a world of its own. Along with very unique story telling that show things as you might imagine through the eyes of a child, and how all of the other adults are shown only in shadow, you can easily begin to feel the world live on it's own. The game can be seen as short, but in my personal opinion the length is perfect. They tell the story they wanted to tell, it isn't drawn out, and it doesn't overly complicate things.While the gameplay itself feels a bit like the bracelt mechanic in LoZ: A Link Between Worlds, the platforming and world manipulation aspects really put this in its own category. It works off the Unreal engine, which is known for having issues with lower budget productions. Surprisingly Contrast doesn't show many signs of that. There are a few times where walls that aren't completely flat can throw you out of shadow, and if you get one interactable object too close to another you can't choose between which one you wish to interact with, but aside from that I didn't experience many other issues.All in all, if you are looking for something simple and sweet, I highly suggest you try this out. If you already have it, get on it.

Posted: March 12, 2016
												What can I say about this game, if you enjoy a Noir art style that looks stunning, and music that is unique compared to other games you may play. I can happily say this is the game for you. From the start I was impressed with this game, firstly not matter what graphic setting you choose the details remain the same, the only difference is the lighting (the higher the setting the more “noir” the game becomes. Even playing in the lowest settings this game becomes a joy to play with its amazing soundtrack that you should buy with the game and upload to your music device soon as you can. No joke I’ve been playing the soundtrack on my morning run for the last week or two.The voice acting is clear and easy to understand, nether unsure of where you need to go. If you do go the wrong way more often than not you will encounter a closed gate or Didi will force a cutscene asking where you are going. The only downside I would mention is that the game does take some learning when jumping between the 2D puzzles and 3d World, this may vary from person to person, those used to shooters and FPS games might experience more of a learning curve than those who prefer Indie and puzzle games. Not helped that you can jump into and shadow you find, this would be a major bonus if they added more secret areas or goals to complete, but for my playthroughs it caused me to stop and figure out if this was the right direction i needed to go.The world itself takes a 1920’s theme, then thrown together with a dreamworld to add a surrealist element to the environment, this catches you by surprise as you only begin to see this style more half way through the first section of the game. Unfortunately there are some flaws to the game, it is a basic platform and does come with some collision issues (tied in with the shadow 2d world you can avoid some segments all together) and it is relatively short, yet despite all the flaws of this game i would play and play again just for screenshot purposes and the music.If you wanted a different game to play for a evenings entertainment I would recommend this in a heartbeat.

Posted: March 10, 2016
												On the whole I really enjoyed Contrast, but the story, although interesting, gets in the way of the gameplay a little too much. Also, I only really started to feel like I was playing the 'proper' game about halfway through, as the first half felt like one very long tutorial. This left the game as a whole feeling too short, as I was only really getting into it shortly before it ended. I really hope they do a sequel and try and concentrate on the gameplay a bit more now that they've sorted the mechanics out.I'd definitely recommend it, but it requires quite a bit of patience!

Posted: March 8, 2016
												An amazingly beautiful and relaxing puzzlegame. The puzzles in this game are fairly simple to figure out, I only found myself being stuck once as I had missed a pretty important mechanic. However, the big drive of this game is the beautiful and weird shadow-world with a french twist. The music in the game is calming, and everything just feels right!This game is perfect for when you are tired, and just want to watch a movie, or listen to some relaxing music. This game has it all!It has a few collectable items and eastereggs, but it doesn't get overwhelming by having 1231512 different items for you to find in each stage. All of the collectibles provide you with different insights to the story, but at the same time, you don't need any of them to understand what's going on.Sadly I found the game to be a bit short, but it is a very good game difficultywise and imagewise for people of all ages.Highly recommended for a friday afternoon with the kids!

Posted: February 12, 2016
												A unique game with stunning art concepts and imagery throughout. You learn two stories as they unravel and solve complex puzzles and are able to manipulate items in the world as well as the shadowy background pieces to create a unique platform-style view. It brings things - objects, people, and ideas - to the foreground and you interact in ways you hadn't considered. It definitely takes time to see the shadows as solid leges and tangible objects, but it was surprisingly easy to use the controls. I was enthralled! The shadows tell a story of their own!! I sped through this game and wish that there were more like it!!
